Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 7 October 1986, at 2 p.m., unless Madam Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF MULTICULTURAL AFFAIRS REPEAL BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill 1986 is a result of the decision announced by the Government on 12 August 1986 as part of its new strategy on multiculturalism. It will repeal the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act 1979 and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Amendment Act 1985. In essence, it will abolish the Institute. The legislation vests all rights, property and assets of AIMA with the Commonwealth at the time of abolition. The Bill requires that a final report and audit of the Institute will be prepared and laid before the Parliament. It also prescribes that any surplus funds available from the winding up of the Institute will go to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Director of AIMA will be retained as an employee of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on a temporary basis for just six months. The rest of the staff will lose their jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading speech by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) he noted that the Bill would protect the Commonwealth's interests in the process of abolishing the Institute. He reminded honourable members that the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983 stated:
The future wellbeing of this country depends upon the acceptance of the cultural, social and economic implications of a multicultural Australia.

The Government's response to this mandate has been to dump one of the institutions which has been inextricably linked with the development which the Summit described. The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs was established by legislation in November 1979. The Fraser Government took up a significant recommendation of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants, better known as the Galbally report. Galbally said:
If we are to achieve the real benefits of a multicultural society, its development must be guided, supported and given direction by independent experts of high calibre.

The six years of operation of AIMA present a record of considerable achievement. The Institute has been called upon to undertake a wide range of activities in providing advice to the Government, research, the publication and dissemination of information and community education. Among its major achievements, projects and activities are an evaluation of the effectiveness of labour market programs and the particular problems and impact of unemployment on migrant and refugee young people and a review of migrant and multicultural education which provided the impetus for the funding of ethnic schools, many of which have been highly successful in developing, preserving and sustaining the traditional values of migrant communities. The Institute conducted a most important study of the circumstances of Australia's ethnic aged. The quality of the research in this instance and the recognition of the specific problems of many of our aged settlers of non-English speaking background should be of immense value to the Government in undertaking special programs for the elderly.

AIMA was also responsible for evaluating the way in which the recommendations of the Galbally report were implemented. The Fraser Government, which expressed and demonstrated a compassionate and practical commitment to the migrant community, acted on this evaluation. The result was a major increase in grants-in-aid for migrant welfare and the extension of multicultural television services throughout Australia. AIMA has also been involved in the community education sphere and has produced a package of material around the theme of the migrant experience in Australia. This educational material was developed alongside a six-episode television series and materials for schools. The Australian Institute for Multicultural Affairs has also liaised with education centres, particularly in Victoria, for the display and dissemination of education resource materials on multicultural issues.

Twenty-eight research reports have been published by the Institute, including 12 in the past year. It has also published a regular newsletter and kept a communications flow with individuals and organisations concerned with the problems and needs of migrants in our country. The Institute has been involved in major conferences and has sponsored two such conferences. One was entitled `Promoting Tolerance in a Multicultural Society'. The other conference, on research, was entitled `Ethnicity and Multiculturalism'. The Institute has been an active participant in the conferences of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the National Population Council and has collaborated in a number of projects with Commonwealth and State agencies.

The proposed new Federal strategy on multiculturalism and this Bill to abolish AIMA is brought to us by a Government, a Prime Minister and a Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs who continue to demonstrate their contempt, lack of understanding and care for this special group of our fellow Australians. This Minister has so far distinguished himself by presiding over an increasingly frustrated and delayed immigration program. He has acted as a cultural commissar to determine which artists will be served up on the platter of Australian entertainment and he has attempted to scoop quid pro quo with the media. The abolition of AIMA is also his decision. The Minister's statement of 12 August 1986 suggests that the new strategy on multiculturalism and, consequently, the abolition of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs is the first response to the findings of stage 1 of the Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services headed by Dr James Jupp.

The review Committee did not recommend the abolition of AIMA. It recommends the Institute's retention as an independent research and community education organisation with a role in advising on access and equity within the delivery of government programs and services. The review recommends the establishment of an Office of Ethnic Affairs within the Department in addition to the retention of AIMA. This information has not come to me from the Minister, nor from AIMA but from other sources. The decision to abolish AIMA is suggested to be a budgetary measure. The Government has stated that savings of $1m will be achieved in 1986-87 from the abolition of AIMA with $2m of savings in a full year. However, the Senate Estimates committee indicates that the actual savings in 1986-87 will be $692,000, not the $1m claimed by the Minister.

To replace the Institute the Government will establish an Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs. Nowhere in the Budget is there an indication of the cost of operating this new office. Of even greater significance than the inconsistency of the Minister's statement was the divisive and selective nature of the announcement of the abolition of AIMA and other measures announced ahead of the Budget. It was not a decision announced along with other Budget cuts. It was deliberately announced before the Budget. It was put forward with the Government's proposal to amalgamate the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Special Broadcasting Service. It was a deliberate and selective announcement aimed at the unsuspecting and the unprepared. Is it any wonder that organisations such as the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils feel completely let down on behalf of their communities? The Sydney Morning Herald encapsulated the actions of the Government and the Minister in their inconsistent attitude towards ethnic affairs. I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald:

Two days after the Government abolished the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, merged the Special Broadcasting Service with the ABC, cut back the English as a Second Language Program by almost half, ended the Multicultural Education Program, and closed down regional departmental offices, he (the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs) said: `The Government is reinforcing its commitment to multicultural principles by bringing them to the forefront of decision making.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a marvellous way to reinforce it.

—Yes, exactly. This is not the first time that the Government has decided to attack the AIMA. The Government received the report of the committee of review of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs set up by the then Minister, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), in November 1983. That review recommended the abolition of AIMA and the replacement with another statutory and independent authority. That review was soundly criticised as a-I quote Frank Galbally-`divisive, corrosive and entirely political document'. Further review and discussion throughout 1984 led to the introduction of amendments to the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act in February 1985. At that time, the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am anxious that the Institute should have a much more prominent public profile and increased role in the education of all our people in the benefits of our multicultural society.
He continued:

The new Council is made up of members who have special relationships with communities and interests with which they are linked, and is poised to create an institution which will be greatly valued by all Australians.

Despite the Minister's acknowledgment of the important role of the Council, the Minister chose not to consult with it on the decision to abolish the Institute. All he offered were platitudes on its role in having developed the profile of the Institute and having introduced many initiatives. In no way has the Minister or the Prime Minister substantiated, as yet, how AIMA has failed to meet the objectives which this Government imposed on the Institute. In 1985, amendments were introduced to the Institute's Act which effectively increased its statutory functions and at the same time reduced its budget by nearly 30 per cent. The amendments charged the Institute to respond to the Government's wishes for it to increase its public profile and its community education activities. Yet the Minister, having changed the charter for providing policy information to that of a public relations educational authority, now, in abandoning AIMA, asserts that it has failed to give adequate policy advice. In the debate in this House in 1985 on the AIMA amendments, the Minister made some significant statements of absolute and unequivocal support for the Institute. He said:

I want to say, firstly, how happy I am to be the Minister in charge of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. I am very hopeful that under my stewardship and, of course, the stewardship of this Government, which will continue for the next 10 or 15 years, we will be able to make a great contribution in this land of many cultures through the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs.
That was said barely 12 months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Minister now?

—Where is the Minister now? The Minister said last night when it was indicated that the debate would be on that he would not be here. The Minister also made it clear that a government department and bureaucracy was not the appropriate mechanism for achieving the objectives of independence and the development of strategies and values of multicultural programs. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I really hope that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs will do just that job, (shout multiculturalism from the roof tops), not in an abrasive way but in a quiet, persuasive way. I do not believe it is the job of Government departments or even of us in this Parliament to do it too often. I think it is much better that it should be done by a body such as AIMA.

So much for the Minister, this Government and what they believe in. Now the Minister wants to do the shouting, using the words prepared for him by this new unit to be established within his Department. The Council of the Institute and its Chairman, Archbishop David Penman, have advised the Government of their concern about the decision to abolish AIMA in favour of establishing a new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs with no statutory independence or autonomy. The independent status of the Institute was one of the fundamental principles of its establishment in 1979 by the coalition Government, and as recommended by the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants. Such a view has been confirmed by the present Government's own review.

In his second reading speech, the Minister also alluded to the abolition of AIMA as a result of `a further re-evaluation'. We want to know exactly what that evaluation is. To date, no one has any idea as to what process of re-evaluation of the Institute has been undertaken. The Minister has not declared it; the Government has not produced it; and it certainly was not done in those terms by Dr Jupp, who recommended its retention. I call on the Minister to table this re-evaluation and have his decision accountable to public scrutiny. The migrant communities and the Council of AIMA should, at the very least, be accorded some of the privileges which have been extended to the trade union movement by being included with the consultative process. It would seem that unless one is a Crean, a Kelty or a Halfpenny, there is no real access to or equity in this Government's decision-making process.

The Government has also attempted to remove the bipartisanship which has existed in so many of the policies governing the development of ethnic affairs. The Australian Labor Party had always supported the coalition Government's initiatives that an independent body, reporting to Parliament, would provide a valuable, sensible and constructive mechanism for engaging in research on multicultural and ethnic issues, Yet the Government has decided to replace an independent body with a bureaucratic body, accountable to and reporting to only the Minister. What is the reason for this? The Minister gave his answer in his second reading speech, when he said:
. . . in our view, the continuing life of AIMA is no longer the most effective means of achieving our objectives.

Is this Government afraid of independent research and reports that may be critical of its actions or its inactions? It is clear that this Minister has the desire to manage that which people should know. He seems to have a desire to bring independent research and evaluation under his direct control. However, it would be grossly unfair to place the entire blame for the betrayal and deceit at the feet of the Minister. Much of the blame belongs fairly and squarely with the Prime Minister. On 22 August, the Prime Minister gave an answer to a dorothy dix question from the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), the Chairman of the Government's Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Committee, on the Government's commitment to multicultural values. He said:
The Government, through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and, on this occasion, through me, commits itself unequivocally to enhancing multicultural values.

How do he and his Government do this? They abolish AIMA; they merge the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service; they abolish multicultural education programs; they slash the English as a second language program; and they close six regional offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. So much for the Prime Minister's commitment. His Government gives a 12.1 per cent increase in grant-in-aid to migrant community groups, yet he gives the trade unions a 23.1 per cent increase. Then he cuts the number of assisted passages for refugees by 3,000 places.
The Prime Minister went on in that answer to speak about people from non-English speaking backgrounds. He said:

They have to make a language adjustment when they come to this country. They need advice from social and welfare workers to assist them in making adjustments and this Labor Government has improved all these programs which especially help people of non-English speaking backgrounds individually at the grass roots.

With this in mind, his Government cuts 44.7 per cent from the English as a second language program. With this in mind, the adult migrant education program, although increased by 4.3 per cent in money terms, was cut by 3 per cent in real terms. In addition, his Government has increased the level of citizenship and immigration fees revenue by 75 per cent. He has given migrants the opportunity to be hit first and hit hardest in the firing line of the Budget cuts. This Government has denied equal opportunities to migrants in producing an ad hoc and second-hand ethnic affairs program.

What the Prime Minister offers will have disastrous implications for those people and their families seeking to make a secure economic base for their future and on the capacity of community groups to participate in equitable access to services. One of the most incredible, illogical statements made by the Prime Minister, which appeared in the same answer, was this:

. . . although the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in Melbourne is being phased out, a new office of multicultural and ethnic affairs is being created within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Of course, some people would have considered it nice to have both, but every sector had to make sacrifices. Of the two bodies, the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs will be much more effective, not just cost effective, in promoting multicultural value. The Office will be located in Canberra.

No matter what criticisms have been made of AIMA for its academically biased research, no matter what criticisms have been made of AIMA for its remoteness from ethnic communities, its location in Melbourne, where such a significant number of non-English speaking people live, makes it much closer to the community than the establishment of a new office located in Canberra. For the Prime Minister to suggest that the bureaucracy of the national capital is the closest point to the people is both an absurd and a ludicrous notion typical of the extent to which this Government has isolated and deluded itself. It has lost touch with the electorate and with the community. Does the Prime Minister seriously believe that by wrapping research in red tape it will identify with migrants? Did the honourable member for Calwell, when he posed his question in the hope that the Government might extract itself from the loud protests of disappointment, expect that he would have received such an inane and convoluted answer? I bet he did not.

I am aware that the Director of AIMA, Dr Peter Sheldrake, has been offered a temporary post to head the new Office for six months. The rest of the staff of the Institute will lose their jobs. The Government is very good at intervening with private industry when retrenchments become inevitable, but it certainly shows no consideration for its own employees and their placement. Surely something can be done to assist some very competent and dedicated staff in finding jobs. Support by the Government in gaining consideration for appointments to universities, colleges and other institutions would be good employer practice-something we hear about every day in this place from Government members. Let us see a little of their rhetoric put into action.

The Chairman of the Institute, Archbishop David Penman, said the decision was `a backward step in the Government's commitment to multiculturalism'. One of the most serious issues raised by Dr Penman was the lack of consultation by the Government and the Minister on this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not consult anyone.
—They did not consult a single person, yet they claim they have reviewed it. I thank the honourable member. I quote from the Melbourne Age of 13 August 1986 regarding Dr Penman's claims:

SPEECH.PARA: He claimed that the Government had not consulted with the institute about the decision and that an office within the Minister's department would lack the independence of a statutory authority.
Mr Hurford said the new office would be more independent than a normal departmental division and would be headed by a more senior public servant.
I do not know how one makes it more independent. That is just impossible in our system. It must be a statutory body and separate, or it must be part of the Department.

The ethnic communities are most concerned that the Government's proposals for the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs will not ensure independence. For example, the Chairman of the Ethnic Community Council of Victoria, Mr Tony Bonnici, who is well known to members of the House, is reported as having stated that the Minister did not favour having a body like the Institute and was trying to bring it under his control. Ms Frances Milne, of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils, was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 August as having said:

. . . it was essential that the office be independent of the department, that it receive adequate resources for community education and research, and that the conduct and results of that research be readily available to the public.

Comments such as those from community leaders have led to speculation that the Prime Minister will take significant responsibilities away from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-except for administration. Nothing could be a greater indictment of the abject failure of the Government in immigration and ethnic affairs than for the Prime Minister to be forced to take over from the Minister. A couple of days ago the Melbourne Sun reported:
He-
the Prime Minister-
is believed to be considering taking charge of the proposed new Office of Multicultural and Ethic Affairs, due to begin operation at the beginning of next year.
In order to bail his Minister out of yet another mess, the Prime Minister, it seems, will have to take charge of the new operation.

The philosophy of the coalition parties has always been dedication to political liberty, the freedom and dignity of the individual, individual choice, economic freedom, the expansion of wealth through private enterprise, the use of this wealth to assist the disadvantaged, the decentralisation of political power and a country in which family life is seen as fundamental to the well-being of society.

In government we have been parties of high immigration. Having paralleled and complemented Australia's growth and development, we have always believed that the immigration mix which balances economic advantage and the relief of hardship or persecution has served the dual objectives of self-interest and compassion. One of the notable features of our administrations in relation to immigration and ethnic affairs has been the lack of fear of the migrant and the ready recognition of the outstanding contribution migrants have made to our nation.

Our opponents' concern with immigration numbers and the threat to jobs has been enshrined in the prices and incomes accord. The significance of different philosophical outlooks between the parties is easily demonstrated when the Liberal commitment to the individual is contrasted with the socialist categorisation of individuals as class groups. We do not have any of the difficulties with different nationalities, including perceived threats to class or interest groups of a large, balanced immigration program which our opponents seem to have. Nor have we shied away from providing innovative programs to assist new arrivals in settlement or in their participation with other Australians.

The Opposition, unlike the Government, believes in a responsible, compassionate and understanding approach to ethnic affairs. We believe in consultation. We believe that the Government could not have handled this matter in a more insensitive manner. Australians share common goals of liberty, equality of opportunity and commitment to the family which are able to go above and beyond origin and background.

The social idea of multiculturalism was developed and enhanced by coalition governments to create acceptance, respect and understanding of individuals from differing backgrounds. People from different backgrounds should have equality of opportunity. This equality is able to be achieved only if people of different backgrounds can participate in Australian society on an equal basis.

We must recognise the private culture and traditions of individuals. The objective surely is a cohesive society and one which forges unity from diversity. An individual is entitled to express his own identity. At the same time there must also be an affirmation that our society does share national goals and values. People in Australia should be citizens and residents who are able to live in an environment which allows everyone to achieve his own individual potential; which allows equality of opportunity to participate in a competitive society and in local community, State and national affairs; and which encourages people to share the commitment, the responsibility and the benefits of our nation. We in the Opposition are astounded by the Government's inept handling of a wide range of Budget and Budget related decisions. On behalf of the Opposition, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(1) is of the opinion that the Government's decision to abolish the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs:
(a) will break yet another promise to the Australian community;
(b) will establish a bureaucratically controlled research office;
(c) has ignored the government's own Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services;
(d) does not achieve savings of the magnitude announced by the Government;
(e) signals a downgrading of many important programs; and
(f) was instigated without any consultation or consideration for those who would be affected, and

(2) further calls on the Government to explain how it intends to obtain data of the kind and quality provided by the Institute in order that governments, generally, might make appropriate decisions regarding our society'.

Both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and I have begun a series of extensive consultations with leaders of many ethnic community groups. The actions of neither the Prime Minister nor his Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs indicate the slightest glimmer of understanding of the seriousness of their decisions.

We in the Opposition do not agree with many of the Budget decisions, but it is not our Budget. Any government which selects children's milk and orange juice to increase its taxes-any government which selects one section of the community to bear a disproportionate share of pain-is incompetent. Even to the most bigoted Labor Party supporter, the huge list of cuts to migrant and multicultural services does not conform to the Government's slogan of `restraint with equity'.

The Opposition gives a binding undertaking that upon coming to office, when research and surveys are required, we will commission them based upon independent advice. Research and surveys exclusively commissioned by the Department are no substitute for independently and objectively commissioner projects. The closed shop commissioning of research which the Government is now about to deliver, flies in the face of bipartisan attitudes, which have existed in this country for ten years. Independent experts of high calibre have contributed to the depth and direction of our society through the establishment of AIMA.

I conclude by saying that I consider that the self-delusion of this Government must be assigned by our friends in the migrant community to the waste bin of politics and substituted by practical, thoughtful and deliverable policies. In order that this may be achieved there must be a commitment to the concepts of social cohesion, cultural identity and equality of opportunity and access. The Government has rejected these concepts. We reaffirm them and nobody should settle for less.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes. I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just heard that speech by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) expanding on some new found interest in ethnic affairs that his Party is now pronouncing. I ask the honourable member where he was in the 1950s and 1960s when migrants were brought out and the conservatives considered them as factory fodder. They still consider them as factory fodder. I saw the honourable member laughing with glee and lapping up every word of his colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) praising Blainey. This is his record. No one in the migrant community will be misled--
—Madam Speaker, I find those comments completely repulsive and I wish to have them withdrawn.
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham will resume his seat. The honourable member for Mitchell has a point of order.
—Yes, Madam Speaker. There was an implication of a previous debate there that I cannot accept and I would like those remarks withdrawn.
—I am sorry, I did not hear the remarks as I was reading my papers.

—My remarks were, and I repeat them, that I have seen the honourable member sitting over there in his seat while the debate about the Blainey affair was going on, lapping up every word with glee. I am not withdrawing that. That is my observation and the expressions are parliamentary. If he has got a personal explanation to make he can make it later.
—Madam Speaker, I find those remarks offensive and I want them withdrawn.
—There is nothing unparliamentary in the remarks the honourable member is making.

—The rules that were enunciated yesterday by the Deputy Speaker here in a very intensive debate over a period of time were that if an honourable member finds remarks offensive they are to be withdrawn. The other rule was that if he, the Deputy Speaker, found them offensive-

—Order! That is not the standing order at all, and if that was put forward yesterday it is incorrect. The standing order states that the Speaker is given the right to decide whether the comments are unparliamentary or not. They are not unparliamentary and I call the honourable member for Hotham.
—Madam Speaker, I found the whole speech of the honourable member offensive to me and to the migrant community. I found it offensive--
—I suggest to the honourable member for Hotham that he get on with his speech.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I am rising in this debate to support the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill with some regret. The effect of this Bill before the House will be to abolish the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Let me say at the outset that I support the Bill as, under the circumstances of requested cost cutting, I agree that it would be less damaging to abolish AIMA than to cut direct services to the ethnic community, such as the on-arrival English language program or grants-in-aid. If faced with this dilemma I would have done exactly the same as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has been forced to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I also welcome the decision to set up an Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs which will be staffed and funded by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. That will bring the function of AIMA, or what will remain of it, under the direct control of the Department, a long-standing wish of its head, Mr McKinnon. However, that is purely coincidence. It is bureaucrats' luck when a cost-cutting exercise such as the abolition of AIMA removes some thorns from their sides. It has been long known that the Institute's very existence outside the bureaucratic control of the Department was a source of irritation to some people, to say the least.

The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs was established under Commonwealth legislation in 1979, following a recommendation of the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants. In subsequent years the Institute undertook and compiled a number of projects and studies such as the report entitled `Ageing in a Multicultural Society' and `Migrants in the Labour Force', to mention only two.

In the six years of its operation the Institute's achievements have been considerable. It undertook a wide activity in research and community education. As a result of its work on the review of migrant and multicultural education, funding of ethnic schools was introduced. Following the evaluation of post-arrival programs and services a major increase of grants-in-aid to migrant welfare service flowed as well as the extension of the transmission of multicultural television broadcasting throughout Australia.

Altogether some 28 research reports have been published, 12 in the past 16 months. A review of migrant services in the Springvale region in my electorate is just about completed. I have read the draft report and have nothing but praise for its authors-Josef Petyanski and Richard Chauvel. I wish to go on record as praising these two hard working members of the Institute for their excellent research. Similarly, I would like to acknowledge the work of the rest of the staff of AIMA who, during the years of the Institute's existence, contributed so much to the welfare of the ethnic communities in Australia and to Australia's multicultural development.

In 1983 the Institute was reviewed and the Government amended the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act in 1985. Since then AIMA has functioned in its revised form. To understand the work of the Institute let us look at its objectives as defined in the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act. According to the Act, the objects of the establishment of AIMA include; the Development in the Australian community of an awareness of the existence and contribution of various cultures; the promotion of mutual respect, self-esteem and a cohesive Australian society by encouraging sharing and cultural diversity, and the promotion of equality of access and equality of opportunity and other measures which contribute towards the realisation of a just and equitable society in Australia. The Act also outlines the functions of the Institute. Briefly, these include providing on-going advice to the Commonwealth Government, conducting and promoting community education, research, collecting and disseminating relevant information and providing reports to the Minister and the general public.

Given the broad and wide-ranging scope of the objectives and functions of AIMA one can only lament the abolition of the body which was established to achieve these valuable goals. One would need an incredible imagination to believe that a desk, or even as the Minister puts it, an office in his Department, can fulfil these objectives. I remind the Minister that his Department is much more suited to hunting down prohibited non-citizens and deporting them than to building bridges between communities and assisting the multicultural integration of Australians from various backgrounds. It is far too shortsighted to place our future as a multicultural nation into the hands of department bureaucrats whose main concern is to apply rigidly the rules rather than to promote human sensitivity and understanding.

However, as I said at the outset, I accept that economic necessities brought about the decisions which we face today. I reject the accusations of the Opposition in this place and that of some members of the ethnic elite outside it that the Australian Labor Party has abandoned the path of multicultural development. One fashionable criminal lawyer has even accused us of committing multicultural murder. We should be more bipartisan and forget about political point-scoring. Immigration and the successful settlement of migrants in our community is far too important for us to play politics with it. After all, immigration and ethnic affairs are not just a process of adding numbers to our population; they are about human beings, men, women and children, whose successful settlement and happiness will contribute to our development as a nation.

I call on the migrant communities not to listen to those short-sighted, self-appointed, elitist leaders who want to manipulate them by encouraging anti-ALP sentiments. Let us remember that we migrants owe a debt of gratitude to the ALP, whose Minister, the late Hon. Arthur Calwell, engineered Australia's post-war mass immigration program. Those opposite, the members of the Liberal and National parties, who are now shedding crocodile tears over AIMA always considered and still consider migrants as factory fodder. During their era of government in the 1950s and 1960s there were no services for the hundreds of thousands of new arrivals into this country. All they did was to set up camps, like cattle yards, to herd migrants together and direct them into factories to turn the wheels of industry. Never once did they stop to consider that we have human needs too, that our children need extra English tuition, that our history and culture should be recognised. `Assimilate, or stay a second class citizen' was their motto. Now Opposition members have the hide to come in here to lecture us on multiculturalism. They feign moral indignation, forgetting that they did nothing for the ethnic communities for two decades during their rule in the 1950s and 1960s. It was the Whitlam Labor Government which first introduced services for migrants. It was, and still is, the Labor Party which recognises the human needs of migrants.

The Opposition now wants to make political capital from the fact that certain measures in our Budget fall more heavily on the overseas-born than on the rest of the community. Migrants should not be misled by the crocodile tears of the Opposition. It was the conservative forces which demanded the reduction of government outlays. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has proudly announced the conservative ideology of the need to further curtail government expenditure, which will mean further cuts in services, including services to ethnic communities. While they do not want to disclose where those cuts would be made, I have no doubt that they would abolish many existing services for migrants, such as the grant-in-aid, welfare services, interpreter services and assistance to ethnic schools.

As I said, certain measures undertaken in this Budget fall more heavily on the ethnic community rather than on the general community. I think that we all acknowledge that difficult economic conditions, such as those facing us now, demand sacrifices from all sectors of society, and the migrant communities are no exception, nor would they wish to be. However, it is nonetheless unfortunate that three otherwise unrelated measures in three different portfolios, such as the abolition of AIMA, the merger of the Special Broadcasting Service with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and the cut in funding for the teaching of English as a second language, occurred simultaneously. To avoid the repetition of this occurrence in future Budgets, it is imperative to ensure that careful consideration is given to the consequences of Cabinet decisions for youth, women and, in this case, ethnic communities.

One way in which effective government decisions can be monitored is to separate immigration from ethnic affairs and place the latter under the jurisdiction of the Prime Minister, as is presently the case with the Office of the Status of Women and the Office of Youth Affairs. There are many benefits to be gained by locating the responsibility for ethnic affairs, or, as I would prefer to call it, multicultural affairs, in the Prime Minister's office. Such a development would give added emphasis to the importance which we as a Government attach to the maintenance of our good record of complementing large immigration intakes with successful post-arrival and settlement programs. It would also assist the development of more responsive and sensitive ethnic or multicultural relations between government and ethnic communities and ethnic communities and the wider community.

In my opinion, ethnic or multicultural affairs should have been separated from Immigration and placed under the responsibility and guidance of the Prime Minister a long time ago. Most of us refer to the Immigration Department and tend to forget that it also has a mandate to promote and foster ethnic and multicultural affairs. This is a perception which reflects practice. The Department of Immigration, not of ethnic affairs, has characterised the role played by the Department through the post-war period. During this period the Department has been initiating, administering and enforcing immigration policy. While undertaking these tasks, the part of the portfolio which represents the cultural and human development role has been neglected. It has become increasingly apparent that enforcing rules on the one hand is not compatible with the development of the kind of sensitivity which is fundamental to the nurturing of ethnic or multicultural relations on the other.

One analogy which immediately comes to mind is that of placing the Australian Federal Police in charge of the Department of Social Security. The rationale for placing and then maintaining ethnic or multicultural affairs within the same portfolio which has the responsibility of policing and enforcing immigration laws is equally questionable. The absence of an adequate policy or service response to the issues which are embraced under the umbrella of ethnic or multicultural affairs has been apparent for some time. The Minister's decision and the Bill before us are consequences of the recommendations contained in the draft report of the first stage of the Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services.

In looking at ways in which to extend and strengthen the scope of the multicultural perspective, Dr Jupp considered various strategies and structures to replace AIMA. One of these included the establishment of an office like the Office of Youth Affairs in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The proposal to establish such an agency has considerable advantages, including providing it with `Considerable influence (while remaining) organisationally independent from those responsible for services which it could have to monitor', namely the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In spite of the recognition of a likely conflict of interest, nonetheless Dr Jupp concluded that the new organisation should be placed under the responsibility of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I am afraid that my brief analysis of the draft report of the first stage of the review indicates that Dr Jupp yielded to the same kind of pressure to which the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs will also succumb-that is, by virtue of its location within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and its direct responsibility to the Minister it has an inherent vested interest which militates against the achievement of its objective of promoting the multicultural perspective throughout the decision-making process of our society.

The failure to achieve the kind of just and equitable society outlined in the objects of AIMA should not be placed entirely at the door of the Institute. As I said earlier, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, by neglecting its role of ethnic or multicultural affairs, bears much of the responsibility for the outcome. Multiculturalism can be successfully nurtured and developed in this country only by taking the responsibility for ethnic or multicultural affairs away from immigration bureaucrats and placing it in the care of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It is imperative that we do not underestimate the importance of this issue. We should keep in mind that the adverse economic conditions encourage the Blaineys and the public expression of racist and discriminating attitudes and sentiments. Let us not forget either that it was the Opposition which sought to obtain political capital by supporting Blainey's racist outbursts. It was the Prime Minister who had come into this chamber to tell the Opposition that we, a Labor Government, will never allow or promote the practice of discrimination against individuals on the basis of culture ethnicity or race. While I may not agree with my leader on every issue, let me say loudly and clearly that so long as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) is the Prime Minister of this country, the Blaineys of this world will not have their way. It is no wonder that I would like to see ethnic or multicultural affairs placed under the Prime Minister's jurisdiction and responsibility. I believe that in this way the ethnic communities will have their needs met and receive the attention which they rightly deserve.

Finally, let me reiterate that the Minister's dilemma in attempting to reduce expenditure in these difficult economic circumstances was considerable. The choice of where to apply cuts is unenviable and difficult. By recognising that the decision was not an easy one, I congratulate the Minister for his success in maintaining direct services to ethnic communities and securing increased funding for the adult migrant educational program and the grants-in-aid scheme. Once again I extend my congratulations to the members of the staff of AIMA for their contribution to the promotion and greater understanding of ethnic issues in our society. I hope that their talents will continue to be placed in the service of achieving a genuine multicultural society in Australia. It is with some regret that I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst not for one minute wanting to indicate that I hold the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and his views on the subject of migrants and multiculturalism in anything other than high esteem, because I believe that he is genuine on that subject, I find some difficulty in responding to what was a rather schizophrenic speech on the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill. On the one hand, the honourable member pointed out the unique job that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs has done. His words were that it will take `an incredible imagination', to imagine the Department doing the job, as is the Government's intention. However, at the same time he supported the Government. I point out to the honourable member that there is a difference between reducing something and annihilating it. There is pressure on the Government to pull its head in fiscally. There is pressure on the Government to be more responsible. However, I would not agree that this is a responsible way to approach the matter. If one wants to prune a tree one does not start immediately above ground level. This measure is not a reduction; it is an elimination.

SPEECH.PARA: The fine words about AIMA we have heard today from both sides in this debate are a eulogy for AIMA. That is what this debate is. I would be very curious to know who the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) is going to invite to the wake. Certainly, I suspect that it will not be the Government speakers in this debate. It will probably be some departmental people. However, at no stage can the Minister be congratulated for what he has done in this portfolio and specifically in this area. I take issue with the honourable member for Hotham and his assertion that the Opposition has a new-found interest in the subject of multiculturalism. It was the Liberal and National parties in government which established AIMA, wrote its charter, saw its need and set it up. It is they who should get full credit for the considerable fruits-a number of which the honourable member for Hotham referred to in his speech-that have flowed from it. These benefits are not just for migrants but for the whole Australian community.

This issue is very serious. One would have thought, given the very significant and special role that AIMA has played in the last seven years, that one would have got something a little better than the Minister's second reading speech. I diverge for a minute to note that the Minister is not here. The shadow Minister indicated in his speech that the Minister had said to him that he could not be present last night when the debate should have taken place had we not run out of time. I accept that there are occasions when Ministers cannot be here but I would like this point conveyed to the Minister. On previous occasions when we have debated citizenship and immigration Bills the Minister has also been absent. I have yet to see him be present for a debate on legislation relating to immigration. I accept that there may be pressures on his time. However, I would like those who are listening to the debate on his behalf-if he is not listening in his office at the moment-to convey to him the following message before he replies to this second reading debate. In the debate on citizenship several months ago, the Minister was almost criminally misbriefed by those who he said had briefed him. He admitted that he had not been able to listen to the debate but he said that others had listened on his behalf and had briefed him. It was very apparent in his reply to the second reading debate, and in his contributions in the Committee stage, that he had not been truthfully briefed because he referred to certain issues which had been discussed constantly throughout the debate in a way which clearly showed that he thought he was introducing something new into the debate, something to which he thought people were oblivious. So I ask those listening on his behalf to make sure that this time he is told what the substance of the debate is so that for once we can get a second reading reply from the Minister that is relevant to the points the Opposition has raised and that, apparently, Government members are also raising in objection to this decision.

One has to ask what are the Government's objectives in multiculturalism when it takes such a dramatic step as abolishing this unique statutory authority. As I said a minute ago, the Minister's speech is remarkable for its brevity. It is insultingly brief. He makes a glancing reference to the achievements of AIMA but any sense of justification of why this is to happen is simply not present. I will quote some parts of the speech, which was a matter of only some half a dozen paragraphs. He said:
We believe that enormous improvements were made to AIMA over the ensuing year--
that is, following amendments last year-
but not sufficient to avoid a further re-evaluation.

The Review of Migrant Multicultural Programs and Services . . . which has recently reported, has convinced us of the need for a range of approaches that will more effectively ensure that multicultural principles are accepted.

The report of the review has been in the Minister's hands for some little time. It has not yet been tabled in Parliament. The implication of the Minister's speech is that the report recommends the abolition of AIMA. We have reason to doubt that that is what the report recommends. The Minister does not say it but he implies it. When that report is tabled it had better have some strong justification for the abolition of AIMA or the Minister stands condemned as duplicitous in his approach to this subject. I would not have expected that a report which recommends ranges of approaches would suggest that an independent body in this area should be shoved into the Department. That does not seem to do much for a range of approaches. The other part of the Minister's speech I refer to is the solution he proposes and the justification for it that he gives. He says:
Part of our strategy involves the setting up of an Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs to be staffed and funded within my portfolio . . .

We are given no details about the Office. We are not told about the level of funds. We are not told which staff are to be used. Will they be proven, excellent, research staff from AIMA or will they not? What is the establishment? What is the saving, if a pruning and saving is the reason this measure is justified? The Minister said at the end of his speech:
The Institute will therefore be wound down and abolished before the end of this year at a saving of $1m during 1986-87 and $2m in a full year.
The Minister has some explaining to do to this House about that assertion. The explanatory memorandum to this abolishing Bill under the heading `Financial Impact' states:
It is expected that savings of $1m in the financial year 1986-87, and some $2m in subsequent years, will occur as a result of the abolition of the Institute.

We will need a very good explanation of how this function will be carried out within the Department at less cost-indeed zero cost-compared with now. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87, under the heading `Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs', shows that for the entire year 1985-86 AIMA's expenditure and appropriation was less than $2m; in fact, it was $1,964,000. The Bill shows the appropriation this year is $1,272,000. Some figures are missing from the Minister's speech and from the explanatory memorandum. My arithmetic tells me that the anticipated saving, according to the Appropriation Bill, is less than $700,000. By wiping AIMA out, there will certainly be no $2m appropriation in future. If the function is to be undertaken in the Department, there will be a cost to the Department. There will be an increase in its costs. One would expect the cost to be at least as high or nearly as high. There are few economies of scale in the bureaucracy. By merging functions, one cannot expect always to save. The Minister must explain whether his second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum, also authorised by him, reflect the truth? Are we saving $2m in a full financial year, or is there simply a transfer of cost? The Minister's speech was insulting in its brevity. I reiterate that the report of the Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services should have been tabled before the debate took place. It is ironic that the March 1986 issue of Mosaic, an information newsletter from AIMA, had this to say about the review:

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has established a review of migrant and multicultural programs and services, aimed at ensuring that migrants and their families will be able to participate fully in Australia society'. This implements an earlier Government decision accepting a recommendation made by the Institute in its Evaluation of post-arrival programs and services.

I doubt whether the Government would have had the evaluation to proceed on had it not been for the existence of AIMA. I echo the views of the honourable member for Hotham that I doubt that we will get anything like the objective output of data and reports on the subject of the settlement of non-Australian born citizens in future that we have had in the past. The 1984-85 annual report of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs says this about its own objectives:
The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs is an independent statutory authority established by an Act of Parliament in 1979. It reports to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
The objects of the Institute include:
Developing an awareness of the diverse cultures in Australia and an appreciation of their contributions
Promoting tolerance and understanding and a cohesive Australian society
Promoting a society which is just and equitable, in that it accepts people irrespective of their background and affords them the opportunity to achieve their own potential.
The Act provides that these objects are achieved through:
Providing advice to Government
Undertaking community education and research activities, and disseminating information
Liaising widely with, and promoting co-ordination between, government and community agencies
Promoting the right of ethnic organisations to make representations-
it will be very interesting to see how the Department does that-
encouraging the conservation of cultural materials.

I do not believe that those functions will be met in future by any office in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I hasten to say that I am not bucketing the Department. I have had extensive experience of it in my time as a member of parliament, especially regarding representations on behalf of people wanting to migrate here. I have found, in my dealings with it, that it is of a high standard. Its officers seem to be well motivated in the work they do. However, as the honourable member for Hotham pointed out, they have a function and a role that has nothing to do with what the Institute of Multicultural Affairs was all about. I do not believe that it would be possible for a Public Service department to meet those objectives. I repeat: How are departmental officers going to advise individuals or groups on how to make representations which inevitably will challenge the Department, and probably also the Minister?

The publications that have followed the very high standard of research that the Institute has carried out have covered very profound and important subjects, such as: `Ageing in a multicultural society'; `Atlas of youth unemployment, 1981'; `Australia's people: a resource collection of curriculum materials'; `Differences in the earnings of Australian and overseas born youth: an economic analysis'; `The disabled migrant: an annotated bibliography'; `The ethnic aged: an annotated bibliography and selected statistics'; `Evaluation of post-arrival programs and services'; `Migrant and refugee youth and the Australian labour force: an annotated bibliography'; `Papers on the ethnic aged'; and `A profile of the Italian community in Australia', which was published with Comitato Assistenza Italiano. Will the Department be in a position to undertake research and publications in conjunction with organisations such as Co.As.It? I doubt it.

Other publications are: `Reducing the risk: unemployed migrant youth and labour market programs', an overview report; and `Review of multicultural and migrant education'. That research covers a wide range of subjects and people in our community. It was excellent research. I do not believe that it will be done in future. There is only one way I accept that it would be possible for that sort of activity to be carried out with a government department involved and that would be for some independent body to determine what the research subjects were to be. If the Minister is to tell the unit what it is to research and if the Department is to decide what it is to research, one can bet one's bottom dollar it will not be ferreting out those sensitive and politically dangerous areas that must be addressed, and have been addressed in a responsible way by AIMA.

How very ironic it is that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who has presided over a convulsion in migrant services through the Budget should at the same time grandstand about what he has achieved. I refer to some of the Minister's comments last year in debate in this chamber on an amending Bill relating to AIMA. He said:

I want to say, firstly, how happy I am to be the Minister in charge of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. I am very hopeful that under my stewardship . . . we will be able to make a great contribution in this land of many cultures through the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs.
The Minister was either talking through his hat, speaking with forked tongue or he is a failure. He is a failure if judged by the fact that we are even debating this Bill today. He continued:
The next point I make is that we need a body of this nature to achieve certain objectives. I would like briefly to go through them-
he was not too brief, by the way-

In regard to multicultural issues, there is the community appreciation of and adaption to Australia's cultural diversity that I have talked about. But there is also the need for a respect for the rights of migrants to remain free, to retain and express their ethnic identity, subject, of course, to the provisions of Australian law and without sacrificing their right of equal access to all community resources and government programs. There is the need for the development and maintenance of Australia as a society in which all groups have the same rights, responsibilities and opportunities and share a common identity as Australians. When it comes to community relations issues, there is the need for maintenance of a social environment which accepts racial and cultural diversity and the contribution of the migration program to Australia's national development. I do not want to forget, too, encouragement for the integration of immigrants and their dependants into Australian society and the elimination of racism, discrimination and prejudice against racial and ethnic minorities in Australia.

The Opposition says `Hear, hear' to all those sentiments. They are the sentiments that we expressed in government, and, as one of the major means of achieving them, we established the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Just last year, the Minister was pointing out the central and important role of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs in achieving those laudable objectives. Today, we stand here to see the burial of this organisation, with only a scant reference by the Minister on this occasion to what it has achieved. I hope that the reference is scant because he is ashamed of this decision by the Government and ashamed of his inability to persuade the Cabinet and his Prime Minister of just how important a function in the whole social fabric this organisation was playing.

I will wholeheartedly support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and I say that the Government's sincerity on multiculturalism stands condemned by its actions here today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and many other honourable members here take an interest in multiculturalism. Listening to the speeches of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan)-I know that the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) will speak later-one might have thought that their views were the views of the Opposition. The fact is that they are not the views of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard); they are not the views of the dominant extreme conservatives in the Opposition. The Opposition puts up spokespersons to talk about defending multiculturalism, yet the Leader of the Opposition is not prepared to say anything or commit himself to any policy in defence of multiculturalism. The amendment moved by the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell, says `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading', and yet goes on to attack the Government. If it is the view of the Leader of the Opposition that AIMA should not be abolished, why is the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill not being opposed by Opposition members? Why do they want to have it both ways? On the one hand, they get up and give us pious talk and, on the other hand, they go along with the line of the Leader of the Opposition, which is to cut government services everywhere.
—You will be able to vote for the amendment, then.
—The Leader of the Opposition has put pressures--
—Vote for the amendment, then, Andrew.

—The honourable member had his go. Now I will have my go. The Leader of the Opposition has stopped the mouth of the shadow Minister. The shadow Minister cannot go around saying that he opposes these policies, because it would totally expose the hypocrisy of their position. The conservative forces in this country have been calling for more and more cuts in government services and for more and more reductions in the public sector. Yet we hear lengthy speeches from the honourable member for Moncrieff and the honourable member for Mitchell about how wonderful AIMA is. One can make speeches supporting every sector of the Public Service; but one cannot do that and then, as the Opposition has been doing, attack the Public Service repeatedly and call for more and more cuts in the Public Service and in the fiscal process. What we have here is hypocrisy, and that is why they have not opposed the Bill but have simply moved some mealy-mouthed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us make it perfectly clear that the Leader of the Opposition is not a friend of multiculturalism; nor are the key people around him. The fact that he can produce a few honourable members here-I respect their views-to make some comments on multiculturalism in no way means that the Opposition has changed its views about multiculturalism and ethnic affairs. It has been opposed to it, and it continues to be opposed to it. I say to the honourable member for Mitchell that, rather than coming into this House and giving us pious speeches, he should go back to the shadow Ministry and get some real motions and real policies on multiculturalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —You failed, with the Government.

—That is what he should be doing. The honourable member says that I have failed. I will come back to that in a minute. I do not come into this House and pretend that everything is rosy in this area or put a pious and hypocritical view, as the honourable member has. The fact is that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) was told that he had to cut $4m from his budget. That was the overall economic strategy, which was determined on the basis of attacks from the New Right and the business sector, which were pressuring the Government. They are the very people whom the Opposition supports. If the honourable member for Mitchell were put into that position, what would he have done? Would he have cut the grant-in-aid welfare program? Would he have cut the adult migrant education program? What would he have cut? That is the issue. Of course, this is the luxury of opposition. The luxury of opposition is that honourable members can talk about rejecting this cut, that cut and the other cut without specifying where they would cut. Yet at the same time they are trying to tell us that they would make much more substantial cuts than those we have made.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was faced with that position, and to suggest that he took pleasure in making this difficult decision is an outrage. Of course, he did not. Who would? This was a difficult decision, but it was taken within the context of the overall Budget. As I say, if the honourable member were the Minister faced with that difficult decision, what responsible alternative would he have suggested? Would he have reduced welfare to the ethnic communities? I dare say that he would, but the fact is that the Minister did not do so. He chose instead a difficult and regrettable course, but nevertheless a course which was the least of the evils available.

In doing this, the Minister also took on board the recommendation of the Jupp Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services for the establishment of the Office of Multicultural Affairs. The honourable member for Moncrieff said that the figures do not add up. The figures do add up. Basically, the Minister will save $2.5m in the full year from the abolition of AIMA, and in the full year will spend at least $1m on the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs. That is what will happen.

Of course, the honourable member for Mitchell has an opportunity to refer to a number of government decisions in this area. As my colleague the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) said, a number of the decisions taken in relation to multicultural affairs were taken by different Ministers and, consequently, there was an overall impact on multiculturalism which was not intended by the Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself has admitted that. He has said that that impact and perception were unfortunate, but certainly unintended. As the honourable member for Mitchell mentioned, in reply to a question that I asked in this Parliament of the Prime Minister, he said that the Government is `unequivocally committed' to multiculturalism. He replied that the Government will be committed to those principles. But what happened in the Budget process was that a number of Ministers were making decisions and, unfortunately, the overall impact on the ethnic communities was tough.

We need to work out ways of ensuring that this sort of problem does not arise in the future. I will have more to say about that in a little while. But to suggest that it is a deliberate attack on multiculturalism by the Government is to be mistaken.

This is not to say that every member of this House has an appreciation of multiculturalism. One of the problems in Australia is that people make many statements in support of multiculturalism but have not been prepared to put their money where their mouths are, and thus governments have not been prepared to deliver sufficient services. We have to educate the nation about the importance of a multicultural society. I appreciate that some honourable members opposite want to do that. I do not include the Leader of the Opposition in that group because he has never made a statement on the matter and he has never supported it. However, I do appreciate the support given by other honourable members opposite, especially the honourable member for Goldstein, in pressuring for the support of multicultural programs.

Multiculturalism needs to be promoted further in Australia. It needs to reach the consciousness of the highest levels of government. In order to do that, the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs must be given the highest status. My colleague the honourable member for Hotham and other members of the Caucus immigration and ethnic affairs committee have suggested that the Office be put under the auspices of the Prime Minister, with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs assisting him. That ought to be seriously considered, because the lack of co-ordination in the preparation of this year's Budget ought not be repeated. We support the idea that, because multiculturalism is an area covered by a number of portfolios and departments, the Prime Minister ought to have responsibility for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear; a good Prime Minister, too; the best person for the job.

—As the honourable member said, the credentials of the Prime Minister in relation to multiculturalism have been good. The status of multiculturalism in Australia must be elevated through the elevation of this Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the specific attacks that have been made by the Opposition in relation to what is to happen. I explained that the abolition of AIMA was a decision that was made within a financial context. It was not a decision in which the Government took any particular pleasure. It was a regrettable decision and a difficult one, but it had to be made within that context. As my colleague the honourable member for Hotham said, we wish to pay tribute to the work of AIMA. AIMA played a positive role-especially, I might say, after it was reconstructed by the Labor Government, because in its first few years it was a disgrace. I have spoken about that in other places. Prior to the review by Dr Cass of the operations of AIMA, we had a very difficult situation because the Liberal Party, through its appointees, was virtually running the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs.

We had heard from the honourable member for Moncrieff that the abolition of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs will mean that the Government will not get any politically unbiased advice. I say to the honourable member for Moncrieff that during the period the Fraser Government was in power AIMA never produced any politically neutral advice because it was always under the control of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish! You have not read the research.
—Who was the head of AIMA during that period? Everyone knows the answer to that question. Let me now turn to the question--
—It is not about an ideal, it is about political control; is that right?
—No, it is certainly not.
— Order! There are far too many interjections.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, this is obviously a lively topic. Let me turn to what the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs will be doing. Obviously, this Office has the potential to strengthen the role of multiculturalism in government planning. The creation of this unit is a necessary demonstration to the ethnic communities of Australia of this Government's continuing commitment to multiculturalism. As a unit within a government department, this Office will be able to offer advice to the Government as a whole and serve as a liaison point between the ethnic communities and those responsible for policy making and implementation. We understand the concern expressed at the closure of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, since research is vital for the development of multicultural policies. However, the replacement of AIMA with the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs has the potential to improve research and to make it more relevant, with greater prospects of policy implementation and greater accessibility to both the ethnic communities and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: How can this be done? One way in which it can be done is if, in addition to the work being done by the Office, other work is contracted out to research institutes such as universities and colleges, which I remind the honourable member for Mitchell, will be able to undertake that research on an objective basis. There is nothing to prevent the Government and this unit from contracting out this sort of research. There are many key people in universities and colleges in Australia doing excellent research in multicultural affairs, and we can use those people. In fact, I understand that financial provision will be made within the Office for precisely that task. So, that is part of what will happen. As I say, it is of critical importance that this Office's potentiality be realised. For this to occur, the Office should not be--
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Both the honourable member for Mitchell and the honourable member for Hotham will cease interjecting and allow the honourable member for Calwell to complete his remarks in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I know that you are very interested in multiculturalism and want to hear what we are saying. Let me continue: For this to occur, the Office should not be just a research centre; it should also be an action centre, giving direct advice on its findings to Ministers and pressuring for the implementation of programs. That is one function that AIMA was not able to achieve. It is important that the new Office be not merely a source of research and a source of policy formulation but also a source of policy implementation. It should be able to pressure for the implementation of programs. It must be staffed by experts in the field, preferably with representation from the ethnic communities. It must draw on the expertise and resources that already exist in AIMA, the universities and amongst the various organisations that act for the ethnic communities.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of a government department, the new Office can be accessible to people all over Australia, if staff are given sufficient flexibility to travel and have contacts. I hope that that will form part of the provisions that are given to the new Office. I hope that it will become a truly national body, taking full account of communities all around the country, consulting with them and involving them in its work. I repeat: As the new Office will be part of a government department, it will be involved in actual policy formulation and advice to those who decide on and implement policy. It will not be just a think tank. Many studies have been carried out on the problems and needs of ethnic communities, but the link between research and action has not been good enough. Also, if this Office maintains a constant and genuine contact with the ethnic communities, it will provide for the first time a much needed channel for those communities to be heard by government and the bureaucracy.

The most important thing about this new initiative is that there must be consultation with the ethnic communities about the establishment, formation and structure of the Office. If this Office is to be successful in changing the direction of multicultural policies, it must have the confidence of the ethnic communities and it must be responsive to their concerns. In addition to promoting multiculturalism, the new Office will develop and enhance the Government's access and equity strategy for people of ethnic background. Discrimination remains a problem in the community, and it is important that the Government's anti-discrimination objectives be achieved. The Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs should be able to work together with the amended Human Rights Commission to help to eradicate discrimination and achieve greater equity.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has issued a draft series of possible functions for the new Office and I hope that this will be referred to by the Minister when he replies. I say to the Government and the Opposition that we expect the fulfilment of the assurance that was given by the Prime Minister on 22 August:
And I want to say that the Government, through my Minister for Immigration, now here with me on this occasion, commits the Government unequivocally to enhancing multicultural values.

It is important to ensure that the problem of the lack of co-ordination of multiculturalism policies be resolved and that multi-naturalism promoted through the establishment of the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any calm assessment of where we are going with multiculturalism and in any debate on a Bill dealing with the institutions that have been provided to look after it, it is probably just as well to consider what multiculturalism is and perhaps what it should be. The word `multicultured' has been borrowed from Canada and it has never had any clear meaning in an Australian context. It seems to be used in Australia as an antonym for assimilation, and for many of those who could be deemed to be multiculturists, that is a swear word. Multiculturalism is used in Australian politics to promote the cultural and economic interests of certain non-Anglo-Celtic sections of the Australian community. In the Canadian context, multiculturalism has served to balance the competing interests between two large and diverse groups, namely those of British and French origins.
