SPEECH.PARA: The word `ethnic', seems to have taken on a peculiar meaning in Australia-namely, non-Anglo-Celtic people. The definition that appears in the Macquarie dictionary is as follows:

Pertaining to or peculiar to a population . . . referring to the origin, classification, characteristics . . . pertaining to members of the community who are migrants or the descendants of migrants and-
as, of course, this is the Macquarie dictionary-
whose native language is not English.
That particular definition has become enshrined in the Australian language. However, in reality, `ethnic' means the initial definition as given in the Macquarie dictionary.

`Multiculturalism' seems to wander in meaning through a spectrum ranging from respect for difference and non-conformity, and the recognition that one's own values are neither infallible nor unique, to separatism that is based on ethnicity, or apartheid, the euphemism for which is separate development. This spectrum is sometimes characterised as having soft multiculturalism at one end, proceeding to hard multiculturalism at the other.

The multicultural growth industry has asserted for many years that multiculturalism is necessary to reverse the historical social trend of migrants being absorbed in the broad Australian community. I have to ask why? What is wrong with the historical social trend of migrants being absorbed in the broad Australian community and becoming Australians.

Multiculturalism of the sort that is being generally advocated today seeks, through administrative and educational intervention, to push for the harder forms of multiculturalism. This has meant that values are often promoted which are quite at variance with Australian social mores, and which basically deny those attitudes of liberalism and plurality upon which Australian society is based.

Support for the values of some minority communities means support for a sheltered, separate, limited and thoroughly sexist upbringing for, as an example, daughters. It means, for some communities, inculcating racial and ethnic mythologies theoretically irrelevant to the future of Australia but having a politically and literally explosive potential for our future. It means, in some instances, perpetuating the notion of killing to maintain family or blood honour. It means that members of Aboriginal communities may properly be maimed, speared or even killed by other Aboriginals if they are judged to have violated Aboriginal customary law.

Multiculturalism is not about free-flowing wine, exotic cuisine or simple dancing. It is not even about reinforcing exotic aspects of the cultures of migrants to Australia. Instead, it is about what Professor Lauchlan Chipman has called:

. . . the preservation of ethnic integrity, the reinforcement and imposition on the new born of sets of traditions, beliefs and values, which include, as well as those which are noble and enlightened, some which are at least as inhuman, as grotesquely ignorant, and as racist, and as bigoted as any that can be squeezed from even the most appalling of ockers.

That quotation acknowledges the regressive nature of multiculturalism, which asserts that cultures are static and unvarying from one place to another, and that these cultures must be preserved in as pure a form as possible, no matter how irrelevant this may be. Multiculturalism in its present form in Australia seeks to retard the evolution of Australian culture and society by preventing interaction between different heritages in a liberal and plural background, such as exists in Australia. The pursuit of multiculturalism in its present form in Australia will eventually see Australia reduced to a confederation of ethnic tribes warring with one another for political ascendancy and the financial gravy train that follows in its wake. This is completely at variance with the democratic values held in Australia.

A democratic society is characterised by lack of discrimination and the presence of individual freedom. In such a society there is cultural freedom and the freedom of conscience. An individual is free to engage in cultural activity by himself or in association with others, to live where he chooses, and to intermingle and interact as he chooses. What is not permissible is the imposition of either state-sponsored culture or rules of behaviour. Wave upon wave of immigrants have come to Australia, not because of a state-guaranteed cultural environment but because Australia affords opportunities for individual advancement and freedom. Multiculturalism is the antithesis of these liberal values.

It is most important at this stage in the development of Australian society that we do not blindly accept the concepts of multiculturalism that are now being promoted. I know that because I am querying multiculturalism and, bluntly, suggesting that it is a mistake and not in the best interests of Australia, it is likely that cries of condemnation will be directed at me to the effect that I am racist or prejudiced. If that is the position, I can accept it. I have broad shoulders. While waiting to speak I made a quick list of the nationality of close personal friends of my wife and myself. It is certainly not exhaustive, but it includes Australians whose heritage is Greek, Yugoslav, Italian, French, Korean, Chinese, Malaysian, Indian, Pakistani, American, German, Danish, Norwegian, Argentinian, Indonesian and Vietnamese. That is probably typical of every ordinary, fair-minded and tolerant Australian. That is the pattern throughout our society.

We must query, however, where we are going as a nation. Are we seeking to build up ghettos? Are we seeking to build up separatism? I do not believe that that is the track to follow. There is no reason to be ashamed of being Australian, and I make no apology for saying that and there is every reason for those who come to this country to become Australians to do so.

I do not for one minute challenge the value of migration to Australia. In fact I would be one of the greatest exponents of the value of migration. I can recall, as a very young boy before the war, when growing up in Newcastle, going into a ham and beef shop in Beaumont Street, Hamilton. The shop was called a ham and beef shop because that is what it sold. It sold ham and beef and pickled onions and gherkins and a sausage or two. One of the sausages was originally called, I think, the German sausage but during the war, of course for patriotic reasons, we changed the name to Empire sausage. Of course if we were very, very daring-

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a really good exercise in multiculturalism.

—Oh, get back in your box, Andrew. If we were very daring we would have some garlic sausage which had a wave of one clove of garlic per bullock. Since the war we have seen such an amazing growth in the variety of cuisine in this country. We have benefited amazingly from the people who have come here from all over the world. If we go to any restaurant in Australia we can see how we have been so enriched in a culinary sense by the people who have come to dwell in Australia and be Australians. Every one of us who is not an Aboriginal comes from a migrant heritage. I see no difference between me, with Scottish forebears, and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) who I think has a Greek ancestry-he has never told me but I think I am correct in my assumption. I see no difference between me as an Australian and the honourable member. I am an Australian of Scottish and English heritage and background and the honourable member is an Australian of Greek heritage. I believe that he has every right to cherish that background of his forefathers, just as I have with my Scottish forebears. As a young man I was very keen and enthusiastic about this and I started to learn how to play bagpipes. I did not get very far. I can speak a few words of Gaelic and I still maintain an interest in that Scottish background. I think that is great; I think everybody is entitled to do that. But I do not believe that the best interests of any Australian will be served by creating dissension and by creating a divisive situation.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said earlier today, we have to exercise respect, acceptance, understanding and tolerance for other people. When people make the decision to come to Australia the great bulk of them want to come here to live, to work and to have a better life than the one they had from where they came and, most certainly, to provide a better life for their children. Who can quibble with that ambition? It is one that millions of Australians have taken on board and done amazingly well. I made reference earlier to the vast number of personal friends that I have from varying countries around the world who are here as Australians. They are not Italians living in Australia, they are not Greeks living in Australia but they are Australians of Greek, Italian, Scottish and other heritage. I think this point has to be made very strongly: We cannot have a situation where a government, whichever government it may be, is shovelling money into creating a situation which ends up causing divisiveness.

Some years ago in Melbourne, from 1969 to 1971 I think, I had the opportunity of working in the management area of migrant hostels. I was on the managerial staff at Maribyrnong, Holmesglen, Broadmeadows and Springvale. The honourable member for Hotham will know about one of those migrant hostels because it has just been closed. For those years I actually lived in migrant hostels, longer than most migrants did at that time. My wife was a teacher teaching English as a foreign language. If we are going to consider anything, one single point stands out about the welfare of migrant groups in Australia, and that is that the program for the teaching of English must have absolute priority and must have every bit of funding that it needs. That is absolutely vital.

The Minister sitting at the table, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), said last night in his summing-up on another Bill that the member for Cowper came in in the morning and said cut back on this, and then came in in the afternoon and said spend more on this. There is nothing inconsistent in that because it is a question of priorities. I make that point to say that the priority of this Parliament and of government members should be to provide every dollar that is needed to have enough teachers so that every non-English speaking migrant in this country will have the full facility to learn English.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why hasn't Howard said anything about it?

—I do not know, but I know that this is what is absolutely essential. I also know this: We have areas that some people regard as ghettos, such as Leichhardt in Sydney which is regarded as an Italian ghetto. Over recent decades many Italian Australians have lived in Leichhardt. There are other areas such as Marrickville, Lakemba and so on where other migrants live. The point is-I am sure the honourable member for Calwell will agree with me-that when people who migrate to Australia, such as Italians in this case, leave a migrant hostel they want a staging post. They want to live in a situation where they can do their shopping in their native tongue and where, if they get into any problem, they can discuss it in their native tongue and where they can feel comfortable, relaxed and secure.
—What is wrong with that?

—Who is suggesting that anything is wrong with that? Wake up. You are not really a dummy so do not behave like one. What I am saying is that those particular areas are staging posts and very naturally, if I were going to live in Rome I am sure that with my total lack of Italian, I would be happy to live in a situation-if there were one-where I was in an English speaking neighbourhood. But the reality is that when the people move in there they become knowledgeable about Australia. They get some English and then move on to somewhere else. When I lived at Abbotsford in Sydney I had Italian neighbours, and very good neighbours they were too. In Coffs Harbour, where I live, there is a very big Italian community-a community of Australians of Italian heritage-and they are very good Australians too. I have never met a bad one. The reality is-I come back to this point because I believe it is absolutely vital-that every necessary dollar must be made available for the teaching of English as a foreign language. I do not believe it is appropriate for the Government to provide funds in an area which would create divisiveness and separate development. There are enough problems in the world and enough problems in Australia without that. We do not want another country within our country. With the caring and compassionate society that we have we need to provide assistance to those people who need it, not on the basis of race and colour or anything else but on the basis of need for every Australian. That is what we need and that is what the coalition will do when it gets back into power at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for the call in this debate. I want to take the opportunity, in the discussion on the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill, which is abolishing the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, to make some points about the way in which the Government has gone about this task that it has set itself. I also want to deal with the reasons for the Fraser Government putting in place the Institute of Multicultural Affairs and the reason why multiculturalism is so important in Australia. In doing so I will take up the comments of at least one of my colleagues who spoke immediately before me in this debate, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). The honourable member for Cowper acknowledged that multiculturalism can mean different things to different people and that there were at least two extremes. On the basis of the extremist approach he set up a straw man and then proceeded to knock him down.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think anybody on this side of the House would argue, nor have I heard people on the Government benches argue-there may be some Marxists around who advocate a more extremist approach-for separatism or apartheid in Australia. I certainly would not support any concept of multiculturalism which envisaged separatism or apartheid in Australia. Likewise, I do not see my background and my cultural heritage as being the one cultural background and heritage which ought to give rise to that amorphous group of people whom we now call Australians. The fact that we are Australians is derived from the variety of backgrounds of people who have settled in this country and have made it the great country that it is. What people who talk about multiculturalism are anxious to dispel is the concept that was advanced at one time-that we ought to adopt an assimilationist approach, that our culture was static, that all those people who came to Australia thereafter had no role to play, no cultural benefits to give to the rest of us and nothing to offer, and what was here was that which everybody else had to assume when they became Australians.

It seems to me that multiculturalism is that view which adopts what the honourable member said was so important, that is, a liberal and pluralist approach. Certainly that is the approach that the Fraser Government took and it is the very reason the Fraser Government introduced the Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Malcolm Fraser commented on this matter when he set out his Government's commitment to multiculturalism. He stated:

Australian society and culture has already been enriched by artistic, intellectual, lingual, culinary and other contributions of migrant cultures. The development of a multicultural society involves the recognition of the rights of ethnic groups to maintain and foster their ethnic languages and cultures, and requires efforts on the part of all Australians to adopt a multicultural perspective and to promote social harmony in cultural interaction.
He then said that the Government accepted the guiding principles of the Galbally Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services to Migrants and he made this point:
(a) All members of our society must have an equal opportunity to realise their full potential and must have equal access to programs and services;
(b) Every person should be able to maintain his or her culture without prejudice or disadvantage and should be encouraged to understanding and embrace other cultures.

That is what it is about. This organisation which we are abolishing was committed to enhancing the Australian understanding of these objectives. The Government, which has to put so much emphasis upon multiculturalism and its importance to Australia and Australia's future development, is now seen to be dismantling the very institutions that are designed to enhance that perspective of Australia. The abolition of AIMA and the repeal of this organisation through this Bill we are debating today must give rise to doubts in the minds of some Australians as to the commitment of this Government to multiculturalism.

I was aghast when I saw the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). It provided no reasoned argument for the abolition of the organisation; it provided no persuasive arguments about why we ought to be supporting the Bill; it was not based on any report or recommendations to the Government that this approach should be taken, and it was certainly not a persuasive speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a weak speech.
—It certainly was a very weak and duplicitous speech in the sense that it is totally and absolutely internally inconsistent. The Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The review of migrant and multicultural programs and services (ROMAMPAS), which has recently reported, has convinced us of the need for a range of approaches that will more effectively ensure multicultural principles are accepted. In dealing with diversity, we must use diverse approaches to achieve acceptance of the values and benefits of our developing identity built on multiculturalism.

The Minister then had the audacity to say that the Government must take direct responsibility for achieving these objectives. So the institute that provides part of that diversity is to be abolished and the Department is to assume total responsibility. There is no diversity in that; it is totally and absolutely internally inconsistent. It is the approach of a Minister who is not at all convinced about the arguments he is being pressed to put on this matter. If he had any strength and character in relation to this question other approaches could be taken and resignation is one of those that is often resorted to by those who have strong views on a matter of this sort and are prepared to ensure that people know and understand their position on the matter.

I think one has to look at the way in which this Government has acted in relation to AIMA. On coming to office the Government had a review of AIMA. It was carried out by a former Labor Minister and Labor shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The report was critical of AIMA but it was not critical of the need for an independent body advising in this area. In fact the report went further and said that AIMA should be not only reconstructed but also significantly changed to enhance its ability to be able to work in this area. The Government looked at that review and it had other reports before it and it ultimately determined an approach. It modified marginally the structure of AIMA and so AIMA was constituted in the form that the Government wanted.

The Government then proceeded to make new appointments to the body's council. In June last year it was announced that the Government had appointed the Most Reverend Dr David John Penman, Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne, as Chairman of the body. Clare Dunne, Anna Emamy, Al Grassby, Michael Liffman, Alan Matheson, Ms Nihas, Basil Taliangis, Eric Willmott, Katie Young, and Peter Sheldrake were appointed to the body after the Government had advertised for the appointment of council members. In an advertisement, which I have before me, in the Canberra Times of 13 April the Government made it clear that it was seeking appointments of people to this body. The advertisement stated:
Appointments under the provisions of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act will be made by the Governor-General for terms of up to 3 years.

People, many of whom were very distinguished Australians, were invited to join this body in good faith and to contribute to it. A mere 12 months later the organisation is being abolished and these important Australians, who wanted to contribute in this area, are being dismissed without there being even a note of thanks to them for their work and effort in the speech of the Minister. I acknowledge that some members of the Government have spoken on this matter and thanked the members of the Council and members of staff for their contribution. However, I regard the abolition of an organisation in this way without even bothering to thank the people who have contributed to it as the most insulting and offensive action that can be taken. These people responded to the Government's advertisements to the Government's inquiries-an injunction to come forward and contribute.

Time is limited in this debate and I have been asked to contain myself in relation to this matter. I find that very hard to do because I have been through the speeches of honourable members opposite as recently as March 1985 when we discussed the Government's amending Bill on the Institute of Multicultural Affairs. When one reads the speeches of honourable members opposite, one sees no indication that AIMA might be abandoned. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) indicated that the Government was proposing in this Bill to see that AIMA was structured on the principles of multiculturalism and the acceptance and active encouragement of cultural diversity. The honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) had some comments to make about AIMA and its reports. He commented most favourably on them, particularly in relation to youth and the aged. Honourable members may find something prophetic in what he had to say about youth. He said:
They are undoubtedly, particularly in the Rockdale region, amongst those in greatest need of urgent help.

Perhaps the people of Rockdale who will also be voting in Barton will have cause to look at their own member's words in relation to that. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) spoke on this matter as well and indicated that there was great enthusiasm for AIMA. He gave no indication that Labor members would be pressing for its abolition. We had the comments by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, to which the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) so ably drew attention. The only argument put forward by honourable members opposite was that the Government was faced with some very difficult budgetary decisions. They said that the matter was one of priority-presumably in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is a question of priorities, but when I look at the priorities I would be asking whether, in areas where there are acknowledged needs, the priorities ought to have been based on needs or whether they ought to have been made in other areas.

I have been challenged as to whether I could suggest any possible avenues of expenditure reduction in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I offer a bit of advice on one area in particular-grants-in-aid, particularly those grants-in-aid made to the trade union movement. I am shocked at the extent to which the trade union movement, which ought to have a commitment to multiculturalism, rather than using its own funds receives funding from government as a priority over programs for the aged and youth, which we see as being so important. If I were in government, I would be advocating change to the funding of the grants-in-aid programs in favour of more important objectives. There is one other challenge that honourable members opposite have thrown down to us regarding this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you would cut the grant-in-aid program?

—I would cut it in relation to the trade union movement. One other point was made. Honourable members opposite were asking why we were not voting against this Bill. We would vote against this Bill, but there would be no obligation upon the Government to find the funds to continue to support it, even if the AIMA were to remain on the statute book. The only way to save AIMA would be to reject the totality of the Budget. It will be a matter for which the Government has to take responsibility and be prepared to wear it. The Government cannot absolve itself from this decision and say that we could save AIMA by our vote on this legislation. In such a case we would have to reject the Government's Budget in its totality. I am sure that is not a step that honourable members opposite would encourage.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Calwell attacked our parliamentary Leader in relation to this matter and indicated a lack of commitment to multiculturalism on the Leader's part. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has played a very significant part in ensuring the maintenance of a bipartisan approach to immigration and ethnic affairs, and he has ensured that when these matters are discussed, as they have been discussed in the past and are at present, they are put in a proper perspective. It does not do the honourable member for Calwell any good trying to save this Government's bacon on this important question by attacking the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition is as committed to the concept of multiculturalism as any honourable member on this side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what statements?

—Statements were made in debates in this Parliament on previous occasions, when members on the honourable member's side were suggesting that the Liberal Party had an approach other than one of a bipartisan nature to the maintenance of immigration and the maintenance of multiculturalism. The fact is that this Party has a policy on immigration and ethnic affairs, and it has an approach to multiculturalism which appears in its platform and its published policy. It is important to remind honourable members again of our policy. It is obvious that the honourable member for Calwell has not taken any note of that. I will read the policy statement, which was part of our record for the last election. It was in this form:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe in multiculturalism as an enhancement of the Australian way of life; to be welded into our national tradition and to be recognised as strengthening our nation.

We recognise the desire of ethnic communities to participate equally in all aspects of Australian political, economic and cultural life. We agree this means that all Australians should be able to relate to all our institutions and that measures should be taken to ensure equal opportunity to participate in both the benefits and the sharing of responsibilities.

There is no lack of commitment by honourable members on this side of the House. I will not want to sit in this House again, at any time, to hear arguments about a lack of commitment on the part of honourable members on this side of the House to a bipartisan approach to immigration and ethnic affairs when this Government is now responsible for the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, for the closing down of six immigration offices in various parts of Australia, for halving the funds available for teaching English as a second language in our schools, for the abolition of other programs designed to enhance the teaching of ethnic languages in Australian schools, and for the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. They are all steps that the Government has taken in this Budget-there have been others as well-that have had a very significant impact upon the whole concept of immigration and ethnic affairs. It needs to be understood that this is now part of the Government's record. It will be on the record from now on. Whenever the Government wants to lecture us about these matters, I will be able to draw upon each and every one of those decisions.

The honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) suggested in this debate today that there were reasons for these decisions. He suggested that one of them was to ensure that the decisions were all made at once so that the Government would not haemorrhage, I suppose, over time, by having to make some of the decisions now and others at a later time. I do not know that that is the case; I certainly hope that it is. If I were an ethnic person concerned about these matters and if I were reading the speeches, I would have to have some doubt-having regard to the Government's record to date-as to whether this is the end of the matter or whether we could take it for granted that there would be no significant cuts in these programs by this Government in the future. The Government's record arouses very considerable doubt as to its commitment. Certainly, there is no scope for it to be suggesting that there will be any shortcomings on this matter on this side of the House at any time in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was amused to hear the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) call out that the Liberal Government never did anything about multiculturalism when he knows only too well that Malcolm Fraser had a very great commitment to multiculturalism. That Government's commitment was borne out by two particular decisions: First, the establishment of the Special Broadcasting Service, and secondly, the establishment of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. I do not have any recollection of the honourable member for Calwell opposing those decisions when they were announced, though it is possible that he did. He now claims that we have no commitment, yet when one looks at this Government's record one sees that it has effectively abolished the SBS by merging it with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and through this legislation it is abolishing the Institute for Multicultural Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with my colleagues in saying that I am extremely disappointed in the Government for making this decision. Part of the decision strikes me as being related to what could be described as a `Yes, Minister' power grab by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. One could be excused for being suspicious that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) is in some way captive to the views of his own Department and is not promoting what we once understood to be the policy of the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs is to be closed and is to be replaced by a research office in the Department-an office which, of course, will be under the control of the Department, which in turn will be under the control of the Minister, and so any independent capacity the Institute has will subsequently be lost.

The other argument that the Government uses on this issue is that this is a budgetary measure, that this is a matter of priorities and that multicultural issues are not a priority for the Government. That is what the Government is arguing implicitly. It claims that by closing down the Institute it will save some $2m. That is manifestly false because it is not just closing the Institute, it is also opening an arm of the bureaucracy in Canberra, a city far removed from many of the multicultural issues of Australia. That new arm of the bureaucracy in turn will cost the taxpayers a considerable amount of money. I would guess that the cost to the taxpayers would be similar to the cost of maintaining the Institute of Multicultural Affairs, yet the taxpayers lose an independent body-independent of the Minister and independent of the views of the Labor Party-which is located in a much more sensible place for multicultural issues to be discussed.

Fundamentally the Government through this decision, admittedly in a small way, is turning its back on two major community goals. Neither Government members nor Opposition members would deny that the Government has some role to play in pursuing the great goals of Australia. One of the goals the Government is turning its back on is the goal of building internal stability in our society. That internal stability must be built by doing what we can to eliminate class conflict, something that those on the other side of the House have a passionate love affair with, and eliminating ethnic tolerance from our society. The Institute of Multicultural Affairs, through its work, was contributing to those goals. The Institute will now be abolished. I think abolishing the Institute also makes the greater task of building up our country, partly through constructive and progressive immigration policies, all the more difficult because by helping to alleviate some of the problems created by immigration the Institute has made the whole immigration program all the easier: or it certainly had the potential to do that. I know all members on this side of the House would agree that an immigration program is an essential part of building Australia because migrants are a very important source of creative and dynamic energy for our society.

As I have explained, the Institute has played a small part in contributing to the building of those goals, and that is not surprising because it was set up by a government which, for much of its period, was very goal oriented-the Fraser Government. Of course we on this side of the House support the concept of multiculturalism, although we do not support the concept of multiculturalism propagated by the Left in Australia. We see multiculturalism as part and parcel of welcoming people from a whole array of different cultures to our shores. We encourage those people to come. We want to retain the richness of those people's cultural heritages. We do not want to see those heritages scrubbed out, eliminated. At the same time we want those people, and all Australians, to accept that as a nation we have our own unique and evolving heritage, and it is the institutions we have in this country which have evolved from that heritage which have attracted so many migrants to Australia. We must acknowledge our own unique national values; we must have pride in those national values and in turn must build on them.

This was well recognised by Malcolm Fraser in his inaugural address to the Institute of Multicultural Affairs on 30 November 1981. Mr Fraser's speeches on these sorts of issues are well worth referring to. Honourable members will be aware that he had some very good speech writers. Mr Fraser said:

We cannot demand of people that they renounce the heritage they value and yet expect them to feel welcome as full members of our society. Realism alone dictates that cultural differences must be responded to in a positive way.
But multiculturalism is concerned with far more than the passive toleration of diversity. It sees diversity as a quality to be actively embraced, a source of social wealth and dynamism.
Mr Fraser went on to say:
It is about cultural and ethnic differences set within a framework of shared fundamental values which enables them to co-exist on a complementary rather than a competitive basis.
I think that is an extremely important point; one way above the heads of many on the other side. He went on to say:

It involves respect for the law and for our democratic institutions and processes. Insisting upon a core area of common values is no threat to multiculturalism but it is guaranteed, for it provides for minimal conditions on which the well-being of all is secured.

That speech is extremely important and it is as relevant today to the philosophy of the Liberal Party on multiculturalism as it was just five short years ago. I am concerned that the concept of multiculturalism in Australia is being increasingly hijacked by the Left. Its attitude to multiculturalism is really to use it not as a building tool, as it should be used, but as a tool to undermine the evolving heritage of our country. The Left's attitude to multiculturalism is essentially iconoclastic and sadly enough it is beginning to gain the ascendancy. The Left believes that in Australia cultural masochism is an essential ingredient of community tolerance. In the Left's view, the corollary of that is that most of Australia's history, and Australia as it is today, is some sort of terrible mistake.

The Left goes on to attack the existing and evolving heritage of Australia in three basic ways. First of all, it attacks what have been our united perceptions of what Australia was and is. It claims that it is a society built as a result of invasion, genocide and exploitation; that settlers in Australia have been involved in little more than land degradation; that in international affairs we are subservient to the United States of America and the United Kingdom, and that it is a society which is geared towards militarism. It argues that the institutions of our society are in some way totally out of date. It denigrates the constitutional monarchy. It denigrates our system of justice through the common law system by, for example, introducing a Bill of Rights. It ridicules the Constitution and ridicules the concept of federalism, as we have seen through the establishment of the Constitutional Commission and, in my view, the rather suspect use of the foreign affairs power in the case of the Tasmanian dams issue. In addition to that, it denigrates our national symbols such as the Australian flag.

When it comes to education, its attitude towards Australian culture and our evolving heritage-I really do emphasise the word `evolving'-applies again. The education system that it prefers is a system that lacks any appreciation for the values of our society or its history. That is borne out by the simple fact that those subjects are not longer taught in many Australian schools and educational institutions in the way they used to be. In other words, what I described as Left multiculturalism is extremely negative, is iconoclastic, is undermining our heritage and is providing uncertainty and insecurity in Australia. That contrasts so dramatically with the constructive and progressive multiculturalism of the sort that was advocated by the Fraser Government and which is still advocated by the Liberal Party. Our form of multiculturalism welcomes people of diverse cultures to Australia and wants them, through their diversity, to contribute to the building of our country. But it is also a form of multiculturalism that understands that every society needs deep, growing roots. Our roots are part of our national pride and must provide us with some inspiration to go ahead in the future.

Multiculturalism is building on institutions which have attracted migrants to Australia and which have provided us with a unique degree of freedom in this country and with qualities such as fairness and equity before the law. Those institutions have been developed over some 200 years. Our sort of multiculturalism recognises pride in the history of our country and in the pioneering spirit of so many of the settlers from a whole range of cultures who have come to our country and who have been so eminently successful in building up this country. Our form of multiculturalism, in a phrase, is all about a commitment to building Australia together with a whole range of groups from diverse origins. I quote Malcolm Fraser who, again in his inaugural address, said:

If particular groups feel that they and their children are condemned whether through legal or other arrangements to occupy the worst jobs and housing, to suffer the poorest health and education, then the societies in which they live are bent on a path which will cost them dearly.

I want to know whether the Labor Party disagrees with those comments. If it does not disagree with them-as I dearly hope that it does not-why is it striking down a very valuable institution which is contributing, in a phrase, to the building of Australia? I am sorry that my time is running out and that I have had to truncate my remarks because this is a very important debate. It is a debate which the Labor Party will hear a lot more about because its record on multiculturalism is a record of shame: Merging the Special Broadcasting Service and effectively winding it up; cutting back by half expenditure on English as a second language; and now abolishing the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. The Minister has overseen what, in effect, amounts to an attack on constructive and moderate multiculturalism. He is leaving the field open to radical multiculturalism which is negative and destructive of all that is good in Australia. We on this side of the House express our opposition to this legislation and hope that in the future when the government changes we can get back to the task of building Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take no pleasure in saying to this House that this unfortunate-indeed, disgraceful-legislation, the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill, vindicates the worst fears I expressed during the time I had the honour to be the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in 1983 and in 1984. Sadly, every single prediction I made at that time has now come true. The ethnic communities of Australia have been cruelly and shamefully betrayed by a Government which told them that it was their friend and which, in the space of just a few weeks, has proceeded to destroy the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Special Broadcasting Service and, to cut by more than half, funding for the English as a second language program. On 14 August this year I issued a Press statement, part of which I would like to read into the record. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Now Australia's ethnic communities really know what the Hawke Socialist Government thinks about them. When I was shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs I repeatedly warned that the Hawke Socialist Government would axe the Institute for Multicultural Affairs at the first possible opportunity, and would also bring about the demise of the SBS.

At that time, in 1983-84, nobody wanted to hear what I was saying. Nobody wanted to believe my predictions. Many Australian Labor Party ethnic community leaders repeatedly accused me of scaremongering. They called me a racist and said that I was not speaking the truth. Now the truth is out. The ethnic communities of Australia are now learning the hard way that the Labor Party simply cannot be trusted. The Hawke socialist Government promised the ethnic communities much. Its promises are now dishonoured. At least the Liberal and National Parties under Malcolm Fraser delivered exactly what they promised.

Going back through my files, I noted with interest a Press statement issued at a joint Press conference held by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and me, in Melbourne on 19 January 1984. One of the matters the then Leader of the Opposition emphasised at that joint Press conference was that a Liberal-National Party Federal Government would-I emphasise this-depoliticise ethnic affairs policies and programs. I quote the statement verbatim:

Under the Hawke Labor Government immigration and ethnic affairs have taken a dangerous and radical turn to the left. Mr West is simply listening to the wrong people and pandering to extremist elements who do not represent majority opinions in Australia's ethnic communities. The Hawke Labor Government has already destroyed the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and now is turning its attention to the Special Broadcasting Service, a major initiative of the Fraser Government.

The then Leader of the Opposition said that his Government would ensure `a balanced, non-political and equitable migration policy and a fair deal for ethnic communities, free from political favouritism, nepotism and string pulling'. In this House on 9 December 1983 I challenged the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), who has now been replaced, to provide his outrageous statement that AIMA has been a costly failure. That statement made by the Minister at that time has never been proved. I challenged the Minister to prove that AIMA had not done the job for which it had been established. Again, that statement has never been proved. I challenged the Minister to justify his attack, which I regarded as a disgraceful attack, on two great Australians, Mr Frank Galbally and Mr Petro Georgiou. Again, the Minister and the Government failed to come up with the proof to support their statements.

It is a sad thing for Australia's ethnic communities that they have to learn the hard way that the Labor Party simply cannot be trusted. Right through 1983-84 as shadow Minister I had to say things which people did not wish to hear. It was reminiscent of Churchill's great speech in the House of Commons in 1938 when he said: `I will now have to tell the House the ugly truth which it will not want to hear'. I take no joy in being vindicated. I note the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee). On these three issues, the Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Special Broadcasting Service and the English as a second language program, the honourable member and I have been ad idem. I gave evidence before the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and stressed that the SBS must be retained as a separate institution with separate funding. I gave evidence before the Committee of Review into the Special Broadcasting Service chaired by the Honourable Xavier Connor, QC, on exactly the same points. My position on AIMA has been consistent. I, too, am curtailed in my speech. I certainly will permit the honourable member for Goldstein to make his comments and, in fairness, the Minister has a right to reply--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, thank you.

—The honourable member can make as much noise from Moscow corner as he wants. I am telling him that the ethnic communities of Australia now know that he cannot be trusted. As recently as yesterday a senior ethnic community leader who is a member of the ALP said to me: `Michael, one thing. Malcolm Fraser did not promise a lot, but what he promised he delivered 100 per cent. The present crowd promised the world and they have betrayed us on every turn along the way'. The Government said to ethnic community leaders: `Do not believe the Liberals. Do not believe the shadow Minister Hodgman. We are your friends'. I had to wear that for over 18 months in very tough times. I had some unexpected supporters. People in the Labor Party actually supported me and showed great courage. People such as Mr Bill Jegorow, who stuck with me through thick and thin, are people I will never forget. The ethnic communities of Australia now know that they cannot believe the ALP. It has betrayed them over and over again. The Government is a sham and a disgrace. Any ethnic person in Australia who ever votes for this anti-ethnic Government again needs his or her head read.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. There would never have been one member of the Labor Party who supported the comments put forward by the honourable member for Denison when he was the shadow Minister. He split the ethnic communities and he divided the country.
—You ought to go back to the Soviet Embassy.

—I take a further point of order. I ask that the comment made by the honourable member for Denison be withdrawn. I have done so before. I have never been inside one embassy in this country and I resent the fact that he uses the opportunity in this place to suggest that I visit certain embassies. He lives in certain embassies here and in other places. I do not frequent any embassy. If a foreign diplomat wants to see me, he can come and see me here. I ask that the honourable member withdraw the remark.
—Order! I call on the honourable member for Denison to withdraw the remark.
—In respect to you, Sir, I withdraw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the taxation matters are to be debated later this afternoon, I honour the request to be brief in my remarks. However, I must speak in this debate. I do so more in sorrow than in anger. I have in front of me a newsletter dated August 1986 which was prepared by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia. Under the heading of `Multiculturalism betrayed', there is a very strong editorial on that subject which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The real tragedy for ethnic communities was hidden in the Guidelines for the Commonwealth Schools Commission presented by Susan Ryan. Under the guise of integrating multiculturalism into normal mainstream education programs the multicultural Education Program, worth $5.1m, has been scrapped. Under the camouflage of rationalisation and streamlining the funds available for the Ethnic Schools Program have been cut 5%.

Worst of all, the English as a Second Language program for migrant children has been savagely attacked: the general support funding has been almost halved, from $62m to $34m. Put this together with a real 4% cut in funding for the Adult Migrant Education Program, and an 8% cut in the real budget for the National Advisory and Coordinating Committee for Multicultural Education; place it in the context of AIMA's abolition and SBS's merger; and the Government's commitment to multiculturalism would seem to be a shallow rhetoric with little value in dollars and cents.

A number of questions need to be asked loudly in high places. Just what are the financial commitments to the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs? How real can access and equity be when the funds available for ESL teaching have been so reduced? How can SBS television continue to operate an independent multicultural channel under the proposed new charter? Australia's ethnic communities will need some good answers.

I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I support his criticisms of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Repeal Bill, as well as those of my colleagues who have spoken in the debate. I thought that the contributions were constructive. We are entitled to ask: Where does multiculturalism go now? It is true that multiculturalism is a term which confuses and bothers some people. Let me restate my understanding of the matter. I outlined it many times as a Minister and as one who administered the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in its first three years in existence. Multiculturalism involves a recognition that we have a core culture which happens, by historical accident, to have come from the United Kingdom. That core culture involves the English language, the parliamentary system and the judicial system. Essentially, that is the basis of our society and all that goes with it in terms of rights, freedom and democracy. Those are the issues which all Australians, regardless of their ethnic origin, respect. It is the reason people want to come here, and they respect it.

In various programs which the Fraser Government adopted, we were simply endeavouring to enable people who had the disadvantage of not having English as their native language to have opportunities via a variety of positive programs to be equal to those to whom English was the native language and to help people who were disadvantaged in other ways in terms of training and recognition of their skills. In deciding what were the proper policies for the Federal Government and the State governments to pursue, we recognised that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, with all of its qualities-I agree with what the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) said-was ill-equipped to produce independent surveys and to really tell us what the settlement difficulties were for people of a non-English speaking country of origin.

So the Institute was established. I believe that it hid its light under a bushell. It did not promote itself in the way in which it might have done, even to members of parliament. It has done some very valuable work. I join my colleagues in doubting, regardless of the bona fides of some of the individuals involved, that any office in any department can achieve the same independent research. I join the honourable member for Mitchell in saying that it is a great shame that the Government has made this decision. In my view, it has disproportionately cut the ethnic budget vote compared with other Budget cuts. I think that the Ethnic Communities Council is right to find fault with that. If the Government intends pursuing such a line and continuing with its policy, it must monitor very carefully what the new office does. We in the Opposition will be monitoring it very carefully to ensure that the same quality of independent objective surveys for decision-making by government are carried out by that body.

The Government has made the decision. We wish that it had taken the further step, which the honourable member for Mitchell mentioned, to help to relocate the very worthwhile people who are in the Institute in other areas of employment, perhaps with universities or colleges of advanced education, whereby they could continue their excellent work under the funding of those organisations. I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) to direct his attention to that. Perhaps something positive can be done about it. My time has expired. I conclude by saying that I honestly hope that the Minister will look at that matter. We will be monitoring very carefully the performance of the new office. We hope that the Minister will direct attention to all our remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have taken part in the debate. I very much regret that I was able to be here only for the last three speeches, but I have been fully briefed on the others. Let me explain the reason I was unable to be here. My timetable was built around the debate taking place yesterday. When it got late, I apologised to the shadow Minister that I would miss his speech and said that I hoped to be here for the rest of the debate. However, it transpired that the debate was not brought on yesterday but today. I tried to change my appointments. One of them was with Dr Pardo de Tavera, the Filipino Minister for Social Services. We have a continuing dialogue. I met her in Manila and we discussed the question of Filipino brides, and so on. I do not take lightly missing a debate such as this within my portfolio responsibilities, and I can do no other than explain that I tried to be here as soon as I possibly could. I apologise for not achieving that earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: From what I have heard, there have been many crocodile tears from the Opposition in this debate. My colleagues have had to bear the hypocrisy of honourable members opposite, paying, on the one hand, lip service to a commitment to the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and, on the other, not going back on their economic policies which do nothing more than spell out the fact that if the Liberal- National parties were in government they would cut government spending by billions more than the present Government, in the sensitive way that it has been obliged to cut government funding, has done.

I thank the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) for their contributions to this debate, because they put it in the proper perspective. Within each portfolio, we have had to make tough choices, and this was one of the tough choices we had to make. If we were not cutting spending here, there would have to be a cut in spending on those services for people at the grass roots-the migrant education program, the translator and interpreter services, the grants-in-aid to social workers; and, yes, the grants-in-aid to trade unions, because we are reaching out through those trade union grants to people who would not otherwise be helped, in particular migrant women through unions such as the Miscellaneous Workers Union, who would not otherwise be helped in the way that they deserve. All of those services are intact, despite the tough decisions that had to be made in the context of the Budget.

We do not enjoy terminating AIMA, and anyone who suggests that I, as Minister, enjoyed terminating AIMA is spreading an untruth. Of course we do not. If it came to a choice, as it has, between having AIMA and having the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs, I would make the same choice again. Unfortunately, AIMA was removed in Melbourne and was not having that influence on government policy-not only in Canberra but, through our network, government policies in the States-that I expect our Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs to have. We would have preferred not to have had that choice. We would have preferred to have had both AIMA and the Office; but when one has these hard choices to make, one chooses what is best for the people at the grass roots. That we have done.

As was pointed out by the honourable members for Hotham and Calwell, if the Opposition had been in power, there would have been a cut in services at the grass roots. There would have been fewer places for learning English; there would have been a reduction in the translator and interpreter services; and there would not have been many of the grants for social workers which are so badly needed.

I know that many more of my colleagues would like to have been involved in this debate, including the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), with his large multicultural constituency; but unfortunately we have time limits, and I must keep to them, too. I want to make it clear that the only reason why the report of the Jupp Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services has not been tabled is that we are waiting for copies to be printed. The shadow Minister has a copy. I make no claims other than that the Jupp committee had recommended the setting up of an Office of Ethnic Affairs. We have converted that recommendation into an Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs. The Jupp committee did not address the question of whether AIMA should exist; that was not among its terms of reference. Among its members, as among the informed community in this area generally, one would find some who believe that AIMA should continue and some who believe that it should be terminated. I happen to believe that, if resources grew on trees, it would be nice to continue with AIMA, but when we had to make hard choices, that option was not before us.

The Government's commitment to the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs is undiluted. We shall be going ahead with that. The details of the Office are being determined at present; an announcement will be made after we have gone through the necessary consultations. But the Government's commitment to multiculturalism is not reduced one iota by what has happened in this Budget. We are putting flesh on the bones of multiculturalism. We are not just going through the empty rhetoric about multiculturalism and the sloganeering which has been so much a part of political debate in this country. To us, multiculturalism is an equality of opportunity for everyone, whatever their backgrounds, to contribute to our growing Australian identity. Multiculturalism is also an equality of treatment for everyone, whatever their backgrounds. This Hawke Labor Government is making sure that those commitments are undiluted.

The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) can quote from a document issued by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, but that document is inaccurate. We will find, when it comes to grass roots policies to carry through our definition of multiculturalism, that the commitment of this Hawke Labor Government to multiculturalism is no less. I commend the Bill to the House. We will be opposing the amendment.

That the words proposed to be omitted (MrCadman's amendment) stand part of the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
Noting that-
(a) the 3 Baltic States, Latvia Lithuania and Estonia, were independent sovereign republics and members of the League of Nations from 1918 to 1940;

(b) in 1940, as a consequence of the Molotov- Ribbentrop Pact between the USSR and Nazi Germany, the 3 States were incorporated into the USSR by military force and in a manner which violated elementary principles of freedom, democracy and justice;
(c) like other democratic governments, Australia does not recognise de jure the incorporation of the Baltic States into the USSR;
(d) under Soviet rule, well-documented violations of human rights have occurred and continue to occur in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, and
(e) as a result of existing Soviet policies on indigenous languages and immigration, the very survival of the Baltic peoples as separate ethnic and cultural entities is endangered-

(1) acknowledges the concern felt by the members of the Australian community over the situation in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, particularly the repression of individuals engaging in the non-violent expression of their ethnic and cultural identity and religious convictions;
(2) commends the Government for its action in bringing this concern to the attention of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights at the Commission's meetings in March 1985 and March 1986;

(3) invites the Government, on its own initiative and in consultation with like-minded Governments, to continue to raise formally the question of self-determination and other human rights for the Baltic States before appropriate international forums;

(4) calls upon the Government of the USSR to end acts of repression against the Baltic peoples and to abide by the commitments which it has entered into under the various international covenants on human rights to which it is a signatory, and
(5) requests the Speaker to bring this resolution to the attention of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.

I understand that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) will second the motion, to which I will speak for only one or two minutes. I would first thank the honourable member for Grayndler and the House for allowing the motion to take precedence. Those honourable members who have followed the course of events will know that on 20 February 1986 a similar, but not identical, motion was moved by me. There was some disagreement between me and the honourable member for Dundas on its actual wording. However, we came to what I think was a reasonable agreement on that subject and the result is the motion before the House.

I would like again to emphasise that my personal point of view with regard to the Baltic States, and many of the other problems concerned with the Soviet Union, is not necessarily shared by either the Government or every honourable member on this side of the House. Many of the objections to the Soviet Union are fairly nationalistic objections by residents and ex-residents or many of the Soviet Republics. That is not my main objection. My major objection-I consider to the main problem as far as the Soviet Union is concerned-is that the Soviet Union is a dictatorship. If the Soviet Union were run according to its constitution, residents of the Baltic republics, the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic or any of the republics or minority groups that wished to secede from or leave the Soviet Union would be able to do so. Alternatively, they might wish-I emphasise might-to remain part of the union of democratic republics. That has not happened. My own view is that, of course, the best chance of the people of the Baltic States and other persons in the Soviet Union winning freedom and the opportunity to fulfil their national aspirations would be by changing the Soviet Union from a dictatorship to a democracy. I am not suggesting for one minute that that would be easy but to my mind it would be easier than somehow persuading the current regime to free all of the republics that currently make up the so-called Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

I think it is important to note the official Australian government attitude to this issue. There is no better way of summarising that than by reading four paragraphs from an answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as late as last week to a question on notice by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest). The honourable member asked:
What steps have been taken by the Government over the last three years to press for the observance of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia?
The Minister replied:

This Government over the last three years has strongly and consistently deplored the Soviet Union's unsatisfactory human rights record, including in relation to the Baltic States . . . We have expressed our views publicly as well as conveying them privately to the Soviet authorities.
Australia has also joined in international efforts calling upon the Soviet Union to abide by the important principles of human rights embodied in United Nations instruments.

In response to the concern over the human rights situation in the Baltic States this Government raised the question of violation of human rights in the Baltic States at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March 1985 and March 1986.

On the question of self-determination, as you will already be aware, Australia does not recognise de jure the incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania into the Soviet Union but recognises de facto the Soviet Government's control over the Baltic States.

This Government will continue to support an end to the violation of human rights in the Baltic States and make efforts towards this end which can be assessed as constructive and not counter-productive.
I do not wish to add more because I understand that the House wishes to debate another motion which is probably more controversial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in seconding the motion in its present form. I want to thank my colleagues for giving the House the time to debate this matter briefly and ensure that it is carried today. I want as well to record the interest of colleagues who wished to speak on this matter but have forgone the opportunity of doing so. I refer to the seconder of my amendment, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) and the honourable member for Kooyong, the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Peacock).

SPEECH.PARA: By way of background, I have to note that the form of amendment that I proposed previously was the same as the resolution that was carried in the Senate. I believed that there ought to be a continuity of view as between the House of Representatives and the Senate on the matter. That was why I pressed it. I saw in the original motion of the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) a number of what I thought represented significant differences that ought to be redressed. The first was that, in the preamble of the Senate resolution, particular mention was made of the general desire of all people to live in freedom and achieve self-determination. That was omitted from the honourable member's original motion. A second omission involved the linking of Australia to other international protesters. Thirdly, the motion was drafted in order particularly to commend the Government upon raising the Baltic question before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. I have no objection to that because I believe that the Government should be commended upon so raising it, but it is a far cry from the Whitlam Government's recognition of the incorporation of the Baltic States into the Soviet Union. Nevertheless, I saw the draft as failing to offer a continuing commitment to raising the question in all international forums. However, I must say now, by way of commendation of the Government, that on a second occasion it has raised the matter in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

The fourth and most significant difference was the deletion of a notation of the intensive Russification, aimed at eliminating indigenous languages and culture, that is taking place in the occupied Baltic States. I saw the Government's failure to refer to the Russification process, coupled with its merely vague reference to concern about the repression of ethnic and cultural identity, as sending a special signal of lack of concern about the concept of Russification. That was the reason I pressed my amendment. I am delighted, therefore, that the government has consulted the Baltic Council about the terms of a resolution that all members could willingly support. Included in the motion are references to action taken by the Government since the Senate motion was passed. For that purpose different words have had to be used and that is appropriate. The Soviets cannot now draw any solace from the fact that certain significant thoughts were omitted from the Senate's resolution because these have been addressed in the amended motion. The amendments should be noted. Paragraph (e) provides:
As a result of existing Soviet policies on indigenous languages and immigration, the very survival of the Baltic people as separate ethnic and cultural identities is endangered-
Secondly, paragraph (3) provides:

Invites the Government, on its own initiative and in consultation with like-minded governments, to continue to raise formally the question of self-determination and other human rights for the Baltic States before appropriate international forums.

It will be quickly seen that paragraph (3) of the preamble, or notation, is a description of the process of Russification, whereby immigration policies and the replacement of indigenous languages and cultures is not only endangering but also threatening the very identity of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. The paragraph clearly links Australia's protest with the protests of other like-minded countries and invites action further to that which has already been taken. It refers specifically to self-determination and other human rights which we enjoy and believe should also be the right of the Baltic peoples. They are the very thoughts that are embodied in the first part of the preamble to my amendment. The paragraph also envisages that, by reference to appropriate international forums, this matter will be pressed in other bodies than just the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. Finally, the steps taken by the Government to date are acknowledged in paragraph (2).

When I last spoke on the question I recounted the history of the Soviet's occupation of the three Baltic States. I raised the general violations of human rights which persist; the absence of the right to emigrate and freely travel abroad; the absence of the right of peaceful association; the absence of an independent judicial system and a free Press; the existence of censorship; the repression of religion and the absence of free trade unions. I recounted the distorting of history, the downgrading of the Baltic languages and culture and the exaltation of the Soviets, coupled with significant immigration from elsewhere in the Soviet Union to the Baltic countries. More recent events in the Soviet Union have impacted upon the Baltic people and ought to be noted at this time. They are: The conscription of Baltic people, amongst others, to perform hazardous work in the Chernobyl area over long periods and in making repairs and the like at the Chernobyl site following the recent nuclear disaster. A second matter is the concern of Swedish experts about the large Ignalina facility in Lithuania, which may be even more suspect than was the Chernobyl plant in regard to possible nuclear disaster. A motion in this form is deserving of the support and unanimous endorsement of the House. Once carried, the Government will have the responsibility of ensuring that action is taken at every opportunity to protest the Soviets' continued occupation of the Baltic States and, in the words of the motion, to raise formally the question of self-determination and other human rights for the Baltic people. For my own part I will continue to monitor the Government's actions in this regard. I am sure that the Speaker will take pleasure in bringing to the attention of the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics the terms of this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) congratulates the Government on the success of its policy of improving the efficiency of the Australian shipping industry, and
(2) commends the turnaround in operating results of the Australian National Line resulting in a $22 million improvement in 1983-84 over 1982-83.

It is with great pleasure that today I present this motion in relation to the shipping industry of Australia. As an island continent, Australia is almost totally dependent on shipping to carry its international trade. Australia is also heavily dependent on shipping for bulk haulage around its coastline to bring raw materials from remote areas to processing plants in major population centres. In 1984-85, Mr Deputy Speaker, 312 million tonnes of cargo was shipped into and out of Australian ports. Some 269 million tonnes, or 86 per cent of that cargo originated from, or was destined for, overseas markets. The carriage of our overseas cargo required 6,760 vessel visits to Australia-largely unfortunately in overseas vessels. As well, 75 vessels participated in Australia's coastal fleet, and a further 11 were engaged in coastal and overseas trade and opportunities to earn foreign exchange in servicing our overseas trade have been lost. In fact, of a total freight bill of $6.7 billion for 1984-85 a mere 13 per cent was paid to Australian operators. The actions of conservative governments have allowed 87 per cent of Australia's freight bill to be picked up by overseas freighters. They are the people who now are claiming in this House that there is something wrong in having a deficit! They contributed to nearly $6 billion going out of this country in a single year to pay for foreign shipping. In 1984-85 the activities of non-resident transport operators accounted for some $2,262m of Australia's total balance of payment deficit. Australian resident transport operators contributed $138m. The net deficit on transport related activities represented nearly 20 per cent of Australia's current account deficit. All of this was caused by the trade. Shipping is therefore a vital element in Australia's economic well-being. Its costs and the degree of efficient service that it provides represent significant factors in the competitiveness of Australian goods in international markets, a matter to which the House should pay particular attention at present. It also has something to do with the ability of Australian products to compete on domestic markets with imports. Australia is a top-ranking, world supplier of major commodities such as coal, iron ore, grains, wool, wheat and meat, yet in 1984-85 Australian flag shipping carried only about three per cent of our international trade. That, I believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, is an absolute disgrace.

When this Government took office in 1983 it was confronted by a sick shipping industry. The Fraser Government's lack of coherent policies on shipping and the waterfront cost this country dearly. Industry inefficiencies have imposed unnecessary costs. Previous conservative government's tinkered with, indeed smashed, the Australian National Line and the Australian shipping industry generally. Efficient and competitive Australian flag shipping could make a positive contribution to the reduction of this deficit. It is estimated that over the lifetime of a vessel up to 40 per cent of its total freight earnings will be contributed to the balance of payments. For instance, BHP's Iron Pacific, earns on each voyage some $1m in freight earnings. The Hawke Labor Government has from the outset been prepared to face up to the issues. We have instituted a comprehensive industry program of measures which are systematically tackling every aspect of these problems. The government's objective has been to provide the basis for an efficient, competitive Australian shipping industry which will be able to stand on its own two feet and gain access to cargo on commercial grounds. We are not into providing subsidies and the like, we are simply into asking for Australian shipping to be given a fair go in Australia. A clear and high priority for the government upon assuming office was the task of tackling the problems of the ailing Australian National Line. An efficient and profitable Line is clearly a keystone to the Government's efforts to improve the overall effectiveness of the industry. The government was confronted with a national line that was in a desperate situation and tottering on the edge of bankruptcy. The Line was grossly undercapitalised and saddled with massive debt and crippling interest payments which had been inflicted upon it by previous conservative governments. It is interesting to note that certain comments were made by Captain Sir John Williams, the first chairman of the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission-which is the Australian National Line-on the activities of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) when he was the Minister in charge of transport in Australia. Captain Williams said in his book So Ends this Day:

To our surprise, not long after his appointment, Sinclair informed us that we should now regard the Commission as what he termed a `Political Instrument' subject to control by his departmental officers, overlooking the fact that it had been set up by Sir Robert Menzies to operate free of interference on a private enterprise basis.

Every day the Opposition seeks to tell this Government that it ought to support free enterprise, yet when the previous Minister for Transport was controlling the Australian Shipping Commission he told it that it should not act in a free enterprise way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member for New England was not the previous Minister for Transport. He was Minister for Transport many, many years ago.

—I thank my colleague, the honourable member for Murray, for confirming the fact that the right honourable member for New England was indeed a previous Minister for Transport. In referring to the Secretary of the Department, Captain Williams went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the tactics employed by the former were petty beyond belief and it was my impression that Sinclair was involved in the meanest of them.
