There is little point however in raking over the embers of long dead fires saving for record purposes and the record shows that the `Political Instrument' policy put the Commission in the red for the first time since its inception in 1956.

In sharp contrast to that, this Government, when it took office, initiated immediate action to revitalise the ANL's operation and place in on a sound commercial basis. The Hawke Labor Government has provided capital injections to put the Line on a sounder financial footing, appropriate to its size as one of the larger carriers in the Australian trade. Unlike the previous Minister for Transport, the right honourable member for New England, we have amended legislation so as to give the ANL greater independence and commercial freedom. The Hawke Labor Government has restructured the ANL's senior management and has appointed a new management team with a strong commercial background. The Government believes that the ANL should be out there in the market-place working for Australia. The Government's action has produced positive results. The new management has rigorously overhauled the organisation and reviewed its commercial operations. It has terminated unprofitable services and has disposed of uneconomic vessels and terminals. The benefits of the action taken by the Government and the ANL are flowing through into the ANL's financial results. They are reflected in the Line's return to profitability. It now pays both dividends and income tax. The significant achievements of the ANL are made plain by the fact that in 1985-86 the operating profit is expected to be $38.2m. The ANL is paying its first dividend on profit since 1969-about the time when the right honourable member for New England was presiding over its activities. This year it is paying out $5m in respect of 1984-85. It plans to pay out another $5m in dividends, in respect of 1985-86. It is expected that the ANL will make its first income tax payment-since 1974-some $8m for 1985-86. These achievements have been made possible by the Government's positive action and by the willingness of the ANL's management, and employees to work together. This is a great example of a Government instrumentality, and the unions in the industry getting together to make sure that the industry stays in good health and benefits for all Australians will flow from a great public enterprise.

These results are even more encouraging when seen against the world shipping industry's difficult financial position. A surplus of shipping capacity world-wide has led to the collapse of several large shipping groups, the crisis restructuring of others and an unprofitable operation for many leading shipowners. On the broader industry front, the Government took early action to implement the recommendations of the Crawford report on the revitalisation of Australian shipping. The introduction of new vessels has been accompanied by crew reductions of 20-30 per cent, which should be recognised as being a very significant first step in improving productivity and shipboard work practices. Indeed, the Department of Transport, has been into looking at work practices and productivity since this Government came to office. I repeat, the Government has not just been looking at work practices in recent weeks, as has been suggested by the Opposition. It has been seeking to revitalise work practices and productivity since coming to office. These initiatives are now showing results in the coastal shipping industry where the cost of shipping coastal iron ore from Western Australia to Newcastle, for instance, has halved since 1982.

The emergence of a more efficient and competitive Australian fleet has opened up opportunities for Australian owners to penetrate overseas trade commercially. The entry of BHP's three new bulk carriers to the coal trade of Japan and Korea is significant for a number of reasons. It provides access to cargo on commercial grounds and is particularly significant given record low freight rates obtaining world-wide. It is proof that Australian flag ships can compete. It must be admitted that in the past the industrial record of the industry has been rather poor. Despite this, that the number of working days lost in the seagoing industry is now less than one-third the figure for 1979-82. Similarly, the number of stevedoring days lost has been cut by about three-quarters. These are significant achievements-achieved responsibly by co-operation and consultation between employees and employers rather than by the confrontationist approach of the previous Government. Last year the Government sponsored an industry and union study mission to examine shipping development overseas. That provided great incentive and indeed a great appreciation on the part of people in the industry here of ways of ensuring that the industry will become even more co-operative.

Coastal shipping is a domestic industry which, in the same way as our road and rail transport or indeed our farms, is rightly the province of all Australians. Shipping efficiency is only one element of the transport chain that impacts on the efficiency of the transport services provided to Australian exporters. Without corresponding improvements in the efficiency of shore-based activities the benefits of shipping improvements are not likely to be fully utilised. Shore-based shipping activities account for around 50 per cent of the door to door costs of general cargo and about 20 per cent of the cost of bulk cargo. In recognition of the significance of shore-based shipping costs the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) established in September 1984 a task force to examine the problems of shore-based industry and make recommendations for improving efficiency. The report of that task force identified the scope for greater operational efficiency and reducing the costs of the land-based elements in the movement of sea cargo. It confirmed that there was a clear need to raise productivity and improve industrial relations on the waterfront and detailed the opportunities available for improving the efficiency of shore-based shipping operations. However, the real achievement of the task force is that it has brought all parties involved in these industries together for the first time to examine their problems. It represents a milestone in co-operation between all of the parties involved in these industries and is a timely contribution to the debate on Australia's trading opportunities. The Minister for Transport has invited interested parties to submit by the end of December their views on the report. The responsibility is now firmly with the industry to bring forward constructive and realistic proposals that will improve the efficiency and reliability of shore-based activities.

Finally, I would like to turn to the Government's initiatives in establishing an industry task force to overview Australia's overseas liner shipping arrangements. The main purpose of this study was to consider the effectiveness of Australia's regulation of liner shipping in the light of changes that had occurred since the 1960s, when the existing legislation framework was developed. It might be worth while recalling that the value of non-bulk shipping, which carries half of our overseas trade, is about $26,000m. Wide-ranging comments on this report are now being considered by the Government. One key thread which runs through all the measures that I have outlined is consultation. As with many of the Hawke Labor Government's initiatives, consultation and co-operation have been shown to be the way to go. This Government has brought about not only revitalisation of the industry, but also has a new environment of confidence. It is pleasing to see that local ship owners have recently joined forces in a new organisation-the Australian National Maritime Association. For the first time it has given the local shipping industry a single voice. The previous conservative Government was quite happy to see overseas shippers rape the Australian industry. This Government has set the shipping industry on the right course. Considerable progress has already been made in improving its efficiency. Significant further improvements are in prospect. Three years of hard work have paid off. Consultation and co-operation have proved effective. This achievement will be a lasting monument to the Hawke Labor Government and its energetic Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion formally, and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The business that we are discussing is the Australian shipping industry. A number of aspects of the motion and the industry are worthy of comment. The first is that notice of the motion was given in February 1985, which indicates the percentage of time that is devoted to private members' business in this Parliament. The second concerns the improvements in the ANL operating results and I join the previous speaker in applauding them. The third concerns the suggested success of this Labor Government's policy for improving the efficiency of Australian shipping. As to that the Opposition basically disagrees, because most of the examples given by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) actually resulted from initiatives of the previous coalition Government. The aspect that is of greater importance in relation to having an efficient shipping industry has not been touched upon at all. I refer to the disgraceful situation in our shore-based sector, the waterfront, also to what needs to be done to make Australian shipping, for both coastal and international purposes, genuinely internationally competitive. To that end I will later propose an amendment to the motion which I believe will more accurately reflect the position of the Australian shipping industry and its associated industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the present management and staff of the Australian National Line upon the improved operating profit and loss statement concerning which we have received preliminary figures. There is no doubt that the ANL is now a more commercially managed and oriented organisation. It has rationalised many of its services, ships and staff. I pay particular tribute to those at the top of that management team, the Chairman of the Australian Shipping Commission, Mr Bill Bolitho, and the Chief Executive, Mr Max Moore-Wilton. In so doing I acknowledge the work of both the previous Minister for Transport and Construction, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the present Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), with regard to their efforts to amend the Act so as to allow the ANL to become more efficient. But I must draw attention also to the $160m of taxpayers' money which has been injected into the ANL by the present Government in the last three years. One could argue that if one could not improve operating performance of the profit and loss situation after that sort of injection one should not be in business at all. But it raises the more fundamental question: Is there a need, or is it common sense in 1986 in Australia to maintain a government shipping line?

The Opposition's transport policy is still being determined and I would appreciate it if, at the appropriate time, the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation would leak the document and provide us with the same very good coverage he provided for us a few months ago in regard to our aviation policy. I believe that our policy will move towards making the ANL more commercial by changing it from a statutory authority to a company, initially with all of the shares being owned by the Commonwealth-similar to the position of Qantas at the present time, and similar to what we would propose when in government as a first stage with regard to Australian Airlines. After that we would determine the most appropriate way to develop a genuinely internationally competitive Australian flag shipping fleet, one that was competitive in its own right for both coastal and international trade, also what appropriate role there would be for an ANL in that final, competitive industry. Australia does need an internationally competitive coastal and international flag shipping industry. The previous speaker made the point that the invisibles that we fail to gain for this country in our overall balance of payments arrangements represent income that the nation desperately needs. Because of the Crawford incentives and initiatives, the percentage of Australian international cargo has increased slightly. I acknowledge that it still is very, very low. However, it happens to be higher than the figure achieved in the United States.

The credit for the impetus in the last three years for a more efficient Australian fleet, both domestic and international, rests with the Crawford incentives-initiated by the honourable member for Gwydir when Minister and introduced by the coalition Government of which he was a member. The Crawford incentives recognised that the capital cost of a ship was the single most important factor in total operating costs. Somewhere between 45 per cent and 50 per cent of the total cost is in capital. Therefore, as part of the Crawford initiative or incentive, for the first time a depreciation allowance was given, not just to coastal shipping but also overseas shipping carrying the Australian flag. As well, an investment allowance was allowed and depreciation could begin one year ahead of the actual delivery of the ship. That provided a tremendous boost to re-equipping the Australian fleet with more fuel-efficient, more operator-efficient ships. I understand that between 12 and 15 ships will be or have been built under that particular incentive. With the coming of the new ships, the manning levels also were to be addressed. These constitute about 15 per cent of the total cost of operating a ship. There is no doubt that in those ships that have resulted from the Crawford initiatives the manning level has been reduced to 25-30 per ship. In the meantime, of course, the rest of the world has moved on. I am referring here not to Third World countries, or flags of convenience, but to our competitors in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, which now have manning levels of 15-18. What is more important, those smaller crews are more productive, particularly in regard to maintenance and other onboard work. We are now, if anything, starting to fall behind again. The third significant factor in the cost of a ship, whether it be coastal or international, is the cost of bunker fuel, which represents about 20 per cent of the total. Australian bunker fuel costs twice that of our international competitors. That is a disgrace. The Government is not addressing the issue; it is making it worse by its continual increases, which are completely out of line with the situation in the rest of the world, in the price of bunker fuel.

That also raises a further question. What is to happen when the Crawford initiatives, the incentives of the previous coalition Government, finally run out, as they will when these 12-15 ships are built? The BHP Iron Pacific, which the honourable member for Grayndler mentioned, was of course one of those ships that were built under the policy of the previous coalition Government. The present Government did not introduce the Crawford incentives; it terminated them. It took away incentives designed to give our shipping a real chance to be more competitive. What the industry wants-the Minister knows it; I have heard him comment on it-is a three-year depreciation on new shipping, to allow it to continue to replace those ships with more fuel-efficient ones and achieve greater efficiency in manning-try to get lower, more flexible and more productive manning arrangements, so that some work is actually done by the crews. It is not just a matter of efficiency from an economic point of view. There is also the social view point. There is a problem of alcoholism on our ships, our coastal ships in particular. This was highlighted by the TNT Alltrans accident. I do commend the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation upon the action that he is taking in this regard. He is also aware of the manning problem, because of the Maritime Industry Development Committee which he has established. But I do question his ability to achieve any further success with manning, more particularly its productivity, without some form of incentive to encourage the building of new ships for Australia.

Our coastal shipping fares even worse in this situation. Because of its inefficiency, it has been reduced to carrying bulk cargoes, which cannot be carried in any other way, and to servicing Tasmania. Tasmania is, of course, a very important part of that responsibility. Unless our coastal shipping is made more competitive, it will be a burden to Australia, to all Australian taxpayers. Shore-based costs are a disgrace in the whole transport situation and they have an even greater impact on our coastal shipping than on our international shipping. The Minister has a tremendous opportunity to show his ability to achieve greater efficiency in our shipping, our flag shipping in particular, because the phosphate rock contracts are coming up for renewal. Those contracts, which are terminating, are costing Australian farmers millions and millions in unnecessary expenditure. It costs them $20-$25 a tonne more than it would if we had open, genuine, international shipping arrangements. The farmers are paying over two-thirds more freight for phosphate rock than they should-this is at a time when the Government is calling on all Australians to take the hard decisions, to make our exports more competitive! The Minister has an opportunity to show that he is doing something by opening up the shipping of our phosphate to the genuinely lowest international tenderer. I hope that an Australian company is successful, but it has to be done on a genuinely competitive basis. New Zealand woke up to that years ago and got out of the joint arrangement before 1980. If honourable members do not think that my views on the problem of the shore-based industries are enough to go on, I will quote what has been said by Mr Bolitho, the head of the Australian Shipping Commission, according to an Australian Associated Press report from Melbourne on 21 August:

Australian National Line (ANL) Chairman, Bill Bolitho, today warned the company's climb back to an efficient maritime transport operator was still under threat from outmoded and inflexible work practices. Mr Bolitho made his comments while announcing ANL had made a $19m net profit for the year to June 30 against $19.05m previously. He said the company had experienced its worst year on record for industrial disputes at its terminals. Terminals and stevedoring had contributed reduced results for the year with reviews of work practices and rosters at Port Botany and Webb Dock terminals causing major industrial disputes. If ANL is to continue its process of regeneration into an efficient Australian flag maritime transport operator, it is essential that further progress is made in eliminating the outmoded and inflexible work practices while continuing to earn sufficient profits.

Once again, the Minister has recognised this by creating a shore-based shipping cost task force, whose report indicates that overall the problem is that there is generally no incentive to be efficient, no penalty against inefficiency. More specifically, there is a lack of co-ordination between the different sectors on the waterfront-for example, truck queuing and restrictive work practices which result, for example, in our container-loading rate being about half that of any of our competitors.

There are also industrial disputes. I know that they are not dealt with in the report but they are a reality of the waterfront. Their incidence is four to five times higher on the waterfront than in the general work force. How about that? It is up to 10 times higher on occasion because of political strikes. These are not even industrial strikes. Shore-based costs represent between 50 and 70 per cent of the total door-to-door cost of transporting a product. That is a disgraceful percentage. If honourable members do not wish to take my word for it, I can refer them to a speech given very recently, on 15 September 1986, by Mr Colin Freeland, the Secretary of the Federal Department of Transport, on initiatives and maritime transport. He was addressing the biennial conference of the Association of Australian Port and Marine Authorities. Time does not permit me to enumerate the range of figures that he gave, but he also stated that port and related charges represented 20 per cent of total shore-based costs and that the authorities must develop more commercial attitudes, must accept overall responsibility for planning and, in some cases, must stop making charges on ships as a result of industrial disputes which are within their responsibility. Such practices are disgraceful.

I am pleased that the Government is about to establish a royal commission into grain handling. It will include an examination of the part played by state railways and bulk handling terminals. If one wants figures on industrial disputes, one can quote from an answer that the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation gave me- Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Darling)-Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may be permitted, Madam Deputy Speaker, I will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `House' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
(1) commends the Fraser-Anthony Government on the success of its policy of improving the efficiency of the Australian shipping industry by:
(a) the introduction of the Crawford Report incentives in relation to the purchase of Australian flag ships, and
(b) introducing the Australian Shipping Commission Amendment Bill 1982 to create a more commercially oriented Australian National Line;
(2) condemns the Government for:
(a) terminating the Crawford incentives;
(b) maintaining Australia's unenviable world record in 1985 of 21.54 per cent of all maritime strike insurance claims;
(c) failing to improve the loading efficiency for containers, grain and other bulk tonnage beyond the current half to two-thirds per hour rate of Australia's O.E.C.D. competitors, and
(d) allowing the plethora of restrictive and inefficient work practices, and union blackmail, to continue in the shore-based sector of the industry, and

(3) calls on the Government to initiate (a) a Royal Commission into the efficiency of the shore-based waterfront sector for liner cargoes similar to that about to commence for grain handling and (b) an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the future of Australian flag shipping'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this debate, seconding the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). Obviously as a seconder I support the motion moved by him and reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). It was very interesting to listen to the honourable member for Murray talking about shipping. We hear from him that the Opposition transport policy is still being determined. How convenient that is. The Opposition comes in here day after day and we hear about all these policies that are yet being determined. Let me tell the honourable member for Murray that, although the Opposition's policy is still being determined, there are aspects of his speech that will be in that policy. We can all be sure of that. We can be sure that the policy will enable foreign ships to carry Australian cargo around the Australian coast. We can also all be assured that it will be a sell-out to the multi-nationals and that the Australian National Line will be a political instrument once more.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Grayndler reminded us of the time when the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), now the Leader of the National Party, had responsibility for transport. The Opposition talks about what its policy is going to be. It had seven years of occupying the treasury bench to put its policy into effect and what did it leave: It left us with a bankrupt ANL. Since we have been in government we have done what the Opposition could never do. I might say that honourable members opposite are making much of the report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping and we all agree that it was a step in the right direction; but the Opposition did not legislate for the Crawford report. When we came into government we found that all the problems of the Australian shipping industry are a product of the neglect of that industry during the seven years that the Opposition had control of the treasury bench.

It was clear to us on assuming office that if the Government was to succeed in its efforts to improve the efficiency of Australian shipping, the Australian National Line had to be revitalised. By any measure, ANL is an important element of the shipping industry. It is one of the country's largest ship owners, it is one of the largest terminal operators, it is a major Australian operator in overseas liner trades, it operates coastal liner and bulk services, it is engaged in overseas bulk trades. When this Government took office in March 1983 it discovered that ANL, instead of being a driving force in the industry was nearly bankrupt. Years of mismanagement and neglect by successive conservative governments had reduced a once successful shipping operator to the point of near extinction.

The Minister for Transport, the Hon. Peter Morris, immediately set to work and produced a four-point package designed to revitalise ANL. This included measures to improve the Line's financial base, ANL's legislative charter was amended to give it commercial freedom and control. A new chairman and managing director were appointed as part of a management shake-up which brought into line executives with successful commercial track records. Greater union involvement and consultation were encouraged to ensure that ANL management and unions worked more as a team. Both ANL management and the unions responded to this initiative in a positive way. Management developed a rationalisation strategy, the first stage of which involved a 20 per cent reduction in head office staff. The sea-going unions agreed to manning reductions to improve ANL's efficiency.

By the end of 1983-84 the effects of the measures taken started to flow through into ANL's results. The operating profit in that year was $3.3m, a dramatic turnaround and improvement on the $22m of the previous year. Despite this achievement, ANL's recorded overall losses of $67.8m and this was due mainly to the need to recognise the inadequacy of previous depreciation policies which necessitated abnormal write-offs and the extensive use of off-balance sheet lease funding arrangements of prior years. In June 1985 further measures were taken to give ANL a financial base appropriate to a business of its size.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 1.45 p.m. In accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Peter Morris) agreed to:
That the time for discussion of Notice No. 1, General Business, be extended till 2 p.m..

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, in June 1985 further measures were taken to give ANL a financial base appropriate to a business of its size. Substantial progress has been made in implementing the revitalisation program. This involved difficult but necessary decisions which included the withdrawal from unprofitable services and the closure of uneconomic terminals. The termination of the Darwin service-I see the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) is here to respond to that-and the replacement of the Empress of Australia on the Bass Strait ferry service mean that ANL is now not receiving any operating subsidy from government.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that the Federal Government provided $26m as a grant to the Tasmanian Government; that disproves the claim that we are anti-Tasmania. We provided a $26m grant to Tasmania for the purchase of the Abel Tasman, the new Bass Strait ferry. ANL has introduced newer, more efficient tonnage, whenever this has been commercially viable. It introduced the modern cellular container vessel Australian Trader into the trans-Tasman service, and rebuilt the bulk carrier Selwyn Range, now renamed the River Torrens, to improve the efficiencies of ANL's bulk cargo handling. It is now introducing the Australian Advance into the East Asia trades to replace two older fuel-inefficient vessels. Such steps would not have been possible without the co-operation and goodwill shown by the sea-going unions. We should all commend their commitment to ANL and the contribution they have made to ANL turnround in performance that we have witnessed over the last three years.

There has been a sizable turnround. In 1982-83 ANL reported an operating loss of $18.8m. By 1983-84 the loss had reversed and a modest operating profit of $3.3m was recorded. By 1984-85 operating profit leapt to $41.4m. By 1985-86 preliminary results indicated that the line has been able to maintain its improved performance, recording an operating profit of $38.2m. This return to profitability has meant that ANL has resumed paying dividends for the first time since 1969. It contributed $5m to the public coffers from its 1984-85 profit. The Commission has recommended that a further $5m dividend be paid on 1985-86 profits. More than that, ANL has resumed paying income tax. An amount of $8m is expected to be paid in income tax on 1985-86 profits, the first time such payments have been made since 1974. All that is happening at a time when its Conference competitors are recording worsening financial positions or even going bankrupt due to world shipping depression and intense competition.

In three short years ANL has been turned from a bankrupt enterprise into one making consistent profit, paying dividends and income tax. That ANL result shows that given the right degree of commitment on the part of government, management and employees, public enterprise can be successful despite the views and efforts of the Opposition which attempts to dispose of public enterprise. In spite of the achievements of the last three years ANL still has a long way to go. It has not completely escaped the legacy of the past. It has accumulated losses of some $100m and its fleet is aging. However, we can be confident that the new ANL is well placed to tackle the problems ahead.

Let me now turn to the ill-informed criticisms of coastal shipping on which the Opposition has based its proposal to repeal the coastal trade provisions of the Navigation Act and open up the coast to foreigners. This is a recipe for disaster, reversing the bipartisan policy of the past 60 years that recognised coastal shipping as part of the domestic transport task which should be performed by Australians. The Opposition policies seek an easy, quick, slick solution but provide no real answer to an issue which requires hard work, effort and foresight. The Government's policy is to ensure that all coastal trade is carried in Australian-controlled and crewed vessels. However, the Government's policy is also to tackle the real issue of improving the efficiency of Australian shipping by sensible, practical means.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has been actively pursuing this aspect. Australia's policy on coastal shipping is not unique and is followed by many other important trading nations. If we move back this national boundary, what would the Opposition want to do next? It would want to import cheap foreign labour to work on our ports, on our farms, in our mines or factories or run our trains. It should be totally unacceptable even to the Opposition to single out coastal shipping treatment different from that given to other domestic industries and incur further foreign payments for shipping services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I think the fact that we are about to build a power station in Darwin to be fuelled by coal when we have found that it was cheaper to bring coal from the west coast of the United States of America than to ship it around the coast from Queensland says it all about coastal shipping in Australia. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) raised a question in this House earlier in the week concerning certain solitary practices which might be used to relieve tension and pain. The motion before us today seems to have been inspired by advice similar to that handed out by the Leichhardt Women's Health Centre, since it is transparently designed to relieve current Government pain by self-congratulatory manipulation. I shall not use the short word for it since Madam Speaker has advised that that word is not parliamentary, but that is what the first part of this motion is.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have no great quarrel with the second part of the motion and I support and second the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Considering the odds, there is no doubt that the Chairman of the Australian National Line, Captain Bill Bolitho, and chief executive Max Moore-Wilton, have achieved a considerable turnaround in the fortunes of ANL. Indeed, Max Moore-Wilton seems to be one of the more effective of the bureaucratic troubleshooters. That has not been without the $160m-plus assistance of the taxpayer and it has been helped by the disentanglement rather than the intervention of government which makes the first part of the motion look a little extraneous.

The facts are that this Government did little more than implement some of the recommendations of the Crawford Committee on Revital- isation of Australian Shipping, set up by the former Transport Minister, Ralph Hunt, inject large doses of taxpayers' funds and give the management a freer reign to do what had to be done. That has involved selling off ships, paying off excess managerial staff and withdrawing from shipping routes. Although I sincerely regret that that process involved the loss of the Darwin-east coast shipping service, I was more amused than angry to note my Labor predecessor's words during debate on the Shipping Commission Bill in this House in November 1983, that a return to coalition government would mean the loss to the Northern Territory of both that shipping service and of the north-south rail link.

I do not propose to spend time mourning the broken promises of this Government on transport in the Territory. It would take all day. Rather I focus on the inactivity of the great Labor mediators and conciliators of this Government in an area that Opposition members have been raising for years but that the Government seems to have only just discovered. It is an area which is topical and which is vital to the future of ANL, namely, work practices. Of all areas of Australian industry and commerce, national shipping has suffered most from the restrictive work practices both on and off-shore of the various waterside and shipboard unions of this country. Indeed, the history of militancy and blackmail is legend. Australian seamen have priced themselves out of work; Australian waterside workers have driven off trading partners; Australian opportunity has been lost for ever.

It will take all the combined skills of Captain Bolitho and Mr Moore-Wilton to recover some ground, or should I say, some sea, for Australian shipping after the saboteur efforts of union bosses. I am conscious that ANL competes in an over-supplied market, must strive against countries that protect and subsidise their shipping lines and must operate in competition with countries that pay much lower wages to crews and operate with lower manning levels. But this should act only as incentive to Australian crews and waterside workers to restrain their avarice and lift their productivity. I am also conscious that shipping companies that operate into Australia relatively and frequently have caved in to union demands at great cost to Australian shipping, which must ply our ports week in and week out. These are realities but there are others such as the 19,000 kilometres of coastline and a billion-plus tonnes of domestic freight to be moved along it. Then there is the reality of 500 ships in the import-export trade and the fact that Australian ships carry just 3 per cent of that trade.

The Whitlam Government interference-in particular, the disastrous purchase of two bulk carriers during the stewardship of Labor Transport Minister Jones, irresolute management and poor accounting procedures-has contributed to Australia's lost opportunities, but most damaging and most devastating to Australia's chances as a maritime nation have been the naked opportunism and sheer pig-headedness of union bosses. I will give a few recent examples. We have seen the calculated victimisation of the Columbus Line and other shipping companies by the Seamen's Union. The great irony is that the union wants Columbus to employ Australian crews, when European operators estimate that it would cost a cool $1m a year per ship to meet the manning levels and other demands of the union.

We watched in awe the Gilbertian comedy of near mutiny from the Federated Marine Stewards and Pantrymen's Association over the new Tasmanian ferry and the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers action in forcing unnecessary repairs on ships that had passed inspection; it has been detailed in this House and in diplomatic protests. So has the dispute over who should man the anchor and mooring line winch on the River Boyne, which was commissioned to cart bauxite from Weipa to Gladstone.

Then there was the Australian Foremen Stevedores Association battle in Sydney and Melbourne with ANL which cost around $1.4m a day and held up 70 ships, and all because the union discovered that ANL had come to an agreement with some electricians on a different roster system. Perhaps on an even pettier level were the months of delay before ANL's new ship River Torrens could get under way while unions demanded, amongst other things, an additional trainee wiper to the already generous 31-man crew-a trainee wiper!

It is reported that work practices such as the nick system, employing one man to work while another nicks off, are still widely in use in Australian ports. It sounds like the wattle bag at Robe River. The sizes of gangs and sling loads on the dockside have remained unchanged, despite containerisation and other modern techniques of cargo handling. The bill for loading and unloading a single container is the same as that for sending that container by rail from Sydney to Melbourne. ANL's container rate, Australia to Hong Kong, is $2,200 or more compared with its competitors' $1,500 or less. Dumb barges are vigorously opposed by union leadership. Australian crews cost $100,000 a berth, according to Captain Bolitho.

I will divert for a moment to discuss Christmas Island where the Navigation Act affords ANL a monopoly on phosphate shipments to Australia. When Whitlam Minister Jones gave ANL the monopoly, the price climbed immediately by $6 to $10 a tonne. Today it is around $33 while a tonne of phosphate to Malaysia on a rival ship comes out at around $15. It seems that Christmas Island will close down altogether, in part due to the high cost monopoly, and if this Government keeps up its act Australia could share the Christmas Island fate, fulfilling the world champion travel allowance Treasurer's predication of banana republicanism.

The subject of my next point has come up three times in three years. The first time, in 1984, the taxpayer was told that this Government had given $90m of his money to ANL. The second time, in 1985, the taxpayer was told a further $70m had gone towards continued subsidisation. Now, the third time, while we are all very relieved not to be coughing up more money, it seems a little premature for self-congratulation after a one in three win, not enough for any sporting trophy.

This Government prides itself on its ability to negotiate and reach consensus on industrial relations matters. It would be better employed using these self-declared talents to assist ANL and the Australian shipping industry to teach Australian maritime and waterside unions some realities, rather than wasting our time by publicly indulging in such a distasteful and solitary pastime as is evidenced by this motion. I support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short time left to me I would like to refute completely all the garbage that came from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). He has a long history of bashing trade union movements and this is no exception.
—He hates workers.
—As my colleague said, he hates workers; it is as simple as that.

—Order! It is now 2 p.m. In accordance with standing order 104 as amended for this session, the time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The honourable member for Grey will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next day of sitting.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the combined effects of two of his great achievements-the youth traineeship scheme and the fringe benefits tax. As the Prime Minister knows, the youth traineeship scheme provides a grant of $1,000 to employers if they take on a young trainee under the scheme. Is he also aware that rural employers, on the most conservative calculations possible, will have to pay over $1,100 in fringe benefits tax on board and lodging of the employee and other benefits provided which are taxable? Can the Prime Minister suggest any reason at all why an employer should take up the Government's generous offer of $1,000 when the fringe benefits tax will cost him over $1,100 to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for raising, at the outset of today's Question Time, the issue of the fringe benefits tax. In regard to his question about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on employers who take on trainees, I will undertake to obtain advice on the potential impact of the tax in that area and to so advise him. I do not pretend to be able to give an off the cuff answer on that technical question. But I assert that I am in a position to further expose the hypocrisy of the Opposition in regard to the whole question of the fringe benefits tax. The reason that I was a little late in getting here was that I have had the great pleasure of watching a tape of the interview of the Leader of the Opposition-who is absent-by Richard Carleton, which took place last night on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation show, regarding the fringe benefits tax and related issues. If ever one has seen a Leader of the Opposition who is on his way out, one saw him in that interview. It is not surprising, because the Leader of the Opposition typifies the position of the Opposition as a whole. It simply does not know where it is on this issue of fringe benefits tax. Let us nail the Leader of the Opposition on this matter. This morning, in repeating what he had said last night, he stated: `We will throw it out lock, stock and barrel'.
—Hear, hear!

—The honourable member interjects: `Hear, hear'. That is the current position of the Leader of the Opposition. Perhaps he will explain what particular part of the road to Damascus he was on when he saw the light. Last year he explained his position in light of the still unrecanted position of the re-elected Federal Leader of the Liberal Party. I remind the House-I have brought it to its attention before-so that the House and the people of Australia have it clearly on the record, what the position of the Federal Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Valder, is on the question of the fringe benefits tax, because the Leader of the Opposition endorsed this position. Mr Valder, in July last year, in referring to the attack by the Treasurer on behalf of this Government on fringe benefits, stated:

ANSWER.PARA: I think again to reverse the whole disease-
that is what he was talking about; the organisational leader of the Liberal Party in this country was talking about the whole disease of the fringe benefits system. He continued:

. . . I think Paul Keating is being very foolish and taking a massive risk in attempting to reverse that in one stroke. But if one attempted to reverse that in a series of strokes over three or four years, then I think it could be done and I've got to say-
this is the organisational leader of the Liberal Party in this country; he has never recanted from this position-
I think that is the fair and just thing in this country-
that is, to wipe out the whole disease of fringe benefits. He went on to say:
and it is going to take, I imagine, every bit of a decade to reverse the trends of the past decade or two. But the longer we leave it, the harder it is going to be.
It was then put to him: `Well, Labor has bitten the bullet'. What did the organisational leader of the Liberal Party say? He said:

Well, that is why I would like to see them do the very hard things that they are going to get into trouble about, because electorally that is the fact of the matter. They are not easy to do. So I have said many times-
and I ask members of this House and every member of the Australian public to savour the philosophy, the character and the decency of the Liberal Party-
you know, let the Labor Party get on implementing the more necessary, but perhaps less popular parts of our policy.

In other words, Mr Valder, the Federal President of the Liberal Party, was saying: `It is our policy to wipe out the disease of fringe benefits. Let the Labor Party implement our policies, the Liberal Party policies, and let us hope they get them into place and promptly lose office'. He said: `I think that would be a very good scenario, don't you?'. So the organisational head of the Liberal Party in this country was saying that fringe benefits had become a disease and should be wiped out. He said: `Paul Keating has been foolish to attempt to do it in one bold strike. But let Keating and the Labor Party wipe out the fringe benefits. Let them cop the electoral flak. We will return to office and leave the fringe benefits tax in place'. What did the Leader of the Opposition say about that exposition by the organisational wing of the Liberal Party? He said:
There are no easy options on cutting government spending . . . I recognise the realities of how hard it is to cut government spending.
This is what he said about Mr Valder's statement:

. . . what Mr Valder said on fringe benefits was not all that different from what a number of us have said . . . if you're able to cut the top marginal rate of personal income tax, then it's fair in that context and that context alone, to do something about fringe benefits . . .

Let there be no doubt about the hypocrisy of this pack opposite. The organisational head of the Liberal Party has said that fringe benefits are a disease in this country, that they should be wiped out, and that it hoped that this Government would proceed with the legislation to wipe them out. He said that that was the policy of the Liberal Party. Very shortly after that, John Howard said: `I agree with him, and if you have this cut in marginal rates', which we have, `then there should be a fringe benefits tax'. But what does Honest John do now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister should use the honourable member's correct title.

—What does the temporary Leader of the Opposition say? Having said that Mr Valder was right, that it was the Liberal Party's policy, to wipe fringe benefits out, under pressure he now says: `We will wipe out the legislation lock, stock and barrel'. If ever there has been revealed a party bereft of principle, reeking of hypocrisy, it is the Liberal Party on the question of the fringe benefits tax.

—My question is also directed to the Prime Minister, I ask whether the Prime Minister's attention has been drawn to recent criticisms of the Government's taxation and Budget policies. If so, does the Prime Minister propose to take any action in these areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perfectly clear that this Government's Budget policy-its total macro- economic policy-is appropriate to the circumstances which have been imposed upon this country by the force of external circumstances; a fact which is acknowledged by virtually every commentator in this country, and was certainly acknowledged by Moody's Investor Services Inc. when it made the recent adjustment to our credit rating. So there is absolutely no need for any change in the fiscal policy of this Government, nor will there be. Most of the criticism of the Government's fiscal policy has come from one noisy and increasingly disreputable source, and that is the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is always willing, able and happy to explain its policies to the community. However, the Leader of the Opposition steadfastly refuses to explain where the money would come from to finance his armful of tax and spending promises. Let us remember what the Leader of the Opposition has promised. He has promised to dismantle Labor's tax reforms, to reduce the overall tax burden through flatter taxes and income splitting, and to reform the assets test.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—They do not worry me, Madam Speaker. The Leader of the Opposition has promised also to have a balanced Budget in three years. When we do the simple arithmetic on the hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition, he turns out to have a $10 billion-plus credibility gap. He will never be able to overcome that credibility gap. Before the honourable member for Bennelong became Leader of the Opposition, he told others that when they make criticism of government fiscal policies-these are his exact words-they have to `make specific suggestions as to where the cuts might be made'. Those words will come back to haunt him.

ANSWER.PARA: The trouble ultimately with this Opposition, and particularly with its Leader, is that it crucially and critically underestimates the intelligence and perspicacity of the Australian electorate. It will not be able to get away with this insult to the intelligence of the Australian electorate, and during every day, week and month between now and the next election it will be driven further and further into the ground. It will then come to the realisation that until it adopts a position of principle on matters of economic debate it will perpetually inhabit the opposition benches of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Treasurer. In the light of one of the principles enunciated by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister before the Tax Summit, and the Treasurer's awareness, no doubt, that persons living in remote locations, whether on farms or at mines, and even those in the police force, so that they might properly do their jobs, are to be subject to fringe benefits tax, will he explain to the House the difference between that tax responsibility and the tax liability on his own entitlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should have thought that the differences were obvious. There is a clear division in the law between the tax treatment of living away from home allowances, travelling allowances and employer-provided housing. In the case of members of the Parliament who have residences in Canberra, there is no employer-provided housing. There were some 4 per cent loans at the taxpayers' expense, but beyond that there was and is no employer-provided housing. Members' entitlements, including electorate allowances and Ministers' allowances of office, will now for the first time be taxed under substantiation-not the fringe benefits tax but the related measure of substantiation. That will require a member or a Minister to substantiate what has been expended truly in terms of electorate costs and the electorate allowance, and also in terms of the ministerial allowance of office.

ANSWER.PARA: Much of the ministerial allowance of office was spent in the past on entertainment, and that is no longer a deduction that is allowable in the tax system. To the extent that that cannot be substantiated, Ministers will need to pay the tax on it. That is why it is reasonable to make the assumption that the after-tax income of most Ministers will probably fall between 15 per cent and 25 per cent-a very great deal indeed. Most members on the back benches will probably see their income diminish somewhat owing to the fact that they may not be in a position to substantiate all expenditures within their electorate allowance. The tax treatment across income groups is entirely the same.

In respect of the travelling allowance, there is no requirement of substantiation. This has not generally been seen as an area of abuse and the deduction has been generally extended in the tax system where the travelling allowance has been expended for its purpose. The tax treatment of these three areas across various income groups is entirely consistent with my position or that of any other member.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. What would have been the impact on tax avoidance and tax abuse had the taxation laws which existed prior to the introduction of the fringe benefits tax prevailed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be a dramatic increase in the incidence of cost to the tax system by the failure of the existing provisions, section 26 (e), to deal with the problem of fringe benefits. It is interesting to note what the shadow Treasurer said on Mike Carlton's program on 2GB this very day when asked about fringe benefits. The transcript reads:

ANSWER.PARA: Reporter: But there will still be some form of taxation on fringe benefits?
Jim: Well there was under the old system, it just wasn't well policed.
Reporter: But how are you going to police it under this new system that you people are going to introduce?
Jim: Well, quite simply. That if you work out, in a proper management sense, exactly how you prevent the gross abuses, you can do it administratively.

In other words, the response to the question, `Under this new system, what are you going to do?', is `Well, accepting the new system, quite simply, if you work it out properly to prevent abuses, you can do it administratively.' Another part of the transcript reads:

Jim: We don't have a hundred per cent foolproof system of clamping down all abuses. We just believe that by tackling the biggest abuses in a sensible way, and maybe that's five per cent, ten per cent of the total, but what you do not do is do what Keating has done . . .
The interview continues:
Reporter: What is the policy, how would it be done?

Jim: What I've said is, that under the original law, there was a capacity, administratively, if people had wanted to work it out properly in a properly controlled management situation to crack down on the rorts and you had to do that.
Reporter: Under that system the payment of tax was very easily avoided.
Jim: Well nobody really tried to stop it sufficiently with sufficient force and they didn't look at it in a proper management sense.
So he is saying that they will look at it in a proper management sense, they will do it under the old law. A later passage reads:
Reporter: How would you ensure that those benefits would be paid, the tax on those benefits would be paid?
Jim: Well, I think that's a fairly simple management problem to solve.

In other words, we are going to have a fringe benefits tax. It will be under a new system. It will be a management system under the old law, but although the old law was not being policed, it will be under the Opposition if it forms a government. This ties in with what the Leader of the National Party said this morning on the steps of Parliament House. He said:
26 (e) will remain and there has never been any suggestion that it will go.
He was asked whether any fringe benefit should be taxed and he replied:
Well there is already an application of some fringe benefits tax by the Tax Commissioner under 26 (e). That is the system that has continued and we have not recommended any change to that.

So the Leader of the National Party is saying that section 26 (e) stays and the shadow Treasurer is saying they will make it work; it did not work in the past or it was not policed but they will police it and make it work in a management sense. Last night, on the Carleton-WalshReport, the Leader of the Opposition said:
Richard, look, my answer to you is that under our Administration tax avoidance rorts will not be permitted. They will be effectively legislated against.
The interview continued:
Richard Carleton: How?

Mr Howard: Well, there are a variety of ways. There were a variety of ways under the law that existed until quite recently. And I was responsible for bringing in a general anti-tax avoidance provision for the Income Tax Act.

In other words, rorts will be legislated against. That will be done under the old law, but it will be administratively changed to give it a management complexion and make it administratively feasible. As I indicated in the Parliament yesterday, the only changes that could be made to section 26 (e) to make it available for collection under the income tax system is if it is changed so that the computation and withholding is done weekly on every individual. That is the huge administrative burden that made section 26 (e) not a workable proposition in the Government's view and why it went to a more general across the board fringe benefits tax collected on a quarterly basis. So here we have the shadow Treasurer this very day saying-not repudiating-that the Opposition will not have a new system but quite simply it will be doing it to prevent gross abuses; it will be tackling the biggest abuses in a sensible way, there will be a capacity administratively and it will do it in a controlled management way. Nobody has tried to do that in the past, but it says: `We will do it'. Last night the Leader of the Opposition said: `We will legislate to do it'. When is the Opposition going to come clean on fringe benefits and tell the public the truth? When it says it will not have the Hawke fringe benefits tax or the Keating fringe benefits tax, it really means that it will have the Howard-Carlton fringe benefits tax, which will be an administrative nightmare on employers in this country, a far greater burden than the fringe benefits tax. When will the Opposition end its duplicity and tell the truth and come clean with the Australian public for the first time in three and a half years?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer and relates to the fringe benefits tax which we are going to throw out lock, stock and barrel; make no mistake about that. Is the Treasurer aware that the Australian Taxation Office has advised the National Farmers Federation that, if a family farm company has claimed the full shire rates as a deduction from income for tax purposes up until 30 June 1986, the family living in the farm house will be subjected to the fringe benefits tax on the assessed rental value of the house? Since this advice conflicts with the assurances that the Treasurer and other Ministers have given, that family members living in company owned farm houses will not be subjected to the FBT, will the Treasurer intervene to resolve the confusion being generated as a result of his statements and the advice from the Taxation Office? Will he also give an assurance, since there is no possible chance of this being abolished until there is a change of government, that he will endeavour to remove the administrative nightmare that is driving employers and employees up the pole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If employers were calculating the benefit to each individual employee and withholding weekly and remitting weekly, can honourable members imagine the burden then on employers compared with the administrative efficiency of the current withholding tax? So there is no point in the coalition going on about why section 26(e) is there. It would not allow section 26(e) to work. The shadow Treasurer has admitted today that his Government never let section 26(e) work effectively, and were it to amend section 26(e) to calculate, withhold and remit to the Taxation Office weekly, the burden would be enormous. Let us make that very clear.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the substance of the question, the point I have made to the Deputy Leader of the National Party on a couple of occasions is that there is no fringe benefits tax payable in respect of the family farm house, but if indeed that farm house were the subject of deductions if it had been owned by a company, the fringe benefits tax would apply to it. Let me make this clear: No other person in the economy is entitled to deduct the costs of his or her home in the tax system, and to the extent that a farmer uses a family company to make the deduction, he has to accept the fact that in claiming the business deduction the fringe benefits tax will apply. The honourable member mentioned a Taxation Office ruling. I will inquire about that and certainly furnish him with an answer.

But more generally about the issue of fringe benefits I make this point: I think it is important at this point in this debate to be clear what the equitable purpose of fringe benefits taxation is. Let me give this example. This is a quite realistic salary package for an executive in the middle to upper management range with a salary of $45,000; representative allowance, $3,000; superannuation, $6,000; motor vehicle lease for a Toyota Cressida, $5,800; motor vehicle maintenance, running costs, registration and insurance, $1,900; hostess allowance, $4,000; home telephone, $300; low interest loan, $8,850; school fees, $3,000; and holiday travel, $3,000. I repeat that that is for an executive in middle to upper management.

While only $45,000 of this package is paid in the form of salary, an employee who received only a salary would have to be paid $115,125 in order to receive the same after tax benefit. Under the former Government's tax system only $17,346 would have to have been collected on this income of $115,000, which is an average tax rate of about 15 per cent. This is the same average tax rate as would have been faced by a taxpayer receiving all of his remuneration in taxable form of only $11,500; that is, the former Government's tax system gave the same average rate to a $115,000 beneficiary of tax avoidance as it did to a taxpayer on a money income of only $11,500. There is no equity in such a system.

The example I have cited is typical in this area of middle management. The former Government was well aware of such examples and it deliberately chose to do nothing about them. But we see now that the Leader of the Opposition has been forced, by the honesty and courage of this Government, to admit to the Australian public that as Treasurer in the former Government he presided over such a discriminatory and inequitable tax system. So the fact is that this is the clear inequity which is involved here: The same average rate for someone paying $11,500 as someone with a benefit of $115,000, an average rate of 15 per cent with a benefit of $115,000 while paying a salary of only $45,000. That is why the fringe benefit is there.

When the Opposition is asked about how it will handle the tax in respect of the representative allowance, or the motor vehicle lease, or the motor vehicle maintenance allowance, or the hostess allowance, or the home telephone, or the low interest loan, or the school fees or the holiday travel it must have an answer. The Opposition cannot say: `We are going to permit this abuse to continue'. It cannot say: `We are going to throw it out lock, stock and barrel and we will put nothing in its place'. That is why we are saying that we cannot leave these fringe benefits untaxed and that is why the shadow Treasurer this morning said on radio that the Opposition will tax it by an amended section 26 (e). That is why the Leader of the National Party said: `We will keep section 26 (e)'. That is why the Leader of the Opposition has said the Opposition will legislate a change to make the rules effective. If that is not abuse, what is? If the Opposition is to remove these abuses, is it any wonder the shadow Treasurer has had to admit on radio today that the Opposition will make it work administratively under the sections of the old law?

However, there can be no equity and no justice when a low income person on $11,500 pays the same average rate of tax as someone with $115,000 of benefits. While this Government is in office it will fight for that equity and it will stand up around this country and say to the average Australian: `You won't have to carry the burden of these people who have urged this upon you for years. You will not have to carry the burden which has been unfairly placed upon you. If there is a coalition government again, remember the burden it saddled you with. Remember the tax changes you received from this Government and weigh the justice of the Labor Party's taxation policies against the unfair, inequitable and unjust policies of the coalition'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to reunions of families of whom some members have had to remain in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Madam Speaker, I preface my question by acknowledging what you personally and members of your delegation to the Soviet Union earlier this year have done in bringing the Soviet authorities' attention to some names of persons seeking exit visas. Is the Prime Minister in a position to report to the House on the progress of efforts by various Ministers, including the Minister for Foreign Affairs and himself, to persuade the Soviet authorities to grant exit visas for particular members of divided families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his question. I think all members of this House will agree that family reunion remains an important and sensitive issue in bilateral relations between Australia and a number of eastern European countries. With varying degrees of success our missions regularly present lists of outstanding family reunion cases to the foreign ministries of east European countries to which we are accredited. Since coming to power the Government has pursued a policy of regular, high level approaches to the Soviet authorities on this matter. I personally raised this matter with the Soviet Ambassador and a number of other Ministers have assisted in making representations at various levels on appropriate occasions. As the honourable member for Kingston indicated, Madam Speaker, you also raised the question at a high level during your recent visit to the Soviet Union as leader of a parliamentary delegation to that country. In particular, my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs has been absolutely tireless in his pursuit of aiming to reunite families concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the House that Soviet authorities recently notified the Australian Ambassador in Moscow that our various lists of Soviet cases had been reviewed recently and a number had been resolved, including two that I know are of interest to the honourable member for Kingston. Although other cases remain unresolved, the Soviet decision represents some progress and it is to be welcomed on that score. We will, of course, persist in our efforts to resolve remaining cases through quiet diplomacy which we consider has proved to be the most practical means of achieving positive results.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister would be aware that the statement from yesterday's conference between government, business and union organisations that discussed work practices made no reference to techniques of profit sharing and equity participation. Does the Government believe such methods are appropriate mechanisms to distribute wealth to workers? If so, will the Government introduce appropriate amendments to the taxation legislation so as to remove taxation impediments to those companies and workers wishing to include such schemes as part of their remuneration package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lyons for his question. The honourable member, as distinct from some of his colleagues, has always, in my judgment, taken a very responsible and constructive approach to his consideration of industrial relations. I know that he has more difference with many of his colleagues than he does with me in this area. The meeting yesterday was very positive and constructive. I wish on behalf of the Government, and I would think the people of Australia, to congratulate the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions for facing up to a basic question which must be resolved in this country; that is, how are we on all fronts going to ensure that Australian manufacturing industry becomes more competitive both against imports and in regard to expanding our exports of manufactured goods? When we consider this issue we must understand that these practices have to be addressed in enterprises not only within the manufacturing sector but also economy-wide because the efficiency of firms and enterprises outside of the manufacturing sector will, of themselves, have some influence upon the competitive capacity of manufacturing industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Those gathered in Melbourne yesterday, in what I think was properly described by the Australian today as an historic outcome, did not pretend that they had addressed themselves exhaustively to every issue which is relevant. I concede directly to the honourable member that the questions he raised have a relevance in this whole matter. I acknowledge that in some enterprises in this country schemes, which are related to the sorts of considerations that he has raised, are operating successfully. I would regard it as appropriate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—The disappearing member for Wentworth. His capacity is so good.
—Order! I invite the Prime Minister to continue his answer.
—He has counted the numbers in Wentworth and he is chickening out before he faces preselection.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister ignored your very proper instruction based on the grounds that you have put down earlier in this House. If he wants to play it personal, we will talk about Bryce and his trips to Japan.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I call the Prime Minister.

—I would hope that when the detailed discussions flowing from the Melbourne meeting take place-that is, the discussions at the sector, the enterprise and the plant level-if the parties involved want to address those issues in the whole range of matters which are relevant to getting the best sort of working practices, I hope they will do so. Finally, I go to the honourable member's question whether, if the practices which he suggests were to become attractive to both employers and employees, some consideration would be given to them in the tax field. That is a hypothetical question but I say this: If we had approaches from industry in the light of some extension of that practice we would be prepared to consider them, and I say that without prejudice. I conclude by again thanking the honourable member for his question which I regard as a constructive contribution to this important area.
—Will the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment advise the House of progress on the national rainforest conservation program?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. On 3 October at Minnamurra Falls, near Wollongong, I shall be launching, with Bob Carr the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, the New South Wales section of the national rainforest conservation program. It will take place in the electorate of Throsby the member for which is one of the Parliament's leading environmentalists and a noted rainforest devotee. It will also be near the electorate of the honourable member for Macarthur and that of the Minister for Housing and Construction who is a former shadow Minister for the Environment. As honourable members would know, a few months ago Cabinet approved some $22.5m--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question asked by the honourable member for Throsby is out of order as it is similar to question No. 4681 on page 8874 of the Notice Paper.
—I do not have a copy of the question in front of me. Would the honour- able member repeat his question?
—The question was: Can the Minister advise the House of progress on conservation in New South Wales?
—The honourable member has asked the question that is on the Notice Paper, but it is his question that is on the Notice Paper; so it is quite in order.

—As the House knows, Cabinet approved some $22.5m over three years, and $7m will be spent this year. The program will be implemented in co-operation with the States and Territories, and includes a survey to identify rainforest areas of high conservation significance, assistance to the States for acquisition of privately owned rainforests, assistance to the States for acquisition for leasing of land for planting purposes, assistance to the States for the planning and management of rainforests, and a study of tourism as a potential for rainforest areas. All honourable members have been invited to come to Wollongong on that date. I take this opportunity to congratulate New South Wales on its initiative in taking up the Commonwealth's offer very quickly so we can get ahead with this program. A few weeks past that date I hope to be able to do the same in Victoria. I am hoping that the Tasmanian and Queensland governments will also take up the offer, because there is some very generous funding available if they take it up quickly.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I noted in the Treasurer's response, where he gave an illustration of a typical pay packet for a middle executive, a substantial amount paid for superannuation. How does the Prime Minister plan to replace the multi-billion dollar tax loss which will occur as a consequence of tax deductible superannuation contributions replacing what would otherwise have been paid as normal wage and salary increases?

—To the extent that the question from the honourable member goes to how this Government will conduct the total budgetary and fiscal policy of this country, I simply say that if he would like to compare the performance of this Government in this area with those of his predecessors, he will find that we have demonstrated an unrivalled capacity to match the proper expenditure requirements of this country with the necessary revenue-raising measures. In that process we have done two things: We have significantly reduced expenditures in areas where we thought they could no longer be justified, and at the same time, with a review of our revenue base, we have brought down the deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product from something like the 5 per cent that we inherited to less than 2 per cent. In other words, we have an unparalleled record of being able to make the necessary decisions on both the expenditure and the revenue side of the Budget formulation process. I assure the honourable member that in the very many years ahead, when this country continues to give us the responsibility for budgetary formulation, we will continue to show the expertise and the responsibility which has characterised this Government's discharge of budgetary responsibility in its first four years of office.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Following his launching of the Australian made campaign, what has been the response of the business sector to the campaign to date?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. It is relevant to a question that was asked of me yesterday by the honourable member for Page. I am pleased to say to the House that the Advance Australia Foundation, which is providing, as I said yesterday, the infrastructure for the campaign, advises that already between 60 and 70 new licensees have signed up. Two major department store retailers have already decided to back the campaign. The first week of advertising has been completed and this has been followed by a pause in the television advertising while logos are being attached to Australian made products. A new round of television advertising aimed at the Christmas shopping period will commence in early November. Yesterday, the honourable member for Page asked me whether the Advance Australia Foundation will moderate its $200 minimum licence fee. I am pleased to say that I am informed that in around 900 phone calls to the Foundation, only about half a dozen expressed concern about the minimum licence fee. Of those, I am informed, most were satisfied once the purpose of the fee was explained to them. The Foundation has arranged, in a couple of cases, for the $200 to be paid by instalments. I will today provide this information and the surrounding details in a letter to the honourable member for Page.

—Did the Minister for Health or his Department issue written or verbal instructions, or both, to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee when submitting a list of drugs for that Committee's June meeting which resulted in the deletion of 45 commonly prescribed items? If so, what was the nature of the instructions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out in the House yesterday during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, I wrote to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee requesting it to give consideration on health grounds to certain delistings. I made it quite specific in the letter, which I tabled in the House yesterday, that that request was on health grounds. I will repeat the letter for the benefit of the honourable member. My request to the Chairman of the PBAC was:

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, I ask that at your June meeting you review some benefit items with a view to determining, on health grounds, whether their listing is justified. The Department will be preparing a submission to the Committee which will include a list of items for review.

Of course, the Department prepared a submission which it forwarded to the PBAC. The remarks that the honourable member made yesterday impugned the integrity of the membership of the PBAC. I, as Minister, asked the PBAC to give consideration to those issues on health grounds. Their response came back to me, in which they justified the deletions on health grounds. Nor, of course, is this an unusual procedure.
