This fits in with current practices such as the overtime barrier which distinguish these positions from lower level positions. Instead there will be access to a grievance review under the Merit Protection and Review Agency, which will have the power to recommend the annulment of the promotion by the Secretary if it finds that proper procedures have not been followed, or the decision has been discriminatory or one of patronage. The relevant provisions defining these circumstances will be strengthened.

For grades below this level appeals processes will be significantly streamlined. Promotion appeal committees will be able to disregard frivolous or vexatious appeals, to undertake a level of inquiry appropriate to each case and to require parties to submit documentation by a specified time. The appeal period will be reduced, and the right of appeal will be limited to those who had originally applied for the job. Currently the appeal system acts more as a dual selection system, with appeals available to all lower ranked officers whether or not they applied for the position involved.

Greater use, at first for a trial period of 12 months, will be made of joint selection committees chaired by nominees of the Merit Protection and Review Agency for bulk promotions. There will be no appeals against promotions where decisions are unanimous and where the Secretary accepts the advice of these committees.

The definition of efficiency in the Public Service Act will be broadened to allow managers to take into account the potential of staff for future development, and their capability to perform a variety of jobs at the same level when deciding on promotions. This will enable more realistic promotion decisions, and greater management flexibility in the deployment of staff. Other elements of the selection process will also be streamlined, and selection decisions will be excluded from the requirement to formally state reasons under section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

At the request of the Government, the Chairman of the Public Service Board has written to all Secretaries of department and heads of statutory authorities indicating the Government's grave concern at the inefficiencies resulting from delays currently occurring in the appointment process, and that departments and agencies are expected to improve significantly their performance in this area, to reduce within six months the average time for appointments by half.
(ii) Higher Duties

The Government recognises that departments and agencies need to fill positions on a temporary basis. But it believes that many of the current provisions for selecting and paying staff to perform higher duties are unwarranted, unnecessarily complex, and costly.

Section procedures for temporary higher duties will be simplified by allowing departments to select the most suitable officer available, having regard to operational requirements. Appeals against such selections will be abolished, unless the period of acting extends beyond three months. Departments and agencies will be required to keep long-term acting arrangements to a minimum, and this will be closely monitored.

Existing remuneration provisions for temporary performance have encouraged staff to expect additional payment for performance of any higher functions beyond their normal duties. Higher duties allowance is too often paid automatically where the payment is not justified. The Government will, therefore, examine options for limiting the incidence and extent of payment of higher duties allowance, including possible financial disciplines which would encourage departments to limit the extent of payments of higher duties allowances.
(iii) Delegation of Central Personnel Functions

The Public Service Board has delegated progressively many of its powers and functions to departments. However, in response to the Government's commitment to achieve a more streamlined Public Service, the Board will now initiate further delegation of its activities, particularly in areas of personnel management and employment conditions. Clear guidance will be given to departments and agencies to encourage efficiency and desirable personnel and management practices.

The Government believes it should continue to set examples in areas of equality of opportunity in employment and participation in decision-making practices. Experience shows that effective equal employment opportunity legislation, particularly at an early stage, needs effective monitoring, but this can be done without generating excessive paperwork. Changes will be made to reporting requirements for both industrial democracy and equal employment opportunity programs. The obligations on those departments performing well are reduced, while monitoring will concentrate on departments which are not adequately fulfilling their statutory obligations. The Board will retain responsibility for ensuring that all departments fulfil these obligations.
(iv) Jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission

The Government does not propose to limit the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to public sector employees. It believes, however, that areas of personnel management decision making which are already governed by a code of personnel practice legislated by Parliament, and overall resource allocation for Government employment subject to Budget decisions, should not be the subject of detailed consideration in awards of the Commission. It will, should the need arise, argue this view vigorously before the Commission.
(v) Flextime

The Public Service Board will conduct a review of flextime. The review, which the Government hopes to conduct with the full participation of the ACTU, will be charged with eliminating abuses, while maintaining as far as possible the advantages of the system to both departments and staff.
Implementation

Many of the measures I have referred to will require legislation, and others will require detailed guidelines and procedures. In those cases requiring only administrative action, I have asked the Public Service Board to proceed as a matter of urgency.
Application to Statutory Bodies

These changes to staffing processes apply only to staff employed under the Public Service Act. Those statutory bodies not staffed under the Public Service Act will be given separate consideration, reflecting the diverse circumstances in which they operate. I have now written to all Ministers asking them to undertake consultations with relevant statutory authorities. We will be looking to making early progress towards achieving reforms to staffing processes similar to those covered in this statement. These reviews will also encompass work practices which stand in the way of greater efficiency.
Review of Changes

The Government will review the various changes within personnel management practices in 12 months, and make any further adjustments that are necessary in the light of experience with the new provisions. The Government has consulted as fully as possible with the public sector unions in the development of the initiatives announced today, and will continue to do so in the implementation phase, on the basis that the participation of the unions continues to be constructive. The Government is aware that not all of what it has decided has met with union agreement of consent. It expects the unions and their members to join with the Government in its determination to make the reforms effective and enduring in their impact, for the greater good of this country.
Conclusion

The changes that I have announced today will lead to a leaner, more efficient public sector. The changes in the administration of the tenure provisions, and other changes in personnel practices, constitute a major and radical overhaul of the personnel management system of the Public Service of the sort that previous governments have not been prepared to undertake. Some of the benefits to the taxpayer will be immediate, in terms of the reduction in the size of the Public Service and savings in administrative costs. Others will be achieved in the medium-term, as the `efficiency dividend' requirement and the work of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit take effect, as well as the service-wide reforms to which I have just referred.

I am confident that public sector employees will accept that, at a time when all sections of the Australian community are being asked to make adjustment to a harsher economic environment, the way in which they function should have maximum regard for efficiency and cost effectiveness. For its part, the Government is firmly committed to such an outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes the Government's statement on the Public Service. Although for reasons that I shall explain in a moment we believe that the statement falls well short of the brave new world of Public Service reform and efficiency promised in the address to the nation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in July, there are a number of features in the Prime Minister's statement that will draw support from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I should make it clear at the outset that the Prime Minister's statement does not attack any of the fundamental problems that we see in the balance between the public and private sectors. The Prime Minister's statement does not announce the abolition of one single function of the Commonwealth Public Service, yet in his address to the nation the Prime Minister said that he would announce a blueprint for a leaner and more efficient Public Service. The House should be reminded also that in the three years that the Hawke Government has been in office, 15,000 people have been added to the Commonwealth Public Service payroll, and today's statement promises to reduce the number of public servants by a paltry 2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not got many people listening to you, John.
—If the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) wants to interject in support of a large public sector, I will be only too glad to stimulate him.
—You have no Liberals behind you.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will cease interjecting.

—I do not need any protection from any member from Queensland. (Quorum formed) As I was saying, in the 3 1/2 years that the Hawke Government has been in office, the size of the Public Service has increased by no less than 15,000 employees. When the Government proclaims that it will reduce the Public Service over the next little while by 2,000 people, it should be remembered that that will still leave a net increase in the total number of public servants of 13,000.

SPEECH.PARA: When we go through the Prime Minister's statement, we can be well assured that Sir Humphrey's ratings are not only very good on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television but very good within the Commonwealth Public Service and within the Government led by the present Prime Minister.

Perhaps the most amazing and ironic feature about the statement was the Prime Minister's reference early on about the `she'll be all right' mentality in the Commonwealth Public Service in the 1960s and 1970s. The Prime Minister went on to lecture the Public Service, and through the Public Service the entire Australian community, about the need to change our attitude to work and to drop the `she'll be all right' attitude towards work, and the need to get rid of entrenched work practices in the Public Service and in the private sector.

The Australian public will not forget that the man who now lectures them about their errant attitude towards work is the man who did more than any other living Australian to entrench those attitudes in the Australian community. I know that honourable members opposite do not like to be reminded of the contribution that the Prime Minister made when he was the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to those sorts of attitudes. We should remind ourselves that this is the week when the Prime Minister has not only lectured the Public Service about the `she'll be all right' attitude but has lectured the entire Australian community about the work practices that he did so much to entrench.

I note in passing that quite a number of the initiatives that are contained in the statement are either direct steals from Opposition policies on the Public Service or the results of initiatives and pressures instigated by the Opposition. I instance the proposals made by the Prime Minister on invalidity provisions.

I turn to some of the more detailed sections contained in the Prime Minister's statement. It is good, might I say, to see the Prime Minister lifting none other than a British Conservative Government initiative to establish his Efficiency Scrutiny Unit, which is modelled on the Rayner Efficiency Unit established in 1979. Lord Rayner, then the Managing Director of Marks and Spencer, was to advise the British Prime Minister and other Ministers on efficiency and effectiveness in the civil service.

Whilst we support the establishment of this unit we ought to point out that it is a direct analogy to the Opposition's proposal to establish a private sector body modelled on the Grace Commission. We are concerned that the proposed terms of reference do not require that the unit report directly to individual Ministers on matters under their responsibility. This is directly contrary to well established principles of good management and could undermine much of the work which it is hoped the unit will carry out. The Prime Minister should have learnt from his experience with the Australian Bicentennial Authority last year that if he wishes to take direct responsibility for the day to day management of policy within departments, as the Opposition we will be happy to see that he carries the full blame when errors are made.

I also say on behalf of the Opposition that we particularly welcome the appointment of Mr David Block, who is currently a director of CSR Ltd, as Chairman of this particular unit. Mr Block has had a very distinguished career in the business community and the Opposition very warmly welcomes his appointment. I am sure that he will do the job in his customary intelligent, zealous and very energetic fashion. The Prime Minister's statement does not contain one word about the need to reduce the excessive level of regulation administered by the Public Service. His own regulatory review unit has already substantiated in two reports that the total cost to the economy of business regulation could be between 9 and 19 per cent of gross domestic product. In addition, unnecessary regulation is obviously a major impediment to efficiency within the Public Service. In view of this overwhelming evidence of the need for change it is amazing that the Prime Minister has not taken this opportunity of initiating significant policy changes in this area.

But the greatest shortcoming in this statement is the total absence of any awareness by the Prime Minister of the need for the Government to control its own employees. One of the first actions of the Hawke Government in 1983 was to remove from the Public Service Act the `no work as directed, no pay' provisions, which have enabled Public Service unions to initiate industrial action totally free of any government reaction or intervention. In our view it is essential that this provision be reinstated in the Public Service Act to ensure that essential government services to the public can be guaranteed. The Government's failure to take this action demonstrates yet again that in this particular area it is still the creature of the Public Service unions of this country.

This statement must be seen against the Prime Minister's extravagant commitment to streamline and rationalise the Public Service, which he made in his address to the nation on 11 June. As usual reality has not lived up to his rhetoric. He has roared a lot but he has brought forth a Public Service mouse. Despite his commitment to produce a leaner Public Service it has continued to grow even in the 1986 Budget by a further 0.3 per cent or 607.5 staff years at an increased salary cost of almost $300m. In the last four Budgets the Hawke Government has increased the size of the Public Service by 3.5 per cent, or nearly 15,000 people. Yet he has the gall to talk about the inexorable expansion of the Public Service when it has all been as a result of his Government's own policies. In contrast, be it remembered, the Fraser Government, over the period of eight years, reduced the size of the Public Service by 0.12 per cent per annum.

The second great omission from the statement was any evidence of the Government's intention to streamline and rationalise existing functions and agencies. Despite the Prime Minister's promise, his statement totally ignores the fact that significant reductions in both the size and cost of the Public Service can be achieved only by a major reduction in the functions of government. Some of the proposals announced by the Prime Minister, as I mentioned earlier, are based upon coalition initiatives. For example, we have consistently been saying that the Public Service cannot enjoy work practices and conditions that are beyond the capacity of the community to pay. Consequently many things beyond what the Government has announced are clearly necessary. The Government has failed to set a lead to the private sector by heeding the call of the Opposition and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to remove the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading which cannot be justified under current economic circumstances.

There is also a conspicuous absence of any proposal to negotiate with the States on the transfer of functions which can be better managed at that level of government. Nor has the Government apparently considered the need radically to restructure departments to minimise duplication between programs. The Government's proposals to reform the existing arrangements for the redeployment and retirement of excess staff have our support. However, the earlier reforms introduced in 1983 significantly contributed to the delays and ineffectiveness of the existing system. The Labor Government's insistence in involving trade unions through industrial democracy and by its focusing on employee rights while virtually ignoring their responsibilities created an atmosphere where effective management was virtually impossible. The Government has already amended on a previous occasion the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. We warned the Government then of the need to take a stronger position in these matters and our advice has now been shown to have been fully justified.

We are pleased that the Government has at last bowed to our repeated demands that the system of flexitime be reviewed, but we are suspicious that all the Government proposes is a review and that at the end of the day most of the abuses and excesses of that system will remain in place. The Government has failed to initiate the necessary reforms in the area of Commonwealth compensation. It is obvious that the current compensation arrangements are being misused. In 1984 Commonwealth employees received $121m in compensation which was paid to 45,000 employees, which represents no less than one in 12 of the entire Commonwealth work force. This is considerably higher than compensation claims in the private sector.

I turn to statutory authorities. In the four years that the Government has been in power it has still not met the objectives it set for itself in the Public Service policy paper `Labor and the Quality of Government', especially in the area of statutory authorities. Quite apart from not meeting the reporting standards laid out in that policy, the Government has failed completely in curtailing the growth of the large number of statutory authorities. In the time this Government has been in power it has created no less than another 45 additional statutory authorities excluding such obviously unnecessary bodies as the Commission for the Future.

In conclusion, I say on behalf of the Opposition that this statement by the Prime Minister in no way represents a serious assault on the size of the Public Service. It in no way fulfils the expectations that he raised when he addressed the nation on 11 June. It in no way will contribute to the reduction of the level of the taxation burden in the Australian community. Whilst there are a number of individual measures in the statement that the Opposition agrees with, in no way can the Prime Minister be said to have delivered on the rhetoric of his statement of 11 June. It very clearly represents a triumph for the forces of Sir Humphrey within the Government of this country to the detriment of the parliamentary authority of this country and to the detriment of the drive towards a smaller, leaner Public Service, which was the stated goal of the Prime Minister on 11 June.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION AND OTHER BENEFITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received advice from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he has nominated Mr Smith to be a member of the Committee of Privileges in its consideration of the matter referred to it on 23 September 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the 254th report of the Committee relating to the proposed computer acquisition by the Department of Defence and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report presents the findings of the Committee's examination of several proposed computing acquisitions, including those for Project DESINE, by the Department of Defence. This set of proposals from the Department of Defence is the third, and by far the largest, acquisition proposal received by the Committee to date under its standing reference to examine and report on proposed acquisitions of automatic data processing facilities by Commonwealth departments and authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence submission to the Committee resulted from a Cabinet decision in December 1985 which gave in principle approval to the proposals. However Cabinet did not give approval for any procurement action or expenditure of funds, pending a favourable report from the Committee. The Defence proposals are both large and complex. The largest of these proposals, Project DESINE, will involve the expenditure of more than $300m including the costs of 3,300 man-years of development effort over the next 10 years. The Department of Defence proposes to do three things under Project DESINE: To decentralise its administrative computing systems and to establish a standard computing environment for those systems; to implement two major redevelopment projects, called the Supply and the Manpower Systems Redevelopment Projects, under the DESINE Strategy; and to establish a five-year period contract with a prime contractor to establish a standard computing environment and to supply equipment and software for these major redevelopment projects.

The Committee's examination of the Project DESINE proposals has focused on five major issues: Project cost-benefit justification; technical risks; Australian industry participation; proposed method of acquisition; and staff resources required. The Committee's examination of these issues has led it to recommend that a phased implementation and procurement strategy be adopted for Project DESINE.

The Committee concludes that, given the size, complexity and duration of the DESINE redevelopment projects, the only satisfactory approach is to plan, cost-benefit justify, obtain funding approval and implement each sub- project of the DESINE projects in turn. The initiation of each sub-project should be considered in the light of a review of the preceding sub-projects. This should allow the effective monitoring of both the expenditure on, and the benefits resulting from, these projects.

The Committee therefore recommends that: The Department of Defence not procure implementation quantities of equipment for each major sub-project of the Supply and Manpower Systems Redevelopment Projects or any other projects to be implemented under Project DESINE until; the planning, systems definitions and cost-benefit studies necessary to define and justify these sub-projects, have been completed; the Secretary of the Department of Defence has endorsed each of these sub-projects in turn and the funds necessary to implement them; and a submission dealing with these sub-projects has been made to the Committee under its standing reference to examine and report on ADP acquisition proposals over $5m.

The first of these sub-projects is likely to be the depot-base sub-project of the supply systems redevelopment project which will involve approximately $30m capital expenditure. The Committee also recommends that the Department of Defence provides an annual progress report to the Department of Finance and this Committee which summarises progress to date on Project DESINE and its component projects against agreed plans. This report will detail the benefits achieved in comparison with those initially asserted at the time of project approval; the costs incurred to date in comparison with those initially asserted; the degree of Australian industry participation achieved; and the proposed expenditure for DESINE projects for the following financial year.

The Department of Defence also intends to let a single, five-year period contract as part of Project DESINE, for the supply of two things: A network architecture which will provide the basis for its computing standards; and subsequently, implementation quantities of equipment and software conforming with those standards. The Committee is recommending a two-stage tendering process be employed to ensure the supply of a satisfactory network architecture and the establishment of satisfactory standards, before large quantities of equipment are purchased. This will minimise the risk of major cost overruns should difficulties be experienced in proving the network architecture and establishing satisfactory computing standards. A two-stage tendering arrangement will also increase competition in the tendering for these separate supply requirements and will increase the opportunities for Australian firms to participate.

Although a two-stage tendering process may involve some additional administrative costs, it need not cause any delay to the main implementation phase of the supply and manpower systems redevelopment projects. The Committee believes that any additional costs and small delays in the early stages of Project DESINE will be more than justified by the reduced risk, greater competition and greater opportunities for Australian industry participation which will result. The Committee believes that Project DESINE offers a major opportunity for government purchasing to contribute to the development of a technologically advanced, innovative and competitive computing industry in Australia. It has therefore recommended that special measures be taken, above and beyond the application of Australian purchasing preference and offsets policies, to ensure that this opportunity is not missed and that a satisfactory level of Australian industry participation is achieved in the DESINE contracts.

The Committee therefore recommends that: Part tendering arrangements be adopted in the major implementation phase of Project DESINE to increase the prospects for Australian industry participation in the supply of specific categories of equipment and software; in addition to the enforcement of the Australian purchasing preference and offsets policies, the level of Australian industry participation be a specific criterion in the evaluation of tenders for the DESINE contracts; the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services participate in the weighing of this evaluation criterion and review the level of Australian industry participation in the recommended tenders before contracts are let; and if a satisfactory level of Australian industry participation cannot be agreed at departmental level, the matter be referred to the responsible Ministers for decisions.

The Committee has also reviewed the two other, and quite separate, proposals contained in the Department of Defence's submission to purchase computing equipment for the Office of Defence Production and to establish a period contract for the purchase of small, stand-alone computing systems. The Committee has given qualified support to the proposed procurements for the Office of Defence Production. It is recommending that the tendering for new equipment for the Office of Defence Production be expedited as quickly as possible. However the Committee is not convinced of the justification for the proposed purchase of a $1.85m secondhand computer to provide interim computing capacity until such time as new equipment is purchased. The requirement for this interim capcacity has arisen because of a 2 1/2 year delay in the provision of suitable accommodation for a warehoused computer already owned by the Office and capable of meeting all its interim requirements. The Committee will be investigating further the reasons for this extended delay, in its current inquiry into the administration of Commonwealth property functions.

The Committee believes that the small, stand-alone systems proposal was included in the Defence submission as something of a sop, to compensate for the very limited opportunities offered to Australian firms in the DESINE and Office of Defence Production contracts initially proposed by Defence. However the level of use proposed for this stand-alone, systems contract has not been specified by Defence, and hence the level of benefits to a successful Australian tenderer is also unspecified and uncertain. The Committee is convinced that the alternative arrangements which it has proposed for the DESINE procurements will provide far better prospects for Australian industry participation in the supply of equipment and software to the Department of Defence. The Committee also notes that there are adequate, alternative means available to the Department to procure small, stand-alone computing systems and that the establishment of a new period contract for the supply of such equipment to the Department of Defence is not justified.

The Committee issued guidelines for submissions under its standing reference, and invited comments from departments on these in May 1985. It has to date received no comments and can only assume that departments and the Public Service Board consider these guidelines to be satisfactory. The Committee has identified some areas of deficiency and of potential improvement in the guidelines. It now intends, with the benefit of its experience of the three inquiries it has now completed under the reference, to issue revised guidelines which will, it hopes, assist departments to prepare better submissions and therefore expedite the process of the Committee's inquiry and report. The Committee continues to welcome any comments that interested departments and agencies may wish to make on the guidelines. I commend the report to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: WAREHOUSE DEVELOPMENT FOR 21ST SUPPLY BATTALION, MOOREBANK, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the ninth report for 1986 of the Committee, relating to Warehouse development (Stage 1) for 21st Supply Battalion, Moorebank, New South Wales. I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main warehousing complex of 21st Supply Battalion is located at Moorebank, near Liverpool, New South Wales. The proposal examined by the Public Works Committee is for the construction of a new warehouse building designed to house a number of activities which are at present dispersed throughout the complex in sub-standard buildings constructed during the Second World War. The estimated cost of the new facility is $17.9m and it will have a gross floor area of 22,000 square metres.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee found that there is a need to improve existing warehouses and to integrate stores processing, materials handling and stores functions. The Committee satisfied itself that the proposed building, which provides integrated high-use storage space and areas for stores processing, will result in improvements to productivity, response times and inventory control.
The Committee is sensitive to security requirements for establishments of this nature and recommends close attention to that aspect. I thank the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to ease domestic cost pressures on farmers.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As farmers and their families well know, the cost-price squeeze has accelerated since the Budget was brought down. In spite of the three weeks of hard sell by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), there are very few people in the community, let alone the country areas, who believe that they are better off. Since the Budget interest rates have soared, fuel costs have escalated, and there has been no attempt to reduce the costs on direct inputs of our export industries, let alone our embattled farm industries.

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Budget will worsen the declining returns on capital investment for farmers-a decline which has accelerated under the Australian Labor Party Government. To give the House some idea of the seriousness of this decline, I will give some figures. Under the Liberal-National Party Government, the Fraser Government, and despite the three-year drought, farm terms of trade declined by an average of 1.3 percentage points a year. Under Labor it has gone up to 2.7 per cent. In other words, it has more than doubled and the rate of decline is accelerating.

Under this Government, an average of 125 farmers and farm employees are walking off farms each week. Yet when the Fraser Government lost office, there were more Australians on farms than there were at the end of the disastrous Whitlam Government in 1975. The two factors causing the negative and low incomes among farming families are the world commodity price problem and the escalating domestic cost problem. Before dealing with the domestic cost problem-I want to say a lot about that-I want to comment on the recent outcome of the ministerial discussions at Punta del Este in Uruguay. It was an achievement of some considerable note with the support of the United States, that the 14 fairer trading nations which were brought together at Cairns, succeeded in having agricultural trade placed on the agenda for the forthcoming multilateral trade negotiations. I give credit where credit is due-credit for that.

I give credit to the Prime Minister for adopting the suggestion I made to him in May-to send an all-party delegation to Washington to present a bipartisan case to congressmen over the growing predatory agricultural trading actions of the United States. In four days we persuaded key congressmen to abandon the Daschle wheat subsidy Bill in the House and the Dole Bill passed by the Senate, both of which were designed to apply subsidies across the board to all wheat markets. Both sets of legislation had the potential to blow the Australian wheatgrowers out of the water. There have been attempts to resurrect similar legislation in the Congress in the last week or two; but counter-moves have also been made, and I am confident that the impact we made in Washington will prevent that from occurring before the Congress rises on 3 October.

Our attack on world subsidies has been a team effort-the Government, the Liberal and National parties, the National Farmers Federation and, of course, the excellent academic work of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in exposing the high cost and economic lunacy of the common agricultural policy to the Europeans themselves. Yet having focused so much attention on corrupted world commodity prices and the sins of other nations, the Hawke Labor Government now runs the risk of losing sight of its own failure to come to grips with domestic costs. Australia's greatest challenge as a major agricultural exporting nation will be to maintain its share of world markets over the next three or four years and to maintain the viability of farmers generally. Let it be understood that the average age of farmers is 58, and so many of our young people are being persuaded to leave the farm because of the problems they are experiencing.

With our record balance of trade deficit predicted to rise even further this year, and our gross overseas debt expected to exceed $100 billion by the middle of next year, no nation has needed its efficient farmers more. There was never a greater need to regain our competiveness and become more export-oriented, outward- oriented as a nation. Let nobody go on with all this stupid drivel that the manufacturing industries, the sunrise industries, the high tech industries, will be our saviour. They might be of great help next century, but for the foreseeable future it will be the farmers of Riverina-Darling at Griffith, of Gippsland, Gwydir, Mallee, and New England, the farmers of Australia, who will again be asked to pull their share and to continue to make their contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Richmond farmers?

—Yes, and the Richmond farmers. I reject the overworked excuse of honourable members opposite that the rate of farm costs increases will be cut to 3 per cent for this financial year. Does the Government stand by this figure, after slugging farmers with interest rates up to three times higher than those of our competitors, inflation up to six times higher, the highest taxing system in post-war years, wage increases outstripping those in our competing nations, as the Leader of the Opposition has so clearly demonstrated, the failure to make a real effort to cut tariff protection on a program predictable basis in spite of the record devaluation of the Australian dollar? Let us have none of this nonsense that the Government is restructuring. It is avoiding the issue like the plague. In contrast, overseas there has been a dramatic slow-down of inflation, an easing of interest rates and relatively buoyant economic conditions. Our own farmers are experiencing declining competitiveness on corrupted world markets due to the monetary, budgetary and wages policies of the Hawke Labor Government, a new array of tax slugs and Budget rip-offs in three years totalling more than $500m from primary industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to three specific examples of this outrageous, unfair and discriminatory manner in which the fringe benefits tax is applied to farmers. Make no mistake: It will be abolished when we get back into government-lock, bloody stock and barrel! Let no one have any doubt about what we think of this outrageous tax.

First, this Government has made great play of its Priority One: Young Australia campaign, yet it says nothing about the impact of its hard-taxing, anti-investment policies. A farm employer who takes on a Priority One trainee becomes eligible for a grant of $1,000. That same farmer will lose more than the value of the grant in the fringe benefits tax alone in most cases where the trainee is housed on the farm. It will cost the farmer about $1,150. What a ridiculous system. This youth trainee system becomes a net liability to the farmer even before wages are taken into account. So the fringe benefits tax has blown Priority One out of the water.

Secondly, I turn to the situation, not uncommon amongst family farmers, where the farm is incorporated into a company structure and the maintenance of the home has been charged for tax purposes. Where full shire rates have been claimed as a business expense for tax purposes, the family farm house will automatically become liable for the fringe benefits tax. This was disclosed yesterday to the National Farmers Federation. But Labor has again laid its trap for the family farm. The Australian Tax Office will use past rate claims to set the eligibility test for the FBT. There is no way out for such farmers. What an outrageous, sneaky trap for farming families earning about one third of average weekly earnings in this country.

Thirdly, I turn to the example of day labour shearers travelling to a property from the nearest township-suburban shearers, as they are called. The Australian Taxation Office has now circulated to group employers a document relating to the FBT which states:
The value of board and quarters provided to `found' employees and the allowance paid to `not found' employees are subject to FBT.

A `not found' employee is one who is designated as not remaining on a property overnight after a day's shearing. It should be made perfectly clear that there is no provision in the pastoral industry award for allowances to be paid to `not found' employees. So the Taxation Office has got that wrong. Despite this, the Taxation Office guidelines force employers to pay fringe benefits tax on the value of board and lodging, even though the shearer goes to his own home at night. The FBT is payable on an allowance which does not exist. This gross confusion and inequity is an unacceptable way to administer the tax laws of this nation.

If the Treasurer refuses to abandon his fringe benefits tax, he should at the very least defer implementation of the tax until 1 July 1987 to give the Taxation Office, employers and employees some time to establish how this tax will operate and to iron out such totally unacceptable anomalies.

The ministerial statement on 15 April was a rational economic document but lacked real teeth in redressing earlier Labor policies. A glance through the Minister's recent progress report reveals little of substance in relation to easing the terms of trade slump. It was long on words and short on action. We learnt that consideration of cutting tariffs on imported agricultural chemicals will now be delayed until the end of the year, despite agreement in principle by the Treasurer more than 12 months ago. The Treasurer had said that he was awaiting the Industries Assistance Commission report. That report was delivered in July. The Minister now says that the Government needs to think about it for `the next couple of months'. This action could save farmers up to $20m in a full year.

From last week on-farm diesel costs are up a massive 5.8c a litre, increasing costs by at least $50m a year, while non-rebatable petrol costs are up 2.1c a litre. Then there is the effect of the high fuel prices for transport to and from the farm gate. For country people with long travelling distances, that bites hard. Since July, interest rates have leapt more than 2 per cent, costing farmers $200m in a full year. With the recent changes to fuel pricing and the 2 per cent increase in interest rates, these increases alone have slugged farmers a further $250m a year. That represents about one quarter of the net farm profit this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. I recall the promise of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) last year that the Budget would bring interest rates down. That is another broken promise-I suppose we could call it a forecast-by Labor. The prime rate in Australia is far above that of our competitors, which is one factor in the loss of our gilt-edged credit rating. Against our 19 per cent prime rate, it is 11 per cent in Britain, 7 per cent in the United States of America and West Germany, and 4 per cent in Japan. Our interest rates on a record farm debt, totalling $8 billion, from the major institutional lenders are crippling farmers. Every percentage point increase in interest rates adds $100m to farm costs. If our prime rate were the same as Britain's-one of the highest, at 11 per cent-this would save farmers nearly $4,000 per annum on average, doubling the estimated net farm income this year. So let it not be said that Labor can escape the blame for the problems facing the farm sector.

SPEECH.PARA: With better management of our economy, world confidence would improve so that stiff Reserve Bank and monetary policy intervention would not be necessary to attract speculative capital to save our dollar from falling further. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government could restore confidence in rural Australia by, with a stroke of the pen, immediately abolishing the capital gains and the fringe benefits taxes. The Government is not yet dependent on this revenue, but these taxes are imposing a nightmare of bureaucratic red tape and will impose heavy costs on the embattled farm sector.

The sales tax on wine has been doubled. The Government promised that it would not impose a sales tax on wine; yet it is up to 20 per cent. A new 10 per cent sales tax has been imposed on fruit juice products and flavoured milk. Wine grapes and citrus growers, on average, will have a negative income this year; yet they are going to be bled to death by a further tax regime. The government promised wine producers it would not impose those taxes, but it has. The Opposition has set up a committee to investigate thoroughly the problems affecting the wine industry and to examine ways of rehabilitating that industry when we get back to government.

The decision to withhold the IAC dumping inquiry into Brazilian orange juice concentrate until the week after the Budget was a cynical attempt to cover bad news with good news. Export inspection charges remain at treble their levels in 1983. We have the most efficient farmers in the world and, given a fair go, they will mix it with the best. But we have farmers in this country who are battling not only against the treasuries of Europe and the United States but also against a Labor Government that could not care less. If it did care less, it would relieve the burden of so many of these costs that are really strangling the farm sector. Australian living standards will continue to depend very heavily upon our farming and mining industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the Opposition's tactics committee has met and has decided to run the same matter of public importance that it raised yesterday. I was not taken by surprise when the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), came up with the urgency motion today. I guess the arguments were also just as expected as the motion. Yesterday, of course, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) decided to get himself thrown out of the House on the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has totally exposed the hypocrisy in the Opposition's case on the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who saw Richard Carleton interview the Leader of the Opposition last night would understand fully the problems that the Opposition has with respect to the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer today again pointed out exactly the situation and the rorts that have gone on in this country. He showed that an individual with an effective salary package of $115,000 under the old system-the system that existed under the leadership of the former Liberal-National Party Government-would pay the same tax rate as some poor wage bloke on $11,500 a year. They were the rorts that that Government would have perpetuated, and they are the rorts that the Opposition wants to go back to.

If there is no fringe benefits tax, it really means more tax for the farmers. Let us be quite clear about that. What we would go back to would be the rorts, the evasion and the tax avoidance, and honest people paying tax would have to pay more. The Leader of the Opposition has already said that all election promises made in the immediate past are off except one-the assets test-so we have to ask the question: Where is the money coming from? If one wipes out the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, farmers will pay more tax. There are no two ways about that. Farmers already pay less than the average national tax rate.
Another thing that the National Party of Australia is running around the bush with is this whole idea of the flat tax policy, or a flatter tax policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Flat earth policy.

—The flat earth policy. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pointed out the other day, a flat tax of 25 per cent-the policy that is being canvassed by the National Party in Queensland-would really mean that the average tax paying farmer would pay $1,675 more per farm. One can look at other figures. Even with a tax rate of 18 per cent or 20 per cent, taking Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures, the average farmer would pay more on a flat tax. So where would the Opposition get the money from?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the whole question of the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer showed to the House today very clearly that city managers who get private school education for their children for nothing, at the expense of the tax paying public in general, are effectively being subsidised by farmers who, in many areas, have to send their children to boarding schools. That is what the National Party is saying. It is saying that it is all right for city managers to get free education for their children as part of a salary package, subsidised by wage and salary earners throughout the community and honest farmers, yet farmers have to pay for the boarding school education of their children. The fringe benefits tax gives remote area concessions. It gives a 40 per cent concession to farmers. If one looks at the number of farmers who will be affected by the measure in the long run-despite all the hype-one finds that it will be very few. It is against the interests of the farmers to campaign for the abolition of the fringe benefits tax and particularly to bring back the rorts which the Opposition dignified when it was in government.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party gave the capital gains tax as an example of another measure a future coalition government may remove. The farmers got what they wanted with the capital gains tax because there is effective exemption for the family farm in perpetuity. Therefore, we have not created any tax shelter. We have an effective tax exemption. Where would the money come from? Would the Opposition remove the diesel rebate, which is now worth about $300m? Would it savage all the other spending programs in primary industry? Or would it attack the wage and salary earners, the great mass of the population, even more? That is what the Opposition has to face up to.

The other thing the Opposition has to face up to-the Deputy Leader of the National Party referred to this-is the whole question of our terms of trade. The Leader of the Opposition, in none of his comments, has ever focused on the question of our balance of payments, our balance of trade and the terms of trade problems we face in this country today. The BAE just brought out its June quarter figures. So now we finally have the figures for the farm sector as a whole for the financial year that has just ended. The annual rate of increase in farm costs during 1985-86 was 4.2 per cent and compares very favourably with a rate of increase of 11 per cent which occurred under the previous Government. If the previous 11 per cent rate of increase had continued, farm incomes would be some 85 per cent lower than is currently anticipated. The annual rate of increase in that period also compares favourably with the consumer price increases during the same period.

There has been a substantial slowing down in the rate of increase in farm costs, culminating in the fall recorded in the latest June quarter. This reflects the full rebating of the diesel fuel excise announced in the 1985 Budget in conjunction with the fall in world oil prices and lower interest rates. This slowing is expected to be maintained as the Government's budgetary and wages policies succeed in reducing inflation and interest rates. Already-one can look at the Australian Financial Review this morning-we have stability in the dollar and the rates are coming down again.

Once again, these indices show that low commodity prices are the major cause of farmers' difficulties. About 80 per cent of the cause of the farmers' problems in terms of their income is derived from overseas. The 2.1 per cent fall in prices received over the year to June was despite the currency appreciation of 8 per cent against the trade weighted index for the same period. That is the big problem. Even with a substantial devaluation Australia's farmers, and the Australian community and economy are not getting the benefit of that. That is due to the corruption of world markets. That is why the efforts by all people-Australian governments and overseas-and, in particular, those of our Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), have finally been rewarded. There is no difference of opinion amongst members on both sides of the House in respect of our international trade and negotiations. We are all in there fighting for Australians and our farmers. The efforts of the Minister for Trade were particularly valiant and praiseworthy because now, for the first time, we have a turn- around, a turning point. It was a magnificent achievement. For the first time in 40 years agriculture will be on the agenda of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That cannot be underestimated. I have been pointing out, as has the honourable member for Gwydir, that the hard work is ahead. However, we have a four-year time scale in which we can negotiate. The presence of agriculture on the GATT agenda will mean, surely, that people in Europe, the United States and Japan with a long term approach, with statesmanship, will start looking at their policies of subsidisation and protection. We have to end the subsidies of agricultural production in the non-efficient countries. We have to end export subsidisation.

The Minister for Trade achieved an enormous amount. When the French Trade Minister on Wednesday during the week of the meeting at Punta del Este put forward the French position, the Minister for Trade did not walk away like Mr Anthony, the former Leader of the National Party, did in 1977. He stayed and negotiated through the night. It is Australia's achievement that in the end the United States, the European Economic Community and Australia were in there negotiating on the words of the text. The group of 14 held together. This reflects particularly favourably on the earlier Bangkok initiative of the Prime Minister and his trade meetings all over the world. So this has been a great achievement, and is where a lot of the answer lies.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party raised quite a few other points. I do not have time to respond to them. However, all governments are very much up against it with respect to budgetary restraints at present. We do not have to look to the past coalition Government to see the failures of the Opposition's approach and the success of this Government's approach, which fundamentally centres on the fact that we have all but deregulated the financial market, that we have a floating dollar and an incomes policy, that unit labour costs have dropped by 7 per cent and that industrial disputation has stopped. Without confrontation as a government strategy we are getting the benefits and a sensible approach to Australia's overall economic situation. It is only the confrontationists, the Frasers of this world, and the people outside whom some call the New Right who are likely to sabotage the magnificent progress that has been made in the last three and a half years.

Let us consider the one State where the National Party is in control-the banana state of Queensland. Queensland has a National Party Government which does not even believe in democracy. Not only does Queensland have the highest unemployment rate of any State-I guess that says it all for National Party policies-but also it has imposed the highest rate of tax increases on its farmers. Between 1982-83 and 1985, rates and taxes on Queensland farmers increased by 41 per cent as opposed to a national average of 38 per cent. At the same time, the Queensland National Party Government-a minority government-syphoned off $33.5m from rural assistance funds and ran up hollow logs totalling around $75m in money that should have been going to assist Queensland farmers.

This Government has taken measures to reduce farm costs which the Opposition would not even contemplate. One measure has been the replacement of tariffs on harvesters and cultivation machinery with bounties. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has claimed that the tariff burden on agricultural machinery should be cut. What is he talking about? We have already done it. We have before us at present the foreshadowed reduction in tariff-imposed costs on agricultural chemicals. I met with chemical people this morning. There are many problems in this area. The various components of agricultural chemicals have tariffs applied to them. The present system which we inherited works in reverse. There is a higher rate of tariff on the components of chemicals than there is on the final product. Another instance is vice versa. We have a rather crazy situation. My colleague, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), is trying to sort it out so that we can get some rational system of tariff protection for the chemical industry and bring down the costs to farmers. It is not an easy task. It is highly detailed. The cost of chemicals to farmers in real terms has been coming down quite strongly.

We have already abolished the Opposition's 2 per cent revenue duty on agricultural chemicals. We have set up a royal commission on grain handling and transport. We have instituted the full rebate to primary producers of the diesel oil excise, which is worth about $330m. Farmers are getting distillate, even with the recent 5.8 per cent increase, at about 29c a litre, whereas other people are paying about 48.5c a litre.

The Government is also spending a lot of money on roads. The Deputy Leader of the National Party knows that 75 per cent of the record expenditure on roads is spent on rural roads. The Brisbane-Cairns road is 100 per cent Commonwealth funded. The Brisbane-Mount Isa-Darwin road is 100 per cent directly funded by the Commonwealth. One will not see too many signs up there in Queensland illustrating that, but that is where all the money comes from for the Bruce Highway and those basic roads that are so important to farmers in Queensland.

This Government has helped with costs in many other areas, but quite frankly some of those areas are a little hidden. The previous Government halved the interest subsidy on the Reserve Bank's Rural Credits Department borrowings for the Australian Wheat Board. We wiped out that subsidy and allowed the Australian Wheat Board to borrow overseas. It is now borrowing $2 1/2 billion a year overseas and is getting an interest rate of about 8 or 10 per cent. It has a physical good to trade-or something like that-and it is able to engage in hedging. We have given wheat growers a great deal of flexibility. We have saved them tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars on their borrowings so far. We are doing similar things with all statutory marketing authorities by allowing them to have commercial flexibility with respect to their borrowings.

Let me talk about fuel, because that is one of the big issues. Last year, when we fully rebated the diesel fuel excise, we thought that it would cost some $35m. By the time the falls in world oil prices occurred earlier this year, the figure was over $300m. The Deputy Leader of the National Party tried to mislead farmers the other week, in a very carefully framed Press release, by suggesting that the fuel excise exemption had been varied in some way. They have not. All that has happened is that the distillate prices have moved up and down according to import parity changes, which is the Opposition's own policy. As the Opposition knows, this whole issue of fuel pricing is again before the Industries Assistance Commission. It is apparent to me why the Opposition has resurrected farm costs as an issue today. It used to be the flavour of the month in agro-political circles, but the reality-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The purpose of the Loans Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1986-87 and subsequent years, together with the associated prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The Senate has again this year returned the Bill to the House of Representatives with amendments moved by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats which effectively remove the provisions of the Bill which would establish it as standing legislation.

As I indicated in my second reading speech, when the Bill was introduced, the Government proposed standing legislation so as to obviate the need each year for what is in effect a machinery financing measure. The Bill merely enables the charging to Loan Fund of moneys which must, in all circumstances, first be appropriated by the Parliament from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Conversion to standing legislation would, however, improve the efficiency of Parliament by allowing a more effective allocation of business during the crowded Budget sittings. Indeed, in support of this view one has to look only at the contribution of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton)-I am glad that he is present this afternoon-to the debate on the Loans Bill last year. I shall quote what he said because he was in one of his more sensible moods:

This Bill makes arrangements for the Government to borrow. Previously there used to be an annual Loan Bill to handle this situation for all circumstances arising during a financial year. This Bill has been drafted as standing legislation rather than annual legislation to remove the necessity to pass legislation annually. As the Bill does not itself authorise expenditure but merely creates a mechanism whereby expenditures authorised by other legislation can be made, the Opposition does not object to the concept of standing legislation. It merely improves the efficiency of the Parliament. We therefore support the Bill.

I hope that I will not sound too pretentious in saying that I could not have said it better myself. Those words sum up the position perfectly. As I have said, he was in one of his more sensible moods. It is unfortunate that the contribution to this year's debate by some of the less enlightened members of the Opposition could not have been as responsible. Instead, Opposition speakers attempted again to suggest, falsely, that standing legislation of the type proposed was underhand or could in some way detract from the Parliament's ability to debate the Budget, the deficit, or the Government's deficit financing measures. I have not noticed, this year, any lack of opportunity to debate those matters. All such assertions are, of course, patently wrong, as a reading of the Loans Bill and its associated explanatory memorandum clearly demonstrates.

I refer to the contribution of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) when the Bill was considered on a previous occasion. He suffered from a misunderstanding about the Bill. He doubted that it was a machinery measure and assumed that, if it were, it would not be proclaimed until after the Budget had been passed. I promised him that I would make some further comments on that later, and I do so now. The annual Loan Bills have always received royal assent prior to the passage of the annual Appropriation Bills. Interim appropriations are available by virtue of the Supply Act (No. 1), which enables borrowings to be undertaken pursuant to the Loan Act to finance defence expenditures incurred during the Supply period but prior to passage of the Appropriation Bills.

Clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill specifically limit the ability to borrow moneys to situations where moneys are lawfully available, or are authorised to be expended. Moneys do not become lawfully available for expenditure under the Appropriation Bills until those Bills are passed by the Parliament and assented to. Thus moneys cannot be lawfully borrowed under a Loans Act in respect of the amounts, additional to Supply, included in the Appropriation Bills unless and until those Bills receive royal assent. It is therefore not necessary that assent to the Appropriation Bills be obtained prior to that for a Loans Bill. I gave that as an example of the misunderstandings on the part of those who did not believe that this was a machinery measure. It is clearly a machinery measure. All the paranoia on the part of those who rolled the better informed in the coalition party room is unfounded.

The fact that the Bill is merely a machinery measure-there is nothing underhand in the Bill-was acknowledged, as I said earlier, by the shadow Treasurer in his contribution to the debate both this year and last year. The Bill would not detract from Parliament's ability to debate the Budget or the associated deficit financing measures. The deficit and the borrowing requirements are announced in the Budget Speech and Papers, which are debated at length in this Parliament. Indeed, in speaking to the Bill this year, the shadow Treasurer said that he did not wish to take the opportunity afforded in the debate on the Loans Bill to debate the Commonwealth borrowing program, but preferred to leave that matter for debates on Appropriation Bills and, indeed, matters of public importance and the many other occasions when he has had an opportunity to debate these matters. He was very sensible. He recognised that, this being a machinery measure, he did not need this Bill to debate those matters.

It is a pity that some of the more sensible elements of the Liberal Party and the National Party got rolled in their attempts to have the Opposition support this Bill. Nevertheless, it is not a matter of crucial importance to the Government. The Opposition's amendments will not add one jot to the power or authority of the Parliament. Regrettably, however, they will hinder its efficiency, because next year we could have had the time that we have taken on this Loans Bill as extra time to debate the other important matters of government. However, as I say, it is not a major matter. We have no alternative but to bow to the non-Government majority in the Senate. This manifests again the fact that our Hawke Labor Government is not in power in this country; it is in office. It is not in power because it does not have that majority in the Senate. The ill-informed, non-Government majority in the Senate must prevail; it has the numbers. The Government will not oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the process of being kind to me, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) was making a political point that he thought was to his advantage. Since I have heard him cantering around the paddock about four or five times on this measure, he rather destroys his argument that it is a waste of time for the Opposition in the Senate to combine with the Australian Democrats to pass these amendments, which the Government has accepted. The real waste of time is in the Government fronting up with a Loans Bill year after year, trying to change it from an annual Bill into a standing Bill, when it knows jolly well that the ladies and gentlemen in the Senate-the House of review, which has every right to decide on these matters-have decided that they want to have a look at the Bill every year. Therefore, the simplest and most efficient way of dealing with this matter would be for the Government-if it is still in office at the same time next year-to front up with a single annual Bill. No doubt the matter will be dealt with speedily, unless there are some questions about what is going on-in which case there will be a lengthier debate-and that will be it. Therefore, my advice to the Government, in order to avoid any undue delay in the processes of the House or of the Parliament, is to desist next year from trying yet again what it has tried this year, having failed last year-to turn this into a different sort of Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The other comment that I wish to make in passing is that it was useful to have confirmation from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer that the Opposition has taken up a very large number of opportunities to debate economic issues-in Appropriation Bill debates and in debates on matters of public importance-because it is the constant theme of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the Opposition does not debate the key economic issues in this chamber. Every day, at Question Time, when the Press gallery is full, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer say: `You are not debating the great economic issues'. However, if one goes to Hansard, as the Minister correctly pointed out-in this case, he is being most sensible and very fair-one can see that we have had ample opportunity to debate the key economic issues and that we have done so. If we look at the matters of public importance that we have debated this year and last year, we can see that an enormous number were on key economic issues. Throughout the economic crisis that has clearly been developing over the last 12 months, we have been giving advice to the Government on what it should do in debate after debate after debate. What the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been saying day after day is absolute nonsense. It is good to have confirmation from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer that the Opposition has certainly not been derelict in its duty in raising these matters.
We welcome the fact that the Government is being sensible once again in accepting these amendments that have been passed in the upper House, and we will delay this measure no longer in Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
