DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX RATES BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX BILL 1986TAXATION LAWS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate order of the day No. 2 concurrently with orders of the day Nos 3 and 4. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill are the principal legislative proposals to give effect to the taxation measures announced in the Budget. Therefore, it is a good opportunity for the Opposition and for the House generally to say something about the subject of taxation. Over the last 24 hours, we have witnessed a very deliberate and, at times, quite desperate attempt by the Government, particularly the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to divert attention from the embarrassment that the Government is experiencing, not only over community hostility to the fringe benefits tax but over community hostility to the travel allowance claims of the Treasurer. Therefore, it is a good opportunity to remind ourselves of a few basic facts about taxation in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The first statement that should be made in any taxation debate in this Parliament is that this Government is the largest-taxing and highest-taxing government that this country has seen since Federation. In this current financial year, 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product will be consumed in taxation collections. Without any argument, contest or doubt, that is the highest level of tax collection that this country has ever seen. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer can engage in all the conjuring tricks under the sun, but nothing can defy the black- and-white print of the Budget Papers that were delivered by the Treasurer when he presented his last Budget.

Not only is this the highest-taxing Government in peacetime, but, on top of that, it is a Government which has deliberately and cold-bloodedly broken all of the tax commitments that it made during the last election campaign. We all remember that the centrepiece of the Government's economic policy during the last election campaign was the much-vaunted trilogy. We all remember the Prime Minister going around the country during the 1984 election campaign saying that he could be trusted and his Government should be re-elected because he was prepared to commit his Government and his Party to an economic trilogy. One element of that economic trilogy was that there would be no increase in the level of taxation as a proportion of GDP either over the lifetime of the Parliament or during the first year that a Budget was brought down under a re-elected Hawke Government. Yet in the two Budgets that have been brought down since that election-the Budgets of 1985 and 1986-there have been increases in the percentage of tax collected as a proportion of GDP. So that leg of the trilogy has also been completely broken. In 1986-87, the Treasurer will collect $1,400m more in additional tax collections over the trilogy ceiling, which shows the extent to which the Government's trilogy commitment was broken by the Government in the two Budgets brought down since the 1984 election.

But it gets worse and it goes much further than that. We have heard a great deal about the taxation reforms of the present Government. We are told a great deal about the reductions in personal tax rates. We are told how, after July next year, there will be a top marginal rate of tax of 49c in the dollar. While the possibility of a mini-Budget in May next year remains-there is a very clear possibility of that-there is no guarantee that, at the last moment, the personal tax cuts will not be taken away by this Treasurer. They were promised for September of this year. They have already been deferred until December of this year. While the prospect of a mini-Budget hangs over the head of this Parliament, there is every prospect and every likelihood that the personal tax cuts will be taken away at the last minute. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) can shake his head and say that there is no likelihood that that will happen, but the reality is that that is a very distinct possibility.

The intriguing thing is that, even if those taxation cuts do go ahead, we will not have the promised reductions in taxation that the Government has talked about so much. It may surprise many honourable members to know that, even after those taxation reductions have been put in place, the average and marginal rates of tax paid by a person, whether he is a single person or a person supporting a spouse and two dependent children, will both be higher than they were when this Government came to power in March 1983. That is a fact that the Government finds very embarrassing. It is a fact that the Prime Minister did not even acknowledge when I asked him about it in the Parliament last week. It is a fact that this House and the Australian community will hear a great deal about over the next 18 months. The average tax rate for that person in March 1983 was 22.9 per cent. The marginal rate was 30 per cent. Even after the so-called great initiative, even if all of the promises of the Government on personal taxation are delivered in the middle of next year, those rates will then be 24.5 per cent and 40 per cent. That is the measure of the Government's duplicity so far as the taxation reforms and the taxation initiatives are concerned.

In the last Budget this Government introduced $1.4 billion worth of new taxes. It increased the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent; it increased sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juices; it increased the petrol excise by 3c a litre. I have compiled a list which shows that no fewer than 14 new taxes have been introduced, or initiatives taken, by the Hawke Government since it came to office that have resulted in increases in tax levels. We have had a fringe benefits tax; we have had a capital gains tax; we have had an entertainment tax; we have had the removal of negative gearing; we have a foreign tax credit system; we have had the lump sum superannuation tax; we have had an increased company tax rate; we have had new and increased wholesale taxes; we have had petrol excise increased from 6c to 20c a litre; we have had the automatic biannual indexation of excise rates; we have had the abolition of concessional expenditure rebates; we have had a wine tax; we have had an excise tax on intermediate and new oil; and we have had a bureaucratic substantiation of employment expenses. That is the measure of all of the new taxes. No wonder this Government is so sensitive about the issue of taxation. No wonder the Opposition welcomes the fact that the Government wants to fight the next election on the issue of taxation.

Over the last 48 hours the Government has displayed its extraordinary sensitivity on the issue of the fringe benefits tax. The circumstances that led to my suspension yesterday demonstrated very dramatically to the Opposition, the Parliament and the Australian public how sensitive this Government and this Treasurer are about the issue of the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer has a double reason to be sensitive. The first reason is that this fringe benefits tax is widely resented and despised throughout the length and breadth of the rural community and the small business community. That is the first area of sensitivity. The second area of sensitivity for the Treasurer is that he has displayed over the last 48 hours, on that issue and on the issue of his travel allowance, that he has monumental double standards. We in the Opposition make no apology for raising that matter; nor will the many people in the small business community feel very deeply aggrieved that we have raised it.

I take the opportunity to say again, as I have said on many occasions, that the Opposition is unqualifiedly committed to the abolition of the fringe benefits tax. The attempts by the Government to suggest that in some way that commitment is qualified, that in some way, because we restate our well-known opposition to tax avoidance practices, that waters down that commitment, is a total misrepresentation of the situation. It has absolutely no substance. For that argument to have any substance the Government would have to establish that the practices against which the fringe benefits tax is levied are substantially practices of tax avoidance. Yet in reality-and this is our complaint, and the complaint of many people in the community-this tax reaches into a large number of areas and catches a large number of practices in which there is absolutely no evidence of tax avoidance. Do people call a football club prize an exercise in tax avoidance? Do they call a safety award an exercise in tax avoidance? Do they call a retirement present an exercise in tax avoidance? Do they call a tax on religious institutions and some charities a tax directed against tax avoidance practices? Do they regard the provision of farm workers' accommodation and food, which is compulsory under the pastoral award, as a legitimate target for anti-tax avoidance legislation? Of course, they do not. That is the difficulty of this tax, that is why it is so resented, and that is why, in the words of my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), it will be thrown out lock, stock and barrel by the next coalition Government-because it attacks those kinds of practices.

I want to make perfectly clear again, the Opposition's commitment to get rid of tax avoidance practices. I will refer to tax avoidance practices in a moment, because this Government has a very miserable record on taking action against tax avoidance practices. It said a great deal about it before it came to office, but it has done precious little since it came to power. So our commitment to get rid of that fringe benefits tax is an unqualified commitment, and is in no way diluted, qualified or modified by our continuing opposition to tax avoidance practices in the community. Any attempt by the Government to establish otherwise is nothing other than a desperate attempt by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to divert the public's attention from the embarrassment suffered by the Treasurer when he was caught fiddling his travel allowance. The Opposition makes no apology for continuing to refer to that matter.

What has happened over the last 48 hours is the classic diversionary tactic. Whenever the heat is put on the Government over something, it creates a diversion. Two or three weeks ago, it started saying that anybody who wanted to reform the industrial relations system was an extremist. Over the last 48 hours, the Treasurer has been caught out. He is the man who has gone throughout the length and breadth of Australia and has abused and insulted ordinary, honest small business people and farmers. He has called anybody who has had some of the arrangements to which I have referred a tax cheat or a tax rorter and has used the most insulting language against people who have ordinary, legitimate taxation arrangements. Because that man has used that kind of invective and that kind of abuse-and he has now been caught out as having the most deplorable double standards that many members of this Parliament have seen for many years-and because he has been caught out, he reverts to the great Labor tactic of a diversionary device. He throws up his arms and, in a loud voice, says: `The Opposition really intends to introduce an alternative fringe benefits tax because it is against tax avoidance'. What a lot of humbug. What a pathetic attempt by the Treasurer to divert attention from his own embarrassment and the predicament in which he finds himself, not only in terms of his taxation measures, but also in terms of his personal credibility.

The reality is that this Government is the highest taxing Government in Australia's peacetime history. Its taxation measures are widely rejected and widely resented by the Australian community. I can only say again, on behalf of the Opposition, that we warmly welcome the fact that the Prime Minister has declared that taxation will be the major issue of the next election campaign. We welcome that fact because we believe that throughout the length and breadth of this country the taxation record and taxation measures of this Government are widely despised and widely rejected.

It is all summed up by what I said at the beginning of my remarks: By any measure this Government is the highest taxing government that we have seen since Federation. It has broken all its promises on the trilogy. Even after the so-called great reforms have been brought in next year, the average and marginal rates of taxation for a person on average weekly earnings will be much higher than they were when the Hawke Government came to power. The Government has introduced no fewer than 14 ad- ditional taxation measures and it has not done anything substantial to counter tax avoidance practices, despite all of its noise to the contrary. Most insulting and humiliating of all, the person who has carried the flag on behalf of the Government, the person who has said more than anybody else on behalf of the Government against the alleged rorts and avoidance fiddles of the rest of the community, has himself been caught fiddling by manipulating the travel allowance system of this Parliament. To his great embarrassment and shame, he has been revealed as a person with monumental and deplorable double standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the National Party and the Liberal Party in Opposition have the greatest of political gall. There is no end to their efforts to cover up what they have done in the past. I assure them, however, that the people of Australia will not forget the record of the Howard-Fraser Government. No matter what Opposition members say here, and no matter how they rant and rave, the Australian people have not forgotten that the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as Treasurer in the Fraser Government did not have the courage to tackle the problems of the Australian tax system. He can rant and rave about it now, but for the eight years that he had power he did nothing. Instead, he left the country with a top marginal tax rate of 60c in the dollar. It is no wonder that small business, business generally and workers who are earning over $36,000 a year cry out for us to do something about marginal tax rates, and certainly the top tax rate. The Fraser-Howard Government-I stress Howard-did nothing during its term of office. Instead, it encouraged massive tax avoidance and evasion.

SPEECH.PARA: We know what was lost to the community. We know also that when this Government tried to recoup the money it was the Liberal and National parties which refused in the Senate to support legislation that would have brought back hundreds of millions of dollars into the nation's tax coffers. That money would have released some of the pressure on the ordinary pay as you earn employee, the individual who pays his tax as he earns it. We have an Opposition that tries to cover its having been part of evasion and avoidance through condoning it. (Quorum formed)

Prior to the quorum being called, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was saying how the Opposition, while it was in government, was responsible for the disillusionment that grew in the minds of electors and taxpayers and for the contempt for the tax system that developed. I heard the Leader of the Opposition talk about double standards and, although it did not relate particularly to these income tax Bills, he talked about the fringe benefits tax and travelling allowances. I am pleased that he raised the issue of travelling allowances because I believe that the people of Australia have a right to know, in view of the attack that he has been mounted on the Treasurer (Mr Keating), whether it is correct that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), has been claiming the travelling allowance while he has been living in Canberra with his family. The honourable member for Gwydir has a house in Forrest; yet he lists his principal place of residence as a place called Dunumbral, which is his family property in the north-west of New South Wales. A few minutes ago we heard the Leader of the Opposition talk about double standards and how he would reduce them.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I ask that you require the honourable member for Capricornia to get back to the Bill before the House.
—I call on the honourable member for Capricornia to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Under the Standing Orders it is quite all right to respond to remarks made by those on the other side of the House. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) has been here a few years and he should know them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get to some truth about these matters. The Opposition has been attacking the Treasurer for days and going on about how he is supposed to be rorting some sort of system. We have had statements from the Leader of the Opposition and undertakings from his shadow Ministry that no one on that side has been doing anything wrong. In a release from the Australian Associated Press the Leader of the Opposition says he has obtained statements from all his shadow ministers that everyone is behaving properly. The honourable member for Gwydir is in the chamber and I ask whether it is correct that he claims the travelling allowance while living with his family in Canberra. Does he declare that his principal residence is his family property in the north-west of New South Wales?

If that is the position, I can understand it and I take no exception to it. If the Treasurer, for example, is called upon to carry out duties in the capital, surely we should not expect him to pay for his rented house out of his normal salary. The editors of the newspapers which have attacked the Treasurer no doubt travel to Melbourne or Sydney to meet as editors or chiefs of staff. Who pays for their board, their units and their motels? Do the individual editors pay for them? Of course not. These expenses are paid for by the employer, and it is only right that the Treasurer should have his costs met too. I think that all the members of the Government agree with the principle, but that is not the issue. We are talking about double standards. The Opposition is accusing one of our Ministers of doing something wrong. As I have said, the honourable member for Gwydir is in the House, and I hope that he speaks in this debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Standing order 76 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
I point out to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the position of the Deputy Leader of the National Party has nothing to do with the situation relating to the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair is very much aware of standing order 76. I do not think that the honourable member for Capricornia has contravened it but he should watch the comments that he makes in relation to the matter he is raising.

—I certainly shall, Mr Deputy Speaker. You will note that I have raised this matter by way of a question, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I have not heard a denial from the other side. There have been many attempts to shut me up. I have had the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) trying to shut me up by raising a point of order. We had the National Party Whip trying to shut us up but we have not heard the honourable member for Gwydir deny it. Why will he not deny it? Let us find out because that has been the attack. That is what we have heard in the rantings and ravings for the last three days against our Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). So let us really see who has double standards. Let us go further because the Leader of the Opposition talked about the fringe benefits tax. He talked about how he cannot support it. We know what he has said in the past. I know he is castigating everybody for the stand taken on the fringe benefits tax but not once has he mentioned that during the National Taxation Summit which was held in Canberra from 1 July 1985 to 4 July 1985, the Hon. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Premier and Treasurer of Queensland, produced this document. Honourable members will notice that there is the crest of the Queensland Parliament and the Government on it. This document is very interesting because in summary the recommendations refer to a single tax rate of 25 per cent. I will mention that later as that has become part of the Income Tax Rates Bill. His third recommendation, as Premier of the conservative State of Queensland is-listen to this-a fringe benefits tax. That is what he says. It is here in black and white. But have honourable members heard the Leader of the Opposition discount it? That is said by the Leader of the Government in Queensland, the Hon. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen; not only that but he goes on and says-this is in black and white in a government document, produced by that Government and presented to the conference-there will be `a fringe benefits tax on the beneficiary . . .'. The document goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: (but with employers to be required to record such benefits on group certificates).

Can honourable members imagine that? We talk about section 26 (e). We talk about the rorts and the rigging that goes on, and here is the Premier of Queensland saying this. I might say that I have tried to raise this issue before. It has been put in many Press releases by the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Neville Warburton, and by me in Queensland, but for some reason the newspapers have not run it. They have left this passage out of all the releases we have put out. Let the Leader of the Opposition in this House explain his attitude to this. Does he now disagree with the Premier of Queensland? Does he disagree with the idea put forward by the National Party Government in that State? Does the Leader of the National Party agree with this, because we have heard him talk about his attitude to the fringe benefits tax? Do we have some conflict here? Do we have a State National Party Government promoting one thing and the Federal National Party promoting something else? Let us hear about the double standards and the conflict and the two types of views, because we have it here in black and white.

I have said before that this Opposition, when in government, was a government of double standards. This is the Opposition which, when in government, placed an intolerable tax burden on the majority of honest Australians. I notice when the Leader of the Opposition was speaking he made some comparisons of what it was like under the Liberal-National Party Government and what it has been like under the Hawke Government. Let us put the facts on the record. Back under the Howard Government an employee earning $16,380 paid an average tax of 21.6 per cent. So that meant that if he was earning that sort of money he would pay $67.99 in tax per week. Under the Hawke Government, with its proposals, as honourable members will appreciate, in stages 2 and 3 which are now being implemented by this legislation, a person earning $16,380 will pay 17.7 per cent average tax. That is a drop of $12.30 a week. Let us look at an employee earning $18,221. Under the Howard Government the average tax was 22.5c in the dollar. So that person paid $78.61 every week. Under the Hawke Government that would be 18.8 per cent, a drop of $12.67 a week. We must appreciate that this is what happened under the Howard-Fraser Government, but let us keep calling it the Howard Government so people will remember. A nurse was paying 22.8 per cent average tax under that Government. Under the Hawke Government that is down to 19.2 per cent, a saving of $12.81. A teacher on $23,000 a year under the Howard Government paid an average tax of 27.4 per cent. Under the Hawke Government that person pays 23.8 per cent. Managers on $30,000, whom the Opposition say they represent, under the Howard Government paid 31 per cent or 31c for every dollar they earned. Under the Hawke Government they would pay 26.7c in the dollar.

It is important that people start to appreciate just what we are doing. Yet we find that this is the Opposition that says that it does not want any of the changes we are putting forward. In fact it will cast them out lock, stock and barrel. But what is it putting in instead? It is talking about bringing in a flat tax system. It talks about double standards. We heard the Leader of the National Party say that he wanted to introduce a flat tax of 20 per cent. But what did Mr Howard say? I will quote from a report on him in the Canberra Times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that he should refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his title of Leader of the Opposition.
—I refer to the comments made by the Leader of the Opposition, on 5 February 1981 in the Canberra Times. He referred to this whole concept of a flat tax and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Eighty per cent of Australian workers would be forced on to a higher tax scale if the National Party's flat tax proposal was introduced.

He went on to say that the 20 per cent flat tax rate suggested by the Nationals would cause a shortfall of $7 billion in government revenue in the first year. Now we find that the Leader of the Opposition is supporting the concept of a flat tax. We wonder from day to day what the Opposition is going to come forward with next. We also note that it does not understand what is really taking place here. In Rockhampton on the weekend the New Right talked about changes in the tax rate. Its members were arguing about the changes, quite unaware of what this Government is already doing in that area. They are totally unaware that in 1984 we had already changed the 30 per cent marginal tax rate and brought it down to 25 per cent. We are also now changing the total tax system. Why are we doing this? We are doing it to give that incentive, to give people the reason to work harder, to increase productivity. That is what we are about, yet the likes of Prue Acton and Paul Terry standing up and calling for changes in the tax system do not know what is going on. I ask the Treasurer please to put together a package and send it to Prue Acton, to Paul Terry, to Maurice Binsted and to a few of these others so that they can start to understand what we are about.

Let the people understand too because there is some confusion, I tell honourable members and Mr Deputy Speaker, as to what really takes place. I was at a place called Moranbah recently and a teacher came up to me and said that she was paying 60c in the dollar in tax. She presented me with her group certificate, which showed that she had earned $24,700 for the year. I looked at the group certificate and saw that the tax she had paid was $6,300. I said `What is the percentage?' and she said `25 per cent' and swallowed it. She did not really understand that there is an average tax system. People do not understand today what the Hawke Labor Government is doing. They do not understand the tax system. There has been confusion amongst the people as they do not understand the difference between an average tax and a marginal tax rate. But let them appreciate just what we are doing. The marginal tax rate of 30 per cent will drop to 29 per cent; the marginal tax rates of 46 per cent and 43 per cent will, by July next year, go down to 40 per cent; those on 48 per cent will go right down to 40 per cent also in July next year; and the top marginal tax rate, the one that hurts a lot of people in my own area, such as the coal miners and others, will drop from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. We are addressing the problems and we do not have the double standard that the Opposition has.

Let me conclude, because my time is going. Let the Opposition tell us about the double standards which we have heard today. Let the honourable member for Gwydir now come out and tell us about his travel allowance. Let him respond to this Parliament as to what he has really been doing in claiming for his travel allowance when he has a principal place of residence in the northern part of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. The honourable member who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), said that I was in the same situation as the Treasurer (Mr Keating). That does misrepresent the position. My place of residence is my property, Dunumbral. It is my home at Collarenebri, 130 miles west of Moree. It is served by daily air services on weekdays. I represent one of the largest electorates in New South Wales. I spend as much time there as my parliamentary duties allow, including holidays and weekends when not on electoral or parliamentary business. I might say that during parliamentary sittings and official business in this place I need to be in Canberra, like most parliamentary members, and I claim an entitlement for overnight allowances, as I am entitled to do. I think that the honourable member ought to recognise that all the honourable members do it. I am at my home base, my place of residence, from time to time as duties permit. I maintain an active and close involvement in the running of my property. I am not there as much as I would like but I am there as much as my duties permit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After 20 minutes of huff and bluff by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) we still have the heaviest taxing government in our history. The Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill bring major changes to the way in which Australians are slugged by income tax. The Government is claiming kudos for being a great reformer of the taxation system in this country. Let us have a quick look at these great reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the introduction of a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax, massive hikes in sales tax and taxes on fuel. These taxes separately, and combined, have the effect of stifling investment, killing incentive, reducing employment opportunities and strangling the ability of major industries to compete in the market-place at a time when conditions are already most difficult, particularly in the rural areas of Australia. The Government has searched for new items to tax. We now even have a tax on the kitchen sink and, worse still, on the septic tank. The result of all these tax reforms is that Australians are now more heavily taxed than at any other time since World War II.

One of the Bills before us today is the sweetener designed to help us forget the incredible new tax burdens elsewhere. This Bill will give taxpayers earning less than $19,500 in 1986-87 the tax saving of less than one lousy cent in the dollar. I have seen people walk past a cent and not even bend over to pick it up because of the way inflation is going in this country. The majority of Australians on the average wage will receive a tax reduction of less than 2c.

TALK.START.PARA: —About the same value as a Halfpenny.
—About the same value as a Halfpenny. Those taxpayers on the top marginal rate will save less than 3c in the dollar in the 1986-87 financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other Bills before us today-the Medicare Levy Bill-increases the Medicare levy by 25 per cent, thus reducing markedly the already minute cuts in personal income tax rates. That is another broken promise. The long awaited personal tax cuts have been effectively wiped out by the new tax increases announced in the Budget. The increase in the Medicare levy, sales taxes and fuel excises alone will raise $1.4 billion in 1986-87. So much for the statements by the honourable member for Capricornia. It is ordinary Australians who will provide this tax money. The inescapable fact is that the Hawke Labor Government is a big spending, big taxing government. We see examples of this every day as we move around our electorates and Australia. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the greatest tax gatherer this country has ever known. His latest Budget will collect 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product in tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—Some 25 per cent of GDP will be collected in tax.
—There is not much left for the rest of us.

—There is not much left to get this country on the road again. This is an all time record high level. The real problem is the Government's continued refusal to attack expenditure. It is prepared only to nibble around the edges like mice around a wheat stack. Government expenditure under the Hawke Government has increased by 3.9 per cent per year in real terms. This is almost double the seven-year average of the previous Liberal-National Party Government. The Government's latest Budget has the fourth highest expenditure level in post-war Australia. The three highest were the previous Budgets of the Hawke Government. It is little wonder ordinary Australians are staggering under the tax burden imposed by this Government. It is the ordinary pay as you earn and income taxpayers who are bearing the greatest load.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said earlier this week that we could learn from countries overseas. Instead of looking to countries such as Sweden, the highest taxing nation in the Western world, we should be following the example of countries such as the United States of America which are significantly reducing personal income tax levels. We must move towards a much lower and flatter personal income tax system in order to restore incentive to the ordinary Australian worker. People in Australia who rely on transport over long distances for the supply of goods and services-people such as those living in the electorate of Riverina-Darling, Gwydir and other electorates--

TALK.START.PARA: —Farrer.
—Richmond and Farrer--
—They are the salt of the earth.

—They are the salt of the earth-and those who use fuel in producing their incomes are being particularly savaged by the Hawke Government through its indecent levels of taxation on fuel. The amount of excise on petroleum products has risen from $1,293m in 1982-83 to an estimated staggering $5,644m in 1986-87. If that were in the pockets of the everyday Australian, imagine what he could do with it. This represents an increase of 336 per cent. The Government must, as a matter of priority, reduce the dependence on fuel as a source of revenue. The heavy taxation of fuel is a significant drain on the income of many Australians, especially those living in rural areas who must travel large distances.

SPEECH.PARA: A classic example of the Government's greed is the recent decision on fuel prices which will result in an effective increase of 6.5c per litre in the actual cost of distillate used on farms in the space of one month. This represents an increase of 24 per cent. Imagine an increase of 24 per cent in one month. The Government has done a neat fiddle. Instead of the change in the tax on fuel being revenue neutral, as the Government claims, the Treasury has actually gained, as less tax will rebated to farmers. Fuel costs represent an average of 8 per cent on total input costs in agricultural industries. With most of our primary industries facing long hauls to the coast for markets and export the high level of tax on fuel represents a tax on our export industries. The only taxes on fuel should be those to support road programs such as the Australian land transport program and the bicentennial road development program introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt).

The present Government will long be remembered for the record level of taxation it has imposed on all Australians. Not content with excessively taxing the Australian people, the Government is now responsible for the situation where ordinary law abiding citizens are being harassed by the Australian Taxation Office and forced to pay massive fees to challenge a Taxation Office decision. I refer, of course, to reports of tax officials harassing small businesses in order to obtain information for the ill-founded fringe benefits tax and the Budget decision to charge a $200 filing fee to refer an objection to a Taxation Office decision to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Going on the reports I have had of the fringe benefits tax, it could be that another 2,000 public servants will have to be put on. Obviously the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are not satisfied with being the greatest tax gatherers this country has known. They are determined to bludgeon every possible tax dollar out of Australians and they will make it as difficult as possible for anyone to have returned to him any moneys wrongly collected.

In the last few days I have contacted many primary producers, small business people and salary and wage earners in my electorate. Their common cry is: `Get off our backs with your high taxing policy so we, in turn, can get on with trying to produce some wealth for our nation'. The Australian people will not be fooled by the largely illusory tax cuts embodied in these Bills. They all know that this Government is gathering tax at record levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make two points about the speech of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). First, it is a typical example of what we have heard repeatedly from speakers on the other side and that is it misrepresents the level of the tax cuts which are being brought in by this Government. He mentioned a 1c cut on the marginal tax rate, a tax reduction from 26c to 25c in the dollar. What he failed to say was that this Government had already introduced a 4c cut in the marginal rate of tax from 30 per cent which is what we had when the Opposition was in government. Let us look at the matter. This Government has brought in a 5c in the dollar reduction on the marginal rate of tax, a reduction of 16 per cent. That is something of which we are proud but it is something about which the Opposition does not want to talk.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the honourable member for Riverina-Darling leaves the chamber he may be interested to learn the important thing he did not say. Not once did we hear any defence to the claims by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), has drawn very healthy travelling allowances while he has his principal home in Canberra. We have no quibble with that because the Remuneration Tribunal set the standards and the rates relating to that and we accept them.

I return to the major part of my contribution. I remind the Parliament that the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill introduce another portion of the Government's tax reform package which has brought greater equity and fairness to a tax system which had earned the disrespect and disaffection of the Australian people. This is no wonder, because of the rorts that had gone on and the inequitable load placed on lower wage and salary earners through the tax scales that we inherited from the Opposition. I remind the House that that package was revenue neutral. It took not one cent, not one dollar more from the people than it was giving. It was a redistribution of the load of taxation that is the hallmark of that tax package. For far too long the pay as you earn taxpayers, partnerships, small unincorporated businesses, have had to pay more than their fair share of tax in a system which worked against them.

The reductions in personal income tax scales which will restore to taxpayers some $4.5 billion on 1 December this year and 1 July next year are a big move to redress the imbalance and to spread taxes more fairly across the economy. These reductions are possible only because of the Government's moves to eliminate the inequities and abuses in our tax system and the demonstrated ability of this Government to equitably and responsibly restrain expenditures. Far from what the honourable member for Riverina-Darling had to say, this Government has shown that it can reduce Forward Estimates, forward outlays, Budget spending, by a huge $4 billion and so come into this House with a Budget deficit of $3.5 billion, which stands in stark contrast to the $9 billion that the present Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer, gave to this House as his legacy as the world's worst Treasurer.

Despite the bleatings from some sections of business that they are overtaxed, a glance at the Budget receipts indicates that PAYE taxpayers will still carry the major burden. Unfortunately, it is still over half of the total revenue. When we add the sales tax and the import duties that are usually passed on to the purchaser-with, incidentally, margins added to them by business-we find another 15 per cent. But the company tax contribution is still less than 10 per cent. The fringe benefits tax-I will talk more about that later-of which we have heard so much contributes only one-fifth of one per cent to government revenue. PAYE taxpayers will receive $4.5 billion in tax cuts, not only through cuts in the marginal rates of tax but also through an increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100. This will have immediate and direct benefit to the lowest income earners, the pensioners and those on small superannuations, and it will ease the poverty traps for pensioners earning a little to help themselves. The cuts in the marginal rates of tax are such that by 1 July no one, no PAYE taxpayer-in fact, no tax levels-will pay more than 50 per cent of salary as tax. No portion, no extra dollar that they earn will carry more than 50 per cent tax.

The average rate of tax is substantially lower. The Opposition has been less than honest to the public in the big tax debate. It has attempted to confuse people, as the honourable member for Capricornia so adequately said, by obscuring the difference between marginal rates of tax and average rates of tax. The Opposition's obvious love affair with the flat rate of tax set at, according to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), 20 per cent and, according to the Premier of Queensland, at 25 per cent, without a tax-free threshold has superficial attraction. Even the most cursory glance, the most casual examination, will show that only the highest paid people would benefit from a flat rate because for the vast majority of people it would mean a huge increase in tax; for example, average weekly wage earners on some $18,000 would be paying under that proposal some 8 per cent more-$8 more in every $100 that they earn. The Opposition's proposal would hit hardest those who are protected now by the tax-free threshold, the pensioners, the small superannuitants, and those in poverty traps.

The Opposition talks about how high taxes dull incentive, but it never did anything about the high rates of marginal tax while it was in office. I repeat, no one will pay more than 49c on any extra dollar earned. That will be a boost to incentive. Actually, it has never been proved that high tax rates remove incentive or create incentive to work harder. A higher income is not the only thing that turns people on and drives people; there are other rewards in life, such as job satisfaction, achievement and pride. But they are not the sort of values we hear praised and inculcated by the Opposition. No, it is the mighty dollar that drives it, and it is the mighty dollar tax cheats who drive its policies. (Quorum formed)

This Government's reasons for the tax cuts are based more on restoring equity and justice to the tax system so that the public will regain their confidence in the tax system itself. Furthermore, it removes another incentive-the incentive to cheat, the incentive to devise tax schemes to avoid paying a fair share of tax and ultimately to cheat the community. If I could borrow from the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), his now infamous phrase about fringe benefits tax, I could parody the current Leader of the Opposition. He says he wants to make the tax issue an issue for the next 18 months-a challenge we are more than ready to accept. He would be going around the country saying: `Vote for me if you want tax cheats. Vote for me if you want tax evasion, and vote for Labor if you want a tax system with equity and fairness'.

Anyone who has any doubts about the equity and proper nature of the fringe benefits tax should read the editorial in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 12 August this year. That editorial is a fine exposition of why that tax is essential, why it will work and why it will bring equity to the tax system. It is unfortunate that time does not allow me to quote it.

One thing that is clear in this debate is that the Opposition must come clean on its approach to the fringe benefits tax. It must explain how it will reduce income tax rates if at the same time it also repeals the measures we have introduced to reduce or banish tax evasion. If it allows tax evasion again to prosper through the removal of capital gains legislation and if it reintroduces untaxed perks through negative gearing on property, the only conclusion is that ordinary wage and salary earners-PAYE taxpayers-will bear a higher burden of tax and tax rates will rise. The other alternative is to cut important Government programs such as child care, health, education, road funding, defence and social security pensions. It cannot have it both ways. It has become clear that the Opposition cannot keep its promises because they are false promises. It has attempted to whip up a campaign against the fringe benefits tax in order to appease the new far Right, but in fact it has realised that the ordinary public has accepted the justice of the fringe benefits tax.

Where does the Opposition stand on the question of the fringe benefits tax? The facts are that the pretenders opposite have indicated on more than one occasion that they would have a fringe benefits tax of their own. On 30 July the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that the fringe benefits tax `would be dealt with in another fashion'. On 20 August the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), said that the coalition would `feel justified in being tougher on taxing those sorts of (fringe) benefits'. On 27 August he again said that the coalition would remove the fringe benefits tax and `then we would be back with the old law which, in fact, imposed a tax on the employee for a benefit received'. So where does the Opposition stand? It will not clarify the situation because it thinks it is on a winner, but I tell the Opposition that it is not. The people are not naive enough to accept the hypocrisy of the Opposition and will treat it as irrelevant until it comes clean.

My belief is that the Opposition will stick to Labor's fringe benefits tax, should it ever unfortunately gain government, because it is administratively simpler and easier for the employer to calculate. These tax cuts and the new lower marginal rates of tax will provide a big stimulus to the economy. Increased spending power means increased demand which, when coupled with improved local competitiveness through devaluation, efficiency and the Government's Buy Australia campaign, will mean a greater demand for Australian produced goods. In turn, this means higher employment, as predicted so properly by the recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development statement, and less call on the unemployment benefit. The tax cuts are part of the Government's recipe for the Australian revival and I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member for Stretton that this Opposition will be pleased to take the Government on over the next 18 months on the fringe benefits tax. It is an absurdly complex tax; it is an anti-business and anti-employment tax. It is a tax which impinges on football club prizes, safety awards, retirement benefits, compulsory accommodation and food for farm workers under awards, religious institutions and some charities.
—Shame!
—Of course it impinges on such things, as the honourable member for Denison recognises. I can assure the honourable member for Stretton that the Australian people will not have a bar of this tax.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is becoming increasingly unbearable. My electorate is Streeton, not Stretton.

—I am pleased to correctly call the honourable gentleman the honourable member for Streeton. The principal aspect of the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986 and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 is to set out the tax scales that the Government is proposing to implement as part of its `reform package'. There is to be one instalment on 1 December and a second instalment on 1 July next year. As I have said before, I have the gravest doubts that the second instalment will ever see the light of day, for the reasons that I recently set out in my speech on the Budget. I will come back to that, but let me make the point that even if it is introduced, we will still have a tax scale where the top marginal rate of 50.25c in the dollar comes in at $35,000. So 50.25c of every extra dollar earned or increase in income above that level will go in tax. I say 50.25 deliberately; it is made up by the 49c in the proposed formal tax scale and the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy. Anyone who has completed a tax form since Labor assumed office knows how real that additional one percentage point, or now 1.25 percentage points, of tax on the whole of a taxable income is. So we are talking about a situation where over half of any additional income or increase in income will still go in tax.

SPEECH.PARA: That rate is certainly better than the 61.25 per cent that prevails at present. I concede that the 60 per cent rate was bequeathed from the previous Government. Its efforts to reduce that rate were thwarted when it sought to change the mix between the direct and the indirect tax package. However, that is in the past and nothing changes the fact that either 61.25 per cent or 50.25 per cent-the great reform rate that we may get next year-is too high. It is exploitative and immoral. It is--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is robbery.

—It is robbery and it elicits an immoral response. When a government appropriates 61 per cent or 50 per cent plus of earnings in this way it is strongly resisted and taxpayers in this range inevitably get into avoidance or evasion in one form or another, including fringe benefits. If we reformed the tax scale, the need to do something about fringe benefits, but never this Government's fringe benefits tax, would be greatly reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I will recount the way in which this tax scale has changed over the years. In 1954-55, as I am sure the honourable member for Streeton would know, the maximum rate came in at something like 18 times average earnings. That would be equivalent today to an income of the order of $400,000 per annum. As recently as 1972 the maximum rate came in at the equivalent of an income of $100,000, but today the maximum rate comes in at $35,000. I say without equivocation that the Liberal and National parties' pledge is to do better than this Keating scale. It is not for me in this debate to second guess the Opposition's tax policy in this respect, but I would say that if we could not implement a tax rate in this range of income at significantly less than half of every additional dollar going to the Government, which will create incentive effects of a significant order, we would certainly be failing the aspirations of so many Australians out there who want to see this country go ahead, who are ready and willing to put in the effort and to take additional risks, and to increase productivity, provided that the Government does not make off with half or more of the additional rewards.

I have been focusing on that top end of the proposed rate scale but the honourable member for Streeton also made reference to the other end of the scale-the no tax threshold. In the proposed new scale, the no tax threshold-the first point on the tax scale, the level of income up to which no tax is paid-is increased from $4,595 to $5,100. I believe that is a retrograde step. Whilst the existence of the no-tax threshold has certain administrative and other advantages, it is subject to a major criticism. I quote from the Government's draft White Paper, `Reform of the Australian Taxation System', published last year. Section 11.4 on page 110 states:

As a means of providing that low income earners do not bear tax . . . the tax-free threshold is a very expensive concession in terms of taxation revenue forgone since all taxpayers enjoy the threshold regardless of size of income. It is, moreover, a generous concession in that many taxpayers with a low taxable income (e.g. second income earners in a family, students working part time, part-year workers, large wealth holders) are not genuinely needy in the sense of having to rely solely on that income for support.

I believe that is a very important point. I draw the attention of the House to the Monash University Centre for Policy Studies, which took up this line of thought and came up, last year, at the time of the National Taxation Summit, with its option D. Option D abolishes the no-tax threshold except for the genuinely low income needy, and imposes on everybody else tax on `first dollars' thereby enabling reduced rates of tax on `last dollars'. In this way it could provide for a tax rate scale of 20c in the dollar for incomes up to $20,000 per annum; 30c in the dollar for incomes from $20,000 to $35,000; and a maximum rate of 40c in the dollar for incomes of $35,000 and above. It achieves this while at the same time yielding much the same total revenue, but without the necessity for the fringe benefits tax or any of the other so-called `reform' measures of the Hawke Government. I am not suggesting that there are not bugs in attempting to proceed along those lines, but it is certainly a proposal worth considering.

I come back to a point I mentioned earlier. The Government, in putting before us this legislation providing for tax scales to be implemented, hopefully on 1 December and again on 1 July next year, is engaging in little short of an act of bravado. The probability that the Government will actually implement these cuts in the light of the deficit situation likely to prevail next year is very low. The honourable member for Streeton referred to the hoary old charge that the former Government passed on to this Government a large deficit. I will not take the time to refute that charge at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.

—It is definitely not true. The honourable member then referred to the current Budget deficit of $3.5 billion. That deficit is undoubtedly a phoney. As I have previously argued in this House, the $3.5 billion deficit is due to the significant increase in indirect taxes but also to a number of one-off items such as the deferral of the very tax changes before the House, which involves a saving of $650 million which will not be available next year. Also a major component of the one-off profit of the Reserve Bank of Australia, about $600 million, will not recur if the Government's policy is successful. Further the Government's expenditure cuts add up to some $500m less in 1987-88 than this year because of changes in timing this year. So if one takes those factors into consideration, and there are others, the underlying deficit this year is in excess of $5 billion. The Government is telling us that on top of that it will implement tax changes at a cost of an additional $3 billion. This will mean that the Government will enter next year with an underlying or implied deficit of the order of $8 billion. I say this to underline the very high probability that, given this situation, the likelihood of the Government going ahead with these tax changes is very slight.
—It is not the first time they have broken promises.

—The Government has a history of broken promises, as my colleague says. Even with these changes, the average wage earner will still be paying tax at a higher marginal and average tax rate than he was when the Hawke Government came to power. That is the impact on the individual of the fact that this Government is the biggest taxing government ever. In March 1983, the single person had an average tax rate of 22.9 per cent and a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent. In July 1987, even if these changes have been implemented, the average taxpayer will be on an average tax rate of 24.5 per cent and a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent.
—It has gone up.

—It is going up. It has gone up continuously from the time the Government acceded to office. Even if the Government implements these changes, a significant increase will still prevail. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out, this is the biggest taxing government ever. Fourteen new taxes have been introduced: The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the entertainment tax, the removal of negative gearing provisions, the lump sum superannuation tax, the increased company tax rate, new wholesale taxes, increased petrol excise, the automatic biannual indexation of product excise rates, the wine tax, and so on. I will not continue the list.
—What a record.

—As my colleague says, what a record. This is the biggest taxing government, imposing the biggest variety of taxes, one could possibly imagine. We have the proposed new tax scales. While they are some improvement on what is available now, it is imperative for the future productive development of the country that marginal tax rates really be reduced. Under the policies of this Government, that is not going to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) have again suggested that the Hawke Government is the biggest taxing government in the history of this country. However, we need to remember two important things about the figures they cite. The first is that if one extracts the Medicare payments, which are only a substitute for private health payments, and one looks at the figures then, the biggest taxing Treasurer in the history of this country is the honourable member for Bennelong, who taxed at a rate of 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product. The other important factor one must remember is that there are now half a million more taxpayers in this country than there were then. So significantly more people are paying tax now than were previously as a result of the success of this Government in the area of unemployment. I suppose that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) would be annoyed that the honourable member for Bennelong was setting the agenda for the next election in his speech. It seems to us on this side of the House that, by the time of the next election, the honourable member for Kooyong most likely will have hold of the reins of Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, a taxpayer who earns $35,000 pays tax at a rate of 60c in the dollar. Thirty-five years ago, in 1985 dollar terms, the 60c rate did not cut in until one earned $400,000, which I am sure all would agree would apply to only very wealthy persons. Thirty years ago, a person on average weekly earnings paid tax at 19c in the dollar. He now pays tax at 46c in the dollar. Thirty years ago, one per cent of the population paid tax at 46c in the dollar. Nowadays, more than 40 per cent of the population pay tax at that rate.

That is the legacy that was left to the Government by the Opposition. The tax structure was limping. The tax system had become unfair. Oppressive marginal rates encouraged dishonesty and produced cheats and rorters. Tax avoidance and tax evasion was a national pastime. Indeed, it was a scandal in this country. The Opposition had its chance. The honourable member for Berowra said that when the Opposition is in government-God forbid that should ever happen-it will do better; it will decrease the marginal rates by more than this Government intends in the legislation. However, the Opposition had the best chance ever to restructure the tax system in this country and it did not take it.

I have in front of me a set of tables prepared by the Statistics Group of the Parliamentary Library which sets out Commonwealth taxation collections-pay as you earn taxation collections, prescribed payments, company tax, sales tax, crude oil excise duty, other excise duty, customs duty, other taxes, and total taxes. The tables set out taxation collections from the year 1970-71 to 1986-87. If one looks at the figures in all of those categories, one finds that only one new tax came into evidence during the Fraser Government's term in office. There were others, of course, but the significant one was the crude oil excise duty. Between the time that the Fraser Government came into office and 1980-81, that duty went from zero per cent of total tax collections to 9.6 per cent of tax collections. It brought the former Government a $3 billion windfall taxation collection. During that time, it had the best chance that any government ever had in this country to reform the taxation system. It did not take the chance; it spent the money. Unfortunately, I suppose the system became addicted to the money. I seek leave to have the tables incorporated in Hansard.
