TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The package of measures that the Hawke Government has introduced is an attempt to share the load in tax, to provide some fairness, and to prevent and remove perks for the privileged. It is an opportunity to allow for a more effective allocation of the nation's resources. Expensive goods and services, not necessarily of good quality but for which employers did not have to pay the full value, which were subsidised by taxpayers, were the norm. That was a way in which resources could be allocated very ineffectively. The package is an opportunity for the Government to restore incentive by lowering the marginal tax rates. Significant cuts in personal taxation, which were announced in September 1985, are the thrust of the legislation. There is an increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100. There are significant tax rate reductions to be implemented on 1 December 1986 and further marginal taxation rate reductions on 1 July 1987. The top rate, as of that date, will be 49c in the dollar. The changes will have the effect of reducing, by about 5 per cent, the tax paid by most workers in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is that important? It is important because it provides incentive. The coalition has said that it is happy to attach its wagon to the engine of incentive to pull it into the station. Where does incentive start and greed and avarice take over when one considers the Opposition's policies? It wants to bring back all the rorts. The Government wants a fair system, a progressive system, without oppressive marginal rates. It wants a system which encourages enterprise, and capital investment and which has a functional economic purpose; not money that is misdirected to a tax haven. It wants business to make a profit but pay its fair share of tax. It does not want business to direct its efforts to the avoidance of taxation.

The fundamentals have been put in place by the Government. We have provided an environment of wage stability and responsible wage outcomes. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures show that in the years 1983 to 1985 Australia had significantly better results in terms of real annual wage changes than a number of other countries. The real annual wage change in Australia was minus 5.3 per cent in that time. In the United States of America, it was minus 0.6 per cent; in Japan, it was plus 5.8 per cent; in Germany, it was plus 3.8 per cent; in France, it was plus 3.1 per cent; and in the United Kingdom, it was plus 10.9 per cent.

Australia has a competitive and a responsible wage structure. The devaluation, perhaps the boldest policy move the Government has made, has provided us with a 40 per cent improvement in our pricing structure. These reduced marginal rates-the thrust of the Bill-will provide more incentive to be productive and to earn profits. We have removed the double taxation on dividends. We have removed the Division 7 profits retention tax on small business. We are providing incentive for business. We want to reward business with profit. We do not want to reward it with a tax haven. It is important to quote an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, which is not, it is fair to say, a purveyor of socialist views or philosophies. It stated:

The pity is that, helped by some persistent politically motivated misinformation, the anomalies and unresolved questions about the tax have obscured its essentially equitable nature in eliminating privileged tax lurks.

No just argument can be advanced for allowing executives, self-employed businessmen or professionals to receive a significant proportion of their remuneration as a tax-free fiddle, when the vast bulk of PAYE taxpayers are taxed at the source and have no way of fiddling their tax to any extent.

The argument that small businessmen and executives are the most productive sector of the community and are therefore entitled to special tax treatment and incentives is just so much self-interested hogwash. One wonders just how productive an executive might be after a boozy and previously tax-deductible lunch. The reward for capitalist enterprise is profit, not a tax swindle.

That is the Government's view. That is the thrust of our moves on tax and the legislation. We hope to provide an environment in which business will be productive and will have the incentive to work hard and earn profits rather than rely on some sort of tax dodge.

Members of the Opposition have complained and whinged about the moves the Government has made in taxation areas. I shall consider one area, and that is the restaurant industry. With the implementation of the entertainment tax, there was much guffawing on the other side of the House. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) said that 80,000 jobs would be lost. All sorts of figures were thrown around. The honourable member revised the figure and said that 10,000 or 20,000 jobs would be lost.

What are the figures? I consulted the Statistics Group of the Parliamentary Library and came up with the following figures. In the year prior to the introduction of the entertainment tax, there was 3.4 per cent growth in employment in the restaurant industry. Subsequent to the introduction of the tax on entertainment, there has been 6.5 per cent growth in the hotel and restaurant industry. Clearly, since then, 11,500 new jobs have been created in that area. The suggestion by Opposition members that the restaurant industry should be underpinned by some sort of a tax rort, that the motor vehicle industry should be underpinned by some sort of a tax swindle and that the building industry needs negative gearing to survive is absurd. It is one of the problems that, for many years, have been part of the malaise in this country. Scarce investment capital has been directed towards unproductive means of expenditure. As a result, many rorts have become institutionalised and there is a belief in the community that perhaps they should remain forever.

This Government wants to provide incentive. The Opposition had the chance, in the race to provide incentives, to provide a better and fairer system of taxation. However, it came stone cold motherless last. We want to reward effort with profit and not with a tax fiddle. We have put in place an environment which provides a far fairer system. We have restored Australia's competitive edge. We have put in place marginal tax rates which are much superior to those that existed previously. We have a full imputation system coming along for business. On the expenditure side, we have provided a leaner and more efficient economy.

The Opposition had the opportunity to reform the taxation system. It did not take the chance. If it does not like this legislation, let it tell the people that it wants to replace all the rorts and put the marginal rates back to where they were. But I think the Opposition supports this legislation. It does not want to be responsible for putting up marginal rates as high as they were when we took office, and I have great pride in urging that this legislation be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill are being treated as part of the package of tax reform legislation, and I shall give my assessment of it as a total package. If the policies reflect anything, they reflect the policies of envy, greed and hate of this Labor Government, policies against the productive sector. If it is productive, the Government taxes it. If someone shows initiative, the Government taxes him. Certainly, if someone is wealthy, that is the final straw; he is taxed out of existence. Only a few months ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) condemned the people in this society whom he deemed to be wealthy as being an infringement against the conditions which he thought should apply at present. That is a sign that profit has become a dirty word. Initiative is to be taxed, and if someone wants to do something in this life, as an Australian, he has to fall out of the initiative and growth sector and into the web of social security.

SPEECH.PARA: This tax package tries to pull everyone down to a common denominator, but what Australia needs at present is lifting so that we can provide the initiative and growth that it so desperately wants. It is all reflected by the falling Australian dollar. This Labor Government will not be happy until the dollar is worth a halfpenny-and he is likely to be here within a couple of months, depending on when the election occurs.

The legislation deals with rates of tax-with what is left to a taxpayer after he has earned his income, bought his goods and carried out the normal weekly activities of work and expenditure. I must say that there is less money in the pocket of the taxpayer now than there was three, six, 10 or 20 years ago, as this Government goes on its crazy path of expenditure on this, that and the other, without taking into consideration what is required to assist the economy's growth. In 1970, someone earning 14 times average weekly earnings was likely to be caught in the high marginal rate, whereas today I understand that about one-tenth of that, or 1.5 times average weekly earnings, will take one into the top bracket. Where is the encouragement? Where is the initiative? Where will the growth come from in a tax system like that?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no incentive.

—There is no incentive in a high taxation regime such as this. Let us look at what high taxation does to an economy. Quite apart from the disincentives and the nil growth that I have mentioned, it is an encouragement to tax avoidance, a positive encouragement to tax evasion and an encouragement to those systems through which people try to take, as part of a package, a benefit instead of something in the hand. What the Government claims its package is designed to avoid will still exist. It is just not on. It is just not economics, and it is a sign that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister and the Government as a whole have no real idea of where they are going or where this package will end up.

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning of his presentation of this tax package, the Treasurer said that the Government was aiming for simplicity, fairness and equity. I recall that, in January 1985, the Treasurer announced that there would be a fringe benefits tax on employees. The next day, Cliff Dolan said `No, you will not tax the employee', and the day after that the Treasurer came out and said: `We will tax the employer as per the New Zealand scheme'. Incidentally, the New Zealand fringe benefits scheme is collecting only about 15 to 20 per cent of the tax that it was expected to collect. Obviously, the Treasurer's position is flexible. He is prepared to change from one end to the other. In his presentation of the tax package, he said that the Government would pull down the marginal rate of taxation to 49c, and then it will be everyone's obligation to pay the tax on what he earns because of the reduced rate. I thought he meant that an employee with a tax package with fringe benefits would be the person called upon to pay the tax on the benefits he received. But what happened? He put the tax on the employers. That shows the Government's desire to penalise business and the growth sector of the economy. The policies of hate and of envy are more evident in this fringe benefits tax than in anything else.

At the moment, the Government is running scared. It comes in here day after day trying to justify its fringe benefits tax. I am afraid that the task is not to persuade its own back bench members about where it stands on fringe benefits tax. The task is to go out in the community and understand how those people will suffer from compliance with the fringe benefits taxation as from the collection date of 1 November. I would be surprised if the Treasurer could not get an engagement every hour of the day and every day of the week throughout the country addressing those people, hearing what their requirements are and hearing how they are suffering. But, no; he is prepared to stay at home with his travelling allowance in Canberra. Even the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has said that the whole strategy is wrong in the area over which he has jurisdiction. I suggest to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that they should not lecture us across the table about something that we know is patently dishonest and wrong. They should get out into the community and tell the people out there. That is where the argument will be lost at the next election, because one thing is clear: The Government will be put out.

I ask only one question on taxation, and I have some references here to living away from home. Under the substantiation law-of course, this is something new-and under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the major thing about the living away from home allowance is defining the place of abode. Section 51 states that the usual place of abode of an employee is the place where he has his family. As I understand it, the substantiation rule suggests that the travelling allowance relates to travel away from an employee's ordinary place of residence. It goes on in relation to board of review decisions to suggest that under section 51 a man's residence where he lives with his family and sleeps at night is always his place of abode. My question is this: If a living away from home allowance or a travel allowance is paid to a person who is not living away from his residence but is in his normal abode, is that not a living at home allowance? The question that I ask the Government is whether, under those circumstances, that allowance is taxable. The professionalism of the taxation officers would suggest that, under the definition of section 51 in the Treasurer's own legislation, the travelling allowance should be taxed because it is not a living away from home allowance. Despite the legislation brought in by the Treasurer and despite the precedents in the Act, I would certainly like to know the answer to that.

This tax package is anything but simple, equitable and fair. When we have 140 pages of legislation of just one tax, it cannot be simple. I appeal to the Australian Taxation Office to realise the costs involved and the imposition on the tax-collecting sector-that is, business people and tax agents, who are being pressed to the limit while trying to comply with these Acts. The Government has paid little regard to their requirements. I am asking for a bit more professionalism from the Taxation Office so that the tax agents can be helped to do their jobs.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to refer to a point of order taken by me during Question Time today, when the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) asked a question of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen). The question was similar to question No. 4681, which is listed on the Notice Paper at page 8874. Madam Speaker, you effectively ruled that it was in order for the honourable member to ask the question of the Minister without notice, notwithstanding the fact that a similar question was already on the Notice Paper. I realise, of course, that if dissent from your ruling were to be moved, it would have been necessary for this to have been attended to immediately. But, for the assistance of honourable members I believe that it would be advantageous if the matter were clarified.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker, contrary to your ruling, at page 496 of Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice there is a section dealing with repetition of questions. On page 497 the following words appear:
Questions without notice which are substantially the same as questions already on the Notice Paper are not permissible.

In view of the contents of Pettifer and in view of my discussions with you, I believe that it would be desirable for members of this place to receive clarification on what rules and practices are to be followed and are to apply in the future.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for giving me an opportunity to expand on my ruling. Members will appreciate that the main purpose of the practice of not permitting a question without notice to be asked which is substantially the same as one on the Notice Paper is to prevent the member who placed the question on the Notice Paper being disadvantaged and his question being pre-empted. A secondary consideration is that, if the Minister is able to answer the question without notice, obviously he should have answered the question on notice; but I do not think this consideration is of importance in this particular case.

INTERJECT.PARA: The point of order raised by the honourable member was essentially correct. But it seems to me that common sense and logic dictate that the practice is not intended to apply to a member in respect of his own question because the questions of disadvantage and of pre-empting do not arise. This is the reason I ruled as I did.

I should advise members that the practice grew up in a period when there were next to no questions on the Notice Paper and when, perhaps, the practice had more meaning and was easier to apply than it is now. There are doubts in my mind whether the practice has anything to commend it in today's House, when there are so many questions on the Notice Paper and when most questions without notice could well be out of order based on this practice. I feel that members today would not wish to restrict themselves in this way, particularly as some questions may remain on the Notice Paper from one year to the next. I hope that this ruling will be of assistance to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence. Would it be possible for this to be taken as an indication of your views on the matter at this stage? Obviously, if the ruling you have given tonight were to alter Pettifer's view, I am not sure that all members of the House would necessarily be satisfied with that. On behalf of the Opposition, I say that we note what you have said, but may we possibly reserve a view on this matter? It should, perhaps, be taken up at some length in another forum. A change to the Standing Orders may be considered--
—That, of course, would go before the Procedure Committee. All members of the House are advised and encouraged to put such matters before the Procedure Committee.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. That is what I had in mind. But it struck me that a particular ruling on a particular day to alter what might have been suggested--

—Order! There is no standing order in relation to this matter. It is more a matter of custom and usage than a standing order. But, if the honourable member for Mackellar feels that a standing order is required by the House, I advise and encourage him to put such a matter before the Procedure Committee.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. If something is contained in Pettifer-and may- be in Erskine May; I have not checked whether it is-one does not alter it on the run, by way of--

—It is a matter of usage, I think, and common sense and logic come into it. If a member has not received an answer from a Minister to a question on notice, and he asks that question of the Minister again, he is not disadvantaging anyone. That is the reason for the ruling. I suggest that the honourable member takes up the matter further with the Procedure Committee.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX RATES BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX BILL 1986TAXATION LAWS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISION) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight in the debate on the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986 and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986. The Income Tax Rates Bill is one of a number of quite significant Bills which set the tax regimen for 1986-87 and, most significantly, for 1987-88. This completes a most historic and significant series of tax reform measures-perhaps the most significant tax reform in this nation for decades. In recent times, of course, the tax debate in Australia has occurred on the basis of a number of quite distinct problems that have been part of the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer briefly to a number of those problems in the context of the rather wide-ranging debate that has occurred today. Taxpayers on relatively moderate incomes lately have been exposed to unprecedentedly high marginal rates of personal income tax. It is not uncommon these days for people who consider themselves to be on relatively modest incomes to be paying what they would consider to be quite high rates of taxation. It is worth while for honourable members to remember that the maximum tax rate from 1 July 1987, which will be the second stage of the Government's tax reform package-the first will commence on 1 December this year-will reduce the maximum tax rate that this Government inherited from the previous Government from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. It is significant, of course, that the 49 per cent rate, which will apply from 1 July next year, will commence at $35,000, which is about one-and-a-half times average weekly earnings. While it is no great boast for any nation to say that no one will pay more than half of his or her additional income in taxation, it is certainly much better, I suggest, to pay a rate of 49 per cent than 60 per cent, as was the case until now and as is certainly the case until 1 December this year.

I think it is worth while also to analyse some of the pay as you earn tax instalment liabilities of people on various income ranges. For example, someone who is at present on average weekly earnings has a taxation liability of $4,872. As from 1 December, this will be reduced to $4,680. But from 1 July next year the tax liability will be $4,495. It is worth while to recall that many taxpayers are in receipt of incomes which are well below average weekly earnings. So, for a person who is in receipt of, say, 75 per cent of average weekly earnings, the present taxation liability is $3,003, from 1 December it will be $2,861 and from 1 July next year it will be $2,764. These reductions are possible because of a number of measures incorporated into the Bill, including the Government's decision to increase the tax free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100. There are also reductions in the marginal rate of taxation. In summary, this represents a reduction of about 12 per cent in the taxation liability of most people throughout Australia. I seek the leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table which indicates the tax paid on certain levels of income in the financial years 1985-86 through to 1987-88.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that these rates show the generous nature of the tax reductions which are a significant part of the Bill. As from 1 December, bearing in mind that that will be when the first part of the two-stage reduction in taxation will be implemented, someone on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings will receive a weekly tax reduction of $3.90, or 5.8 per cent. Someone on average weekly earnings will have his weekly tax reduced from 1 December by $5.65, or 5.3 per cent. Given the nature of the times in which we live-we are all aware of the difficult terms of trade that have been thrust upon us-it is to the Government's credit that it has still been able to proceed with its taxation reform package.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant that we have received quite an amount of criticism about the reforms. Earlier in this debate honourable members said that they had serious reservations about whether the Government would proceed to the second stage of its taxation reduction on 1 July 1987. The Government's decision to introduce these Bills, as it did on Budget night, is a great indication of its sincerity in wishing to introduce genuine tax reductions.

An interesting feature of the great tax debate is that our political opponents on the other side of the House, and others within the community, tend to focus on some of the small sections of the overall tax package. They forget-I suppose quite conveniently-that it is a total tax package. References have been made today to the fringe benefits taxation, as well as a number of other matters. We have all seen some of the double standards of Opposition members in respect of fringe benefits taxation. They have conveniently ignored the Government's worthwhile decision to proceed as from 1 July 1987 with the full imputation system of company taxation. It will be a fundamental and long overdue reform of the company tax system. Effectively, it will eliminate the double tax on dividends that are paid to resident shareholders. Tax will be collected from companies and credits will ensure that individual resident shareholders will pay no further tax on them. Indeed, they may have tax on other income offset by the excess credits. (Quorum formed)

Before the quorum was called, Madam Speaker, I was saying that to some extent our political opponents opposite, and others within the community, have conveniently forgotten that we are talking about a taxation package and have conveniently focused at times on a narrow section of that package. I refer to the Government's decision to levy a tax on fringe benefits, an area of tax deductions which have been ballooning. In the White Paper last year, which was released for discussion by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), it was revealed that the number of employees receiving goods and services as fringe benefits had risen by 26 per cent in just 12 months from August 1984. The Government had good reason to proceed with fringe benefits taxation.

I feel compelled in such a wide-ranging debate to say that there has been a certain amount of double standards in respect of taxation. Some of those double standards have lead to unwarranted attacks by the Opposition on the Treasurer over the past few days. It is most unfortunate that the Opposition has indulged in double standards. How many times have we heard Opposition members ask reasonable questions on the state of the economy? Have we ever heard them make any reasonable comment upon the Government's fiscal strategy? Having no fiscal strategy, wages policy or monetary policy of their own, they are inclined to resort once again to gutter tactics.

It is significant that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) owns a house in the exclusive Canberra suburb of Forrest, and that for the purpose of obtaining the travel allowance he lists his family property near Collarenebri in the north-west of New South Wales as his principal place of residence. This is most unfortunate and it is clear that double standards have been applied to the travelling allowance. I ask whether the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) will ask the honourable member to resign on the basis of his own standards, bearing in mind that the Leader of the Opposition has said today that he has obtained an assurance `from all my front benchers that they were observing the rules'. Perhaps `were' is significant. He continued:
If I find that some of them aren't, I won't be very amused.

Just how fair dinkum is the Leader of the Opposition? Will he be fair dinkum enough to ask for the resignation of the honourable member for Gwydir? As the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said earlier today, we are not really attacking the payment of the travelling allowance to senior Ministers and senior shadow Ministers. But what we are saying is that under the Remuneration Tribunal there is an avenue whereby this allowance can be claimed if these people are going to responsibly carry out their duties. How can anyone expect the Treasurer of this nation reasonably to carry out his duties and be expected to travel back and forth from Canberra to Sydney all the time? The honourable member for Gwydir, being the Deputy Leader of the National Party, could also be reasonably expected to claim an accommodation allowance. perhaps the title `travel allowance' is inappropriate. Perhaps we should be referring to it as a ministerial or a shadow ministerial accommodation allowance, because no one in this House surely is denying that all these people-the Treasurer, the honourable member for Gwydir and others-are entitled to claim that? I ask members of the Opposition not to insult our intelligence by getting up and moralising about what the Treasurer is doing when they have their own snouts in the trough as well, because that is total hypocrisy.

We are saying that the members of the Opposition cannot have it both ways. They are inferring that there is something wrong with what the Treasurer is doing. I put it to them that if there is something wrong with what the Treasurer is doing-I do not think anyone on our side suggests that there is-then the honourable member for Gwydir is also doing something wrong. I do not believe he is. What about the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair)? How long has he retained a house in Canberra? How long has he been claiming this allowance? Yet he has also got up and moralised about the standards of this Government. I, and I am sure my colleagues also, find the whole thing totally reprehensible.

As I have said, we are not seeking to say that the honourable member for Gwydir is doing anything that he is not entitled to, but please do not get up in this House and suggest that some- how the Treasurer is claiming a travel allowance, just as the honourable member for Gwydir is, but that the Treasurer is somehow doing something wrong but the honourable member for Gwydir is not. I find that a totally nonsense argument. Will the honourable member for Gwydir get up in this House, as he was asked to by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) earlier today, and deny the fact that for most of his life his family has lived in Canberra and his children have gone to school in Canberra? Does he stay here on weekends? Does he claim a travelling allowance for the weekends? I say that he cannot have it both ways.

I think this has been a most unfortunate debate over the last few days. It has demonstrated the present level of double standards on the part of the Howard fascist Opposition. I find this a regrettable situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Calare will withdraw that remark.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will certainly withdraw it, but I find it offensive when the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) consistently refers to us as the Hawke socialist Government.
—Order! The honourable member for Calare will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will get back to the point I was making, that the Leader of the Opposition cannot have it both ways. He cannot attack the Treasurer and at the same time get up and make no comment at all about the members of his Party. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition told a news conference that he believed the travel allowance system should be observed by all those who had an obligation to uphold it. He said that he wanted an assurance, and had gained an assurance, that none of his front benchers were abusing the system. I want to make it quite clear that if in fact the Leader of the Opposition is making those claims, he cannot get up and say that it is wrong for the Treasurer somehow to be doing wrong when the honourable member for Gwydir, a senior member of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, is in fact doing something that is presumably in accordance with the provisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. We are not saying that the honourable member for Gwydir is necessarily doing anything wrong. What we are saying is that he cannot get up in this House and moralise and attack the Treasurer. The Leader of the Opposition cannot sit by idly and defend this position and then say: `It does not really apply to us'. The Leader of the Opposition must come clean. He cannot have this double standard. If he is fair dinkum he will ask the honourable member for Gwydir to resign because, by his own test, the honourable member for Gwydir has in fact breached the standards that he has set.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most interesting, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) should take up this matter of travelling allowance in this taxation debate. What he was drawing attention to was the fact that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), the Treasurer of this country, is the person who has been lecturing everybody about the rorts and ramps on expenses; the person who has been talking about brown paper bags being held by workers on trains going down to Granville and looking at the Mercedes-Benz cars going along Parramatta Road; the person who has accused businessmen, small and large, and farmers and the entrepreneurs of this country of ripping off the system. In conjunction with other government Ministers, particularly the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, he has lectured them mercilessly. The honourable member for Calare has drawn attention to the fact that the Treasurer has claimed a travelling allowance for staying in his principal residence in Canberra. That is the point that the honourable member for Calare has drawn attention to. The honourable member for Calare who represents the most important regional centres of Orange and Bathurst in New South Wales-represents temporarily those areas-has drawn attention to the fact that the Treasurer of this country, the person responsible for keeping the national books, the person responsible for setting standards of integrity in financial affairs, has put down on a piece of paper that his principal residence is in Sydney when he has no principal residence in Sydney, and as a result has claimed no less than $17,400 tax free from the taxpayer on the basis of a false claim. The honourable member for Calare is sufficiently ill-advised to raise this matter in this House again.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. If the honourable member wishes to raise a substantive motion against the Treasurer, he should do so. He has claimed that the Minister has made a false claim. I ask for that to be withdrawn. If he wishes to make that allegation he should do it by substantive motion and not by this back door, back-stabbing act which the Opposition is carrying out.

—Order! There was so much disruption in the chamber that the Chair did not hear precisely what the honourable member for Mackellar was saying. If the honourable member for Mackellar did impute a motive by saying that there was a false claim, he might withdraw that remark.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you require me to withdraw, I withdraw unreservedly. I was drawing attention to the fact that the honourable member for Calare had made accusations against members of the Opposition, and he used the following words: `You have got your snout in the trough as well'. As well as who? As well as the Treasurer? I need say no more than that the honourable member for Calare, a member of the same Party as the Treasurer, has used the words, accusing the Opposition: `You have got your snout in the trough as well'. The clear implication of that is that the Treasurer of this country has his snout in the trough. I would not have used those words: They were used by a member of the Australian Labor Party, the same party as the Treasurer, and they were used in the House of Representatives accusing members of the Opposition, as the honourable member says, of behaving as badly-by extension of the words-as the Treasurer of this country. All I can say is that if a member of the Australian Labor Party, representing such an important regional area as the cities of Orange and Bathurst, is prepared to say that in this House-
—And Lithgow.

—And also Lithgow, I am prepared to treat the matter seriously and on its merits. All I can say is this: If I were the Treasurer of this country and came from a Sydney constituency-I represent a Sydney constituency, I happen to live in my electorate--
—So you should too.
—Order! The honourable member for Leichhardt will cease interjecting and he will particularly cease interjecting from out of his seat.

—I understand fully the situation of the Treasurer. I am not in any way decrying what the Treasurer has said about his need to be with his family during the period he works in Canberra. But we have certain rules and people ought to understand what these rules are. They are that most members live in their electorates. They do not have to; it is not required. They are asked to state on the forms they fill in their principal place of residence and that should be the place where they ordinarily reside or where their family lives. Does the Treasurer live in his electorate of Blaxland at Bankstown? He does not. Does he live in Sydney, the city he claims is his principal residence? He most clearly does not.
—Do you want us to go into where we all spend our nights?
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will cease interjecting.
—Therefore, the Treasurer is perfectly entitled to claim--
—You are talking about--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Melbourne.
—This is clearly an organised campaign amongst the Labor Party--
—Goodness!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Leichhardt.

—To prevent me from saying what I have to say on this matter. It is quite clear that members in this House have certain views about where they live. When they come to Canberra and leave their families they have to make provision as to where they will live in Canberra, be it in a motel or a hotel, be it renting a place for the whole year and only occupying it for sitting nights, or purchasing a place, which is obviously an expense, and it is perfectly reasonable--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am aware that this has been a very wide-ranging debate, but I suggest that the honourable member for Mackellar is taking it a little beyond the bounds of wide-ranging. I understand that we are debating income tax Bills and yet the honourable member is talking about something else. I suggest that he return to the Bills that are on the Notice Paper.

—Order! The debate on the legislation has been rather wide-ranging and that was not started by the honourable member for Mackellar. I am sure that sooner or later he will come back to the Income Tax Rates Bill and the associated Bills. He is probably getting to that point now.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I assure you that I will deal with this unsavoury matter very quickly. The rule is that if members have to make arrangements for temporary accommodation in Canberra they claim travelling allowance for those nights, and that is perfectly reasonable. What has happened is that the Treasurer of this country, who has been lecturing everybody up hill and down dale about tax rorting, has put down on a piece of paper that his principal residence is in Sydney where he clearly does not live and has claimed $17,400 tax free for travelling allowance to Canberra which is his principal residence. I did not raise this matter and I was not going to raise it but for the disgraceful contribution of the honourable member for Calare who accused his Treasurer of having his snout in the trough. As members on both sides of the House know jolly well, I am not accustomed to this sort of stock-in-trade that was used by the honourable member for Calare. He raised the matter; it was the Treasurer who lectured us and it is the Treasurer who is guilty of this offence, and I say no more about it tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about the Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and what has happened as a result of the so-called tax reform of the Labor Party. The Opposition is not opposing these three Bills. In respect of the Income Tax Rates Bill, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that-
(1) the Government's taxation policy, in particular its fringe benefits and capital gains taxes, is causing damage and confusion to business and farmers;
(2) the Government's failure to deliver tax cuts on 1 September 1986 as promised in 1985 has caused additional hardship to families, and
(3) this Government is the highest taxing Government in history with tax receipts estimated to reach 25.5% of GDP'.

What has happened is that the Government, in its 1983 policy speech and its 1984 policy speech, in the National Taxation Summit and preceding that the National Economic Summit Conference, has promised the people of Australia a thorough tax reform which will have the effect of reducing the ordinary rates of tax for lower and middle income earners. That is what this Government has put forward as what it wants to do: Those are the objectives which have been stated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer in presenting the Government's taxation policy. In the 1984 election campaign and in his policy speech, the Prime Minister said:
And unlike any previous tax cuts for more than a decade, their real value to the taxpayers of Australia will not be filched by the theft of double-digit inflation.

The tax cuts are the first element in our undertaking to achieve genuine tax reform, and to provide tax relief for the taxpayers, but particularly the middle and low income earners-of Australia-the ordinary hard-working Australians who pay as they earn.

Those were the words of the Prime Minister in his 1984 policy speech; that was the commitment of the Australian Labor Party to the Australian people. What do we see? We have had an economic summit, a tax summit and a major tax statement in September last year; since then we have had 625 additional pages of taxation legislation of immense complication, including the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. All this is supposed to deliver practical benefits for ordinary Australians. What do we find as a result of all this activity? We find that the average Australian family will still be $23.50 a week worse off after tax cuts take effect on 1 December this year. I remind the House that these tax cuts were promised by 1 September this year. So $650m has been filched from people against the promises of the Government. As a result, since the election and since those brave election promises of 1984, the average Australian family is $23.50 a week worse off. Since the last election, a one income family with two dependent children with average weekly earnings of $466 has suffered a loss in real disposable income of $27 a week. The weekly tax saving for the 1986-87 financial year for someone on average weekly earnings of $466 will be only $3.50. Because of the effects of inflation and as a result of the so-called wonderful tax reforms of the Hawke Government this means that the average family is still $23.50 worse off since the last election. In addition, since this Government came to power the excise on petrol has gone up by no less than 14c a litre, which means for the average user of a motor vehicle an extra $6.30 a week since the Hawke Government came to power.

On 17 September, last week, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) tested the Prime Minister on these taxation reforms. He asked him quite simply in Question Time whether he was aware that a person on average weekly earnings will face on the completion of the two rounds of foreshadowed income tax cuts both a higher marginal rate of tax and a higher average income tax rate than at the end of the Fraser Government. The Prime Minister did not answer that question-because it goes to the heart of this whole farce of the so-called tax reform. We have moved the whole mountain and what have we produced? Let us look at what has happened to the marginal rates of tax, that is, the rates one pays on the top end of one's income, which affects overtime, any extra work one may do, or a second job. In March 1983 a person on average weekly earnings paid a top marginal rate of 30c in the dollar. By December 1984, under the Hawke Government, it went up to 46c in the dollar. It remained there until June 1986, when it was 46c in the dollar. Under the so-called reforms, it drops progressively to 43c and 40c. It is still 10c higher than when the Hawke Government came to office. That is the top marginal rate for somebody on average weekly earnings.

The Treasurer put out a selective Press release to certain journalists who he thought might swallow the bait, based on crook calculations, including references to people on part time employment. All the papers he has used until now and all the figures in his draft White Paper on tax and in his 19 September statement, have been based on full adult weekly earnings for average weekly earnings calculations. The selective Press release he gave to certain journalists was designed to mislead. Some journalists were hooked on that.

Let us look at what will happen to average tax rates after these so-called reforms have been introduced. A person on average weekly earnings in March 1983 would have paid an average tax rate-I am not now talking about the top marginal rate-of 22.9c in every dollar. After the Labor Government took over, the average rate rose to 24c in December 1984 and to a peak of 25.9c in June 1986. So people have been paying all this extra tax. It is forecast to drop to 24.7c in December 1986. If there is no mini-Budget next year-there may well be one-it will go to 24.5c in June 1987. Overall, before the Hawke Government came to office somebody on average weekly earnings paid an average tax rate on their whole income of 22.9c in the dollar. As a result of the Keating-Hawke reforms, that average will have risen to 24.5c by the time the reforms have been implemented.

What sort of reform is this? By its own set of objectives, laid down by the Government in its 1983 and 1984 policy speeches, by everything it said at the two summits, it said there would be tax relief for ordinary people. The result of the so-called reforms is that taxes have gone up. The reason is that this Government has been profligate in spending. It has spent taxpayers' money as if it were going out of fashion, and it is the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the amendment seconded? The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) indicates that he seconds the amendment.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Most grievously, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Opposition seems to be implying that by the remarks I made in the course of my contribution to the debate a few minutes ago, I was suggesting improper motives on the part of members of this Government. I said that neither the Treasurer (Mr Keating) nor the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) was doing anything wrong in terms of the requirements of the Remuneration Tribunal. Rather, I said that it was wrong for the Opposition to suggest improper motives on the part of the Treasurer when the Deputy Leader of the National Party was doing no more and no less in terms of the Remuneration Tribunal provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many respects this debate is a rather sad one, because it has obviously created a great deal of animosity on the part of different honourable members. It has caused a tremendous amount of feeling. It has also caused people to become involved in a great number of irrelevancies. It is a very sad state of affairs. Nevertheless, when we are talking about taxation, and in particular about trying to introduce into the tax system some equity, we must start declaring which side we stand on. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), a man for whom I normally have considerable regard, said that the position we were taking in our tax reform was based on envy, greed and hate. I find it very remarkable that when we are attempting to introduce some kind of system which will give a fairer distribution of the tax burden, we are charged with envy, greed and hate.

SPEECH.PARA: The same honourable member and, I suppose, many other honourable members claim that they are on the same side of the family. When one looks at what has happened in the tax system over the last 30-odd years, it seems odd to find out what has actually happened to the family's contribution to tax revenue, especially the pay as you earn taxation. On page 19, the Government's White Paper, under the reference on income tax-I know it will come as a surprise that someone should be talking about income tax in this debate-states:
Increased reliance on personal income taxes has meant a significant escalation in both the marginal and average tax rates faced by average income earners in Australia.
I am talking primarily about the time of conservative governments. It goes on:

In 1954-55, taxpayers with average earnings faced marginal and average tax rates of 19 and 10 per cent respectively. By 1970-71, these rates had risen to 32 and 19 per cent. Today, the marginal tax rates of average earners is 46 per cent . . . while their average tax rate has climbed to 25 per cent.
In most instances it is the middle and lower income families of this nation who have had to make the largest contribution. This is quite remarkable when one thinks about it.

I will indicate just what has actually happened. Many taxpayers on moderate incomes are now exposed to high marginal rates. In 1954-55 approximately one per cent of full time employed persons faced a marginal rate of 46 per cent or more; in 1983-84 the proportion was 34 per cent. The assumption is that everybody is that much better off, but that is just not true. What has happened is that fiscal drag, mainly through the consumer price index, has taken people through these marginal tax rates. This Government is determined to do what the Opposition, when in government, either did not have the courage to do or was unwilling to do because it might have affected its friends; that is, it is determined to change the marginal rates to ensure that the average Australian actually pays less income tax. What is so wrong with that? Should we be accused of envy, greed and hate? Are we saying that those people in Australia who have been able to manipulate the tax system in such a way that they have minimised the proportion of tax they pay-they should actually pay more-are to be applauded? Is this a system of equity? Are we now to turn around and say that anybody who questions that is motivated by envy, greed or hate? How on earth can anyone talk about motivation by greed? What on earth is the motivation of those people? Is it not just greed?

We are trying to introduce some justice into the taxation system and those opposite are saying that we are envious and greedy. What kind of logical contortions do they expect the rest of the people in Australia to go through to understand that? That is absolute nonsense. It is a pity that Opposition members do not go ahead and examine the logic of their own positions instead of trying to defend those people who are the greedy ones-the ones who are opting out of the tax system. It is marvellous that they are defending the fringe benefits system when we know that, if it continues, within a couple of years 25 per cent of Australian income earners will be taking advantage of that. And at whose expense? At the expense of the PAYE tax payers; that is who. Is it so wrong to try to ensure that those people who earn an income in this country make a contribution through taxation to this country's revenue? What is so wrong with that? What is wrong with the principle of it?

We have listened to this tax debate on and off now for 18 months and at no stage during that time has anyone on the opposite side of this House declared himself in favour of the principle of equity in the taxation system. It is an utter disgrace and Opposition members ought to be ashamed of themselves. Not one of them is present in the House tonight to hear the condemnation of themselves for their perfidy and their hypocrisy. I think this an absolute disgrace. I am sure that I am not the only one throughout the length and breadth of this country asking why should people not pay their tax contributions. What is wrong with people paying tax contributions? Why should people get a certain amount of their income in cash and be able to convert the rest of it into kind so that they do not have to pay any tax on it? Is that wrong? What is the principle behind that?

Those opposite say that this measure will somehow affect incentive and initiative. Are we saying that initiative, incentive and the development of this nation should be based upon some people who are required to pay their taxes and others who do not have to pay their taxes because of the way in which they earn their income? I cannot see the logic of the justice of it. It is something of which Opposition members ought to be ashamed. (Quorum formed) It is a sad reflection upon the standards of fairness amongst Australians, not just Opposition members, that those who have made their own decisions to subvert the tax system by adopting what has been called this fringe benefits package, are now denouncing the Government's reformist measures by claiming that incentive is being destroyed. We have never heard those opposite complain about the inequity which has crept into the tax system and has actually forced the greatest burden upon the PAYE taxpayers of this nation. Not once have we heard those people on the other side of the House declare what their real position is on taxation, but they have constantly made excuses for those people who rip off the system. Not only that, but also there is a deliberate denigration of the PAYE taxpayers by those opposite. That is the purport of their silence on the principle of taxation equity. They wish to portray the PAYE taxpayer as a non-contributor to the nation's wealth. The PAYE taxpayer is portrayed as some sort of second class Australian. By contrast, the Opposition wishes to portray those who are able to divide their income into a part-cash, part-kind package as all being creators of wealth. This is crude and palpably dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is misrepresentation.

—It is a deception. By and large it is a dangerous and unwarranted attack upn the PAYE taxpayer by a group which thrives upon socially divisive policies. The advocacy of the non-tax fringe benefits by the Opposition brands its members as the enemies of most Australians. Opposition members do not care one jot for the welfare of those who pay all their due tax-and more because of the defaulters of the friends of honourable members opposite. They purport to be interested in the welfare of the family, yet they are not prepared to support measures such as the fringe benefits tax which aim to bring some justice into the system, in particular, for honest, taxpaying family income earners. The Opposition disparages equity as though it were to be interpreted as a levelling of society. It is nothing of the kind. It is merely an attempt to sort out the crude distortions of the tax system along the lines of fairness. I see nothing wrong with introducing tax equity. I am sure that most Australians do not see anything wrong with it either. It is not surprising that at no time has anyone, either in the Opposition or among those who will be affected, presented any argument of substance which would cast doubts upon the cogency of the arguments for equity.

SPEECH.PARA: You may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this Government attempted to recover $250m which had been denied the public purse by those who were guilty of using bottom of the harbour schemes. Four times we went to the Senate to gain its agreement on this matter and on each occasion the Liberal-National Party Opposition, with the connivance of some of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, rejected our efforts. Now these people have helped to continue the suffering of honest Australian families who have to pay their fair share of tax as well as the share avoided by the friends of those opposite. It is all too clear from the recent past just how little the Opposition really thinks of families. It is no good standing up and making pious statements about families when it took action, when in government, which was obviously to the detriment of the families of this nation.

During the period of government of those opposite, when the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, we witnessed an example of cynical deception of the Australian public which will not readily be forgotten. Prior to the 1977 election great stress was placed upon the promise of cut taxes. Within a few months of regaining government those cuts were removed. The result was an increase in tax payments by ordinary, decent Australians, while the friends of those opposite at the upper income levels actually paid less tax. Not only that, but also the practice of optional taxation crept in via the payment of fringe benefits. This practice burgeoned because its practitioners realised that the Liberal-National Party coalition not only would do nothing about it but also actually encouraged it by default. In fact, the Opposition is encouraging it now, not by default, but deliberately. Most of them want the practice continued. We have heard that, although I must admit that there is a fair amount of confusion opposite at this stage. Opposition members are beginning to get rattled.

The Leader of the Opposition once again wants his public to believe that there would be no fringe benefits tax under his government. At least some back benchers opposite make a feeble sort of noise that perhaps there ought to be. What, however, is the real position of the Leader of the Opposition? We all know that he will continue to tax fringe benefits, or at least he will return to the process of taxing fringe benefits to the unworkable position-advocated by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton)-which was in place previously under section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. But it has proven to be unworkable. It is a nice thing to make pious noises about it because one knows one's mates will be let off the hook once again. Honourable members opposite cannot have it both ways. There cannot be a maximum reduction in the marginal rates of income tax without an attempt to stop the haemorrhaging of the tax system via fringe benefits and capital gains taxes. We cannot return the desired amounts to all taxpayers if we leave out of the system the very considerable sums to be gained from that section of income paid out in kind, that is, fringe benefits.

The reduction of marginal tax rates in two stages, as outlined in the Budget, will have the effect of putting more money in more people's pockets. I believe that this will have a well needed, stimulatory effect upon consumption and, I might say, upon job creation. It will increase the discretionary power which people will have over their own incomes. But best of all, it will put money into the hands of those who most need it and it will ensure that the people who should be paying their fair share of the tax burden actually do so. I believe that this will be a great boost for families. I have absolutely no difficulty whatsoever in commending this Bill to the House. It has my full support and I am sure that it has the support of the great majority of Australian people, including the people in the gallery tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986 and the Tax- ation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 I begin by saying that earlier in the week it was amusing to hear the warm words of praise by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) for Sweden. The Minister's comments seemed to confirm speculation that elements in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its junior coalition partner, which is this Government, are about to intensify their infatuation with the industrial relations and wage settling structures of Sweden, Austria and Norway. However, this is not the occasion to discuss in detail just how stupid such strategies would be for Australia. Of more immediate interest are the disturbing parallels between Sweden's fiscal policies and the approach being adopted by this Government. Sweden, with tax receipts equivalent to 51 per cent of gross domestic product in 1984 and with government spending at 64 per cent of GDP, is the biggest taxing and spending government in the Western world. Anyone examining the Bills before us and recalling other taxation legislation we have seen over the the past 18 months or so could not avoid coming to the conclusion that under the Hawke Government Australia is well on the way to becoming the Sweden of the antipodes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us briefly examine the record. Tax revenue in real terms has been increased at an annual rate of 4.9 per cent per year over the four years of the Hawke Government, compared with 3.3 per cent during the full seven years of the Fraser Government. Tax receipts as a percentage of GDP were increased to 25 per cent in 1984-85. That level has been increased even further in each of the subsequent two Budgets, rising to 25.2 per cent in 1985-86 and 25.5 per cent in 1986-87. The four-year average under the Hawke Government has been 24.8 per cent compared with an average 23.4 per cent during the seven Fraser years. These massive overall tax hikes were, of course, necessary because government expenditure in real terms increased by 3.9 per cent per year under this Government. That is almost double the seven-year average of 2.1 per cent under Fraser. Government expenditure as a percentage of GDP is budgeted to be 29.4 per cent this financial year-the fourth highest in post-war history. As the three highest figures were in the previous three years, the average for the four years under this Government is 29.9 per cent, compared with 27.7 per cent under the Fraser Government.

We can gain an understanding of the practical effects of the Hawke Government's policies if we make two brief comparisons. Had government expenditure under Labor risen at the same annual rate which it did during the period of the Fraser Government, expenditure would have been a total of $13 billion less than it has been under this Labor Government. Had Labor adopted the coalition's policy of a real freeze on the increase in government expenditure during the first three years of its term of office, government expenditure would have been about $20 billion less.

The Income Tax Rates Bill 1986 declares the tax rate for individuals and trustees for 1986-87 and subsequent years to allow for the proportioning of the threshold level and to declare the rate of tax for superannuation funds and certain other groups for this financial year. A key section of the Bill deals with the changes to individual tax rates. It will be recalled that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his 1984 policy speech, said:
I can guarantee you'll keep our tax cuts!
In September 1985, he said that the proposed tax changes:
represent the fulfilment of the Government's commitment to provide tax cuts from September 1986, equivalent to a 2 per cent wage increase.

He repeated something along the same lines in May this year on the Sunday program, but by then he had started to qualify his undertakings. He merely said that the tax cuts would be delivered. He had deleted all reference to the timing. That continued whenever he was questioned. Ultimately, as we have seen in this Budget, the first of the tax cuts was deferred until 1 December and we wait in hope and expectation that the second will be delivered in July next year.

The Budget confirmed those facts. The Bills confirm the timing of the proposed tax cuts. The Income Tax Rates Bill formalises that with a saving of $650m through the deferral decision; that is, the decision to defer from 1 September until 1 December. We are told that the reduction in tax rates will cost an estimated $1,435m in 1986-87 and the impressive sounding sum of $4 1/2m in a full year. What will that actually mean to the man in the street? The Prime Minister has already admitted that the much vaunted $9 a week tax cut will, in fact, be only $6 a week after Budget measures such as the increase in the Medicare levy are taken into account.

Unfortunately, the facts make the position far worse. Last week, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) asked the Prime Minister whether he was aware that a person on average weekly earnings will face, on the completion of the two rounds of foreshadowed income tax cuts, both a higher marginal and average income tax rate than that which applied at the end of the Fraser Government's term in office. The Prime Minister, of course, ignored the question. When one examines the facts it is not surprising that he was not prepared to answer. In March 1983, the marginal tax rate applying to a person on average weekly earnings was only 30c in the dollar. Today, it is 46c in the dollar, and in July 1987 it will be 40c in the dollar; that is, if the July cuts are delivered.

The average income tax rate-that is, the pay as you earn tax paid as a percentage of average annual earnings for a person on average weekly earnings-will, by June 1987, be around 24.5 per cent-well above the 22.9 per cent level that applied at the end of the Fraser Government's term in office. It would require a further $8 a week income tax cut on top of the promised tax cuts to reduce the tax burden to the same level that applied in the March quarter of 1983. It is very important to remember that. This increase in personal income tax does not include the many other additional tax burdens imposed by the Government, including the abominable fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the abolition of negative gearing and concessional expenditure rebates, as well as numerous increases in indirect taxation. The Leader of the Opposition enumerated those many acts earlier today in his fine speech on these measures.

As well as the more immediate deleterious effects of a highly punitive taxation system, there is the crucial issue of the linkage between taxation and economic growth. A fascinating and important study of these links has been made by a staff member of the World Bank. It is known as the World Bank staff working paper No. 605.
