TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened closely to the honourable member's argument, I must say that I find it strange that he has presented a table that has no reference to Australia.

—I thank you for your encouragement, Mr Deputy Speaker, because the next thing I shall do is link it to Australia. The author of the paper, Keith Marsden, found that the general rule was that the lower the tax rate over the period 1970-79 the higher the average economic growth rate for the preceding decade. The clear link that I set out to make has been shown up in the study. If we apply Marsden's research to Australia, we find that a 1 per cent increase in the tax rate results in 0.36 per cent decline in our gross domestic product growth.

SPEECH.PARA: A separate study by Peter Saunders of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development looked at the inter-relationship between the size and growth of general government expenditures and receipts relative to GDP in OECD countries in the 1960-81 period. Much the same thing is shown. That study is entitled `Public Expenditure and Economic Performance in OECD Countries'. Saunders found that there had been an inverse relationship in the 1960s between the size of government and economic growth. The question of economic growth in the short term is of immediate relevance to the Government's capacity to fund the so-called tax cuts. Very serious questions have been raised about the economic assumptions underlying the Budget strategy. Dr David Clark, senior lecturer in economics at the University of New South Wales, has said:
. . . contrary to the impression given by Mr Keating in his Budget speech the forecasts on which the Budget rests are much much more rubbery than he or the Treasury would like us to believe.
He continued:
The forecasts . . . are a product of extrapolation from an only partially known past, through an unknown present to an unknowable future.

Let me illustrate the gravity of that warning by referring to the Budget forecast for 2.25 per cent growth in GDP in this financial year and the fact that that is based on some shaky assumptions, as Dr Clark has mentioned. Most of the projected growth is expected to come from net exports-that is, 1.75 per cent-with only 0.5 per cent from domestic demand. Yet the budgeted expectations of continued economic growth overseas are optimistic and, to the extent that world growth is lower, the demand for Australia's exports will be lessened and hence our economic growth will be lower.

As with other areas, a lower growth rate than forecast will have a quite dramatic effect on the Budget deficit. A one per cent lower growth rate will produce a deficit of some $4 1/2 billion. We should remember that the 1985-86 Budget outlays exceeded the Budget estimate by some $825m. We should also remember that the Government's trilogy commitment-the key aspect to its fiscal policy-has been dumped. The taxation side of the trilogy has been broken in each of the first two years of existence with the Government raising $400m in 1985-86 and $1,400m in 1986-87 in tax revenue over and above the trilogy ceiling. There we have just some of the matters that concern us with the legislation and the Government's approach to taxation generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, let me draw the attention of the House to three myths which have been circulating in the Australian community for the past few years. These myths have been spread by the ill-informed and published in the media as though they are truths, which they are not. The first myth is that unemployment is the fault of the unemployed-that the work is there if they are prepared to go out and look for it. The second myth is that wage and salary levels are too high. The third myth is that Australia is a highly taxed nation. On another occasion, I will no doubt have the opportunity to speak about the first two myths, but today I want to say something about the need for tax reform in Australia. In doing so, I first want to explode the myth that we are a highly taxed nation and a variation of this myth which claims that we are the most highly taxed nation in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, it must be noted that making comparisons with the taxation systems of other countries is not easy, because different methods of extracting taxes-which, incidentally, are not always called taxes-make a direct comparison difficult. Australia is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which does not impose social security contributions as part of its revenue collection system. Eight European countries raise more revenue from social security contributions than from income taxes. In 1983, revenues from social security contributions were equal to more than 30 per cent of total taxation in Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, The Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland, and employers' contributions are greater than employees' contributions in most of those countries. In consequence, Australia has a relatively high dependence on direct income tax, although this slipped significantly during the late 1970s. Now, the highest rate is 49c in the dollar. However, the important overall fact is that despite significant increases in taxation in some areas in recent years, both as a proportion of incomes and as a proportion of gross national product, Australia is still a relatively low-taxed country. For example, we have one of the lowest rates on property, inherited wealth and capital gains.

Unfortunately, we have to fall back on statistics to prove my point. Figures supplied by the OECD show that, in 1983, of 23 OECD countries, only three ranked below Australia in terms of the total taxation burden. In 1981, total taxation in Australia was 31.55 per cent of our gross domestic product, compared with the OECD average of 36.16 per cent. Japan, with fairly low tax rates overall, has the highest corporate tax revenues of any Western-type industrial nation, which is about 5 per cent of gross national product, with moderately high taxes on investment income. Both Germany and Japan have more straightforward tax systems which produce less distortion. They also have a monetary system aimed at keeping interest rates low and stable, industrial relations which trade influence for peace, and industrial finance which relies heavily on debt capital.

It is not the level of taxation which has adverse effect on economic growth and employment; rather, it is the structure of taxation and factors such as the stability of capital costs, labour force productivity, consumer demand and the efficiency of institutions in channelling savings into productive investment.

At this stage, I wish to refer to some letters published in the Australian Financial Review of 24 September. There was one letter from the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and one from Professor J. W. Nevile, of the School of Economics at the University of New South Wales. Both letters referred to an article published in the Australian Financial Review which set out the sort of background to the tax structures of European countries to which I have been referring. However, the headline over that article stated:
Australian tax burden among the world's highest.

That was a most misleading headline, as was pointed out by the two letters. I am very disappointed that a responsible newspaper such as the Financial Review could provide such misleading headlines, particularly as the article made it very clear that that was not the case. What is the Financial Review trying to prove? I hope that we will see some retraction in the Financial Review. It is not enough that letters to the editor complain about these things.

At this stage, I find it tempting to launch into an overview of the Australian economy, because taxation reform is so intimately bound up with the general overall economic strategies of the Government. But debate on the present Bills requires me to refrain from making those general comments about the economy. However, I have to say that no speech about taxation reform could ignore the present distribution of wealth in Australia. A number of wealth analyses has been made, but the most often quoted and reliable survey was that conducted by John Piggott of the Australian National University. This survey reveals that the top one per cent of adult individuals hold around 25 per cent of private wealth, the top 5 per cent hold about 50 per cent, and the top 10 per cent hold more than 60 per cent of the private wealth in Australia. Surprisingly, the figures show a slightly greater concentration than was revealed in similar studies in the United States and substantially less than in the United Kingdom.

A few more comments must be made to round off these figures. Although the proportion of wealth held by the top one per cent of adult individuals has decreased sharply since the First World War, the top 2 per cent to 10 per cent have almost the same proportion of wealth and may, indeed, have slightly increased their share since 1915. It would appear that the top one per cent have part of their share transferred to the bottom 90 per cent, who have increased their share from 22 per cent in 1915 to between 35 and 40 per cent.

People listening to this debate would have to agree with me, however, that a society which allows 10 per cent of its adult population to own more than 60 per cent of the private wealth, while the other 90 per cent own less than 40 per cent of the private wealth, has built-in problems when it relies heavily on a system of taxing earned income, even though the wealth survey has revealed that there is a strong correlation between the ownership of wealth and income.

Unfortunately, little research work has been undertaken in Australia. We are poorly equipped to offer advice on how to reduce wealth in- equality effectively and efficiently. I understand that the Government is undertaking a survey of the wealth in Australia and its distribution, and I hope that the results of this study will be forthcoming very soon, because it is vital for those of us who are concerned about this matter. I do not expect members of the Opposition to be particularly concerned about the unequal distribution of wealth in Australia since they represent those people who have the wealth. As a Federal member of Parliament who has long advocated wealth and inheritance taxes, I am most concerned that little research has been done towards understanding how the process of wealth accumulation occurs as within a generation and wealth transmission patterns between generations. Briefly, we need to know more about savings patterns, retirement provisions, bequests and trusts, fertility patterns and all those sorts of things.

I want to make a few comments about tax avoidance, but first I have to say something about the essence of my comments to the House on the tax Bills. In this respect, I am indebted to the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence for its excellent submission to the Economic Planning Advisory Council last year. The Brotherhood claims-I support that claim-that taxation reform is central to any commitment to eliminate poverty in Australia. The Brotherhood stated:

We have to ask, `what sort of Australia do the majority of Australians want?' On present trends we are moving towards a harshly divided society, with gross inequalities between those with well paid and secure employment and those unable to find work, those unable to earn much more than minimum wages and those dependent on pensions and benefits.

Without a tax system that is able, equitably and efficiently, to stimulate sustained levels of economic growth and to raise the revenue required to finance the achievement of both social and economic goals, no comprehensive strategy to eliminate poverty is realistic.

At present there are nearly three million Aust- ralians living on or below the poverty line. I tabled figures during my speech on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 which indicated present poverty levels, so that honourable members can draw their own conclusions about the relative poverty levels in Australia. Tax reform is a key component of a comprehensive attack on poverty and inequality in Australia. For the tax system to play this role, reform must be based on a set of principles which reflect a commitment to equity.

Taxation is necessary and desirable. There is a widespread belief that taxation is a necessary evil. Over a decade of low economic growth and high unemployment, reductions in government spending have often been proposed as a method of stimulating economic activities. Of course, members of the Opposition have often proposed such measures. But these views are not supported by the experience of growth in a range of Western countries. Part of the accepted role of government is the provision of services for all members of the community, funded by taxation levied on all individuals who receive income above the tax threshold. To perform these functions adequately, taxation is necessary and desirable. There is no substantial evidence that economic growth is undermined by the present level of taxation, or that current taxation encourages tax avoidance.

Taxation should raise sufficient funds for government to perform its role. Tax reform should lead to a tax system capable of providing sufficient revenue for an adequate social security system, access to housing for all Australians, accessible and low cost child care, better job training and retraining, and improved approaches to job creation. The taxation system should be progressive. Taxpayers with a greater ability to pay should pay a higher proportion of their income in tax. In this way, progressive taxation can be levied fairly, and taxation can help to reduce the great inequality in income and wealth which exists in Australia.

Assistance to specific groups should be provided through government expenditure rather than tax concessions and rebates. The progressive impact of income tax would be improved if many tax concessions available through the tax system were abolished. Tax concessions include items such as the concessional rebate, the dependent spouse rebate, the low tax treatment of superannuation income and payments, and investment allowances to industry. Tax reform should provide the best climate for growth in employment. Evidence suggests that the present tax structure does not offer the best climate for general employment growth, and probably also acts to discourage disadvantaged workers from participating in the work force.

Employment growth is held back by, for example, speculative, relatively unproductive investments encouraged by the absence of a capital gains tax, and the impact of payroll taxes in combination with investment concessions, which is likely to encourage employers to automate their production. Disadvantaged workers are discouraged from participating in paid employment by poverty traps. (Quorum formed) Members of the Opposition are not interested in tax reform. I was speaking about tax reform. All they can do is call a quorum. I notice that there are two members of the Opposition present-perhaps 2 1/2-and the rest are not interested in what I have to say about tax reform. Tax reform is important because it involves a comprehensive package of proposals. One cannot talk about individual tax proposals in isolation. They must be part of a comprehensive package.

I was quite prepared to wind up what I had to say. But the Opposition had to be impatient. It had to try to push me to finish what I was saying because it is embarrassed about what I have to say. It is not interested in tax reform. All that it is interested in is trying to increase the wealth of the people it represents. I am really very ashamed of the way in which Opposition members have performed. They have raised matters which bear no relation to tax reform. All they have done is involve themselves in personal abuse and personal attack. I wanted to make a serious speech--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in the gutter.

—As my friend, the honourable member for Hindmarsh says, they are in the gutter. That is very true. I will not say anything more, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it appears that some arrangement has been made by the Whips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been treated tonight to a talk from a person who represents the Socialist Left in the Australian Labor Party. He has outlined for us a chilling prospect, a prospect of a socialist Australia in which there would not be any reward for initiative, enterprise and hard work. I hope that thousands of people are listening to the broadcast of this debate tonight and that they will turn in droves away from the ALP because of the extremist nonsense and claptrap uttered by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a simple distinc- tion--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I point out that I represent the Labor Party in this House, not the Socialist Left.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Labor Party has so many factions and minor groups. There is the left wing, the right wing, the left guard, the right guard, and probably also the mud-guard. But there is a simple, clear and definite distinction between the ALP and the National Party of Australia and our coalition partner. The ALP is a high tax party; the National Party is a low tax party. We believe-and we make absolutely no apology for saying so-that taxpayers should retain as much as possible of their earnings, to spend and use as they wish. Alas, the Government does not agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at Labor's record. The Commonwealth Budget which was brought down recently was a taxing, not axing, Budget. No real effort was made to cut spending. Government expenditure has increased in real terms by 3.9 per cent per year under Hawke. As a percentage of gross domestic product, government expenditure is budgeted to total 29.4 per cent in 1986-87-the fourth highest percentage in post-war history. The three previous records were also set by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Spending will increase by 6.9 per cent this year, to $74.1 billion. Contrast that with the promise of the Opposition to freeze government expenditure during its first three years in office.

Australia is now burdened with a fringe benefits tax, a capital gains tax, a higher Medicare levy, despite Labor's promise to the contrary, new and higher sales taxes, an increase in bank debits tax, an assets test on pensions and a continuation of the superannuation tax. Despite the tax cut that is due in December, revenue will increase by 11 per cent in 1986-87. It is a national disgrace and Labor stands condemned for it. Tax revenue in real terms has increased at an annual rate of 4.9 per cent in the four years of the Hawke Government compared with 3.5 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Moreover, tax revenue as a proportion of GDP will have increased under Labor from 25 per cent to 25.5 per cent, thereby, in effect, scrapping the Government's trilogy commitment for the second year in succession. The Government has treated the trilogy commitment as merely another promise to be broken. But, after all, what is one more addition to its litany of broken promises?

In 1984-85, the Government grabbed $400m more than its trilogy ceiling, and in 1986-87 it has snatched another $1.4 billion. Ned Kelly is not dead; he has merely changed his name by deed poll to Paul Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for his support. The Government's tax policies are crushing incentive. Even under the Government's proposed tax cuts, the top marginal tax rate in Australia will be over 50 per cent when the Medicare levy is included. In contrast, a recent report indicates that the United States Congress is now almost certain to approve a reduction in the top personal tax rate from 50 per cent to 28 per cent, and a cut in the top company tax rate from 46 per cent to 34 per cent. Compare that with this Government's shameful record. The people of Australia will no doubt do so and will see this Government for the fraud and the sham that it obviously is. In contrast to the positive steps of the United States Congress, Labor is doing too little too late, or is heading in the wrong direction completely.

SPEECH.PARA: We need low tax rates. Unlike the honourable member for La Trobe, I believe that there must be reward for hard work. There must be some incentive for someone to go out and have a go. There must be some incentive to take a risk, but the Australian Labor Party's solution to everything is tax, tax, tax and more tax. We must give it credit for its stubborn determination. A vast amount of time, thought and discussion has taken place in the Government's ranks on how to devise new and original ways to rob Australians of an ever higher proportion of their income. On the other hand, Queensland, with its majority National Party Government, continues to be a low tax State.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good Government.

—It is, as the honourable member for Riverina-Darling states. The Australian Bureau of Statistics government financial estimates, the ABS publication `Taxation Revenue Australia 1984-85', the Commonwealth Grants Commission and the State Budget papers' statistical data show beyond doubt that Queensland is a low tax State.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the government financial estimates data, it is clear for everyone to see that Victorians pay State per capita tax of $850 while the figure is $833 in New South Wales, $687 in Western Australia, $650 in South Australia and a mere $554 in Queensland under a National Party government. Victorians pay $296 per head more than Queenslanders, New South Wales people pay $276 more, South Australians pay $96 more and Western Australians pay $133 more. Estimations made by the Commonwealth Grants Commission indicate that Queensland would raise additional revenue of $253m if it increased tax charges to the average rates of the other States. It is clear and unambiguous that the National Party in Queensland presides over a low tax State. Queenslanders pay no liquor taxes, no State petrol taxes, no State tobacco taxes and no State financial institutions duty. It is obvious that Queensland is a highly desirable State in which to live.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I and other Queensland members are proud to represent the State in the House of Representatives.
—And very well too.

—I thank the honourable member from Denison for his perceptive comment. We find that Queensland has benefited from internal migration from other States. In the 12 months ended with the December quarter 1985 23,897 people ran away from the Labor States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Since June 1980, 125,169 interstate migrants have moved to Queensland. This migration has boosted our unemployment figures; there have been 14,968 unemployment benefit transfers between 1982 and June 1986. This has added 1.24 per cent to the State's unemployment. That shows up once and for all the Australian Labor Party's claim that the unemployment rate in Queensland is in some way the fault of the Queensland Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned migration. The recent statements of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) have encouraged capital to migrate to safer shores. He was reported in the media as encouraging business to invest overseas. Honourable members will recall that I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

Does the Minister's recommendation, along with the downgrading by Moody's Investor Services Inc. of Australia's credit rating, prove that under Labor this country is no longer a good investment risk? Was the Minister's advice a suggestion to business that it should get any remaining funds out of the country before the Treasurer's banana republic predictions became a reality?

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister?

—The reference to the Minister in that question was a reference to the Minister for Trade. The Prime Minister, in his usual cowardly style, almost completely ignoredthe question in giving his wholly inadequate reply. He should have come clean. He should have admitted that under Labor Australia is no longer a good investment risk. He should have admitted that it was financially sound to move moneys overseas before the Treasurer's dire predictions became a reality.

SPEECH.PARA: It is sad that this country is in real trouble. Conclusive evidence is provided by the fact that the Minister for Trade is saying in effect: `Get your money out of Australia.' We could be compared with Latin America or Argentina. Does the Budget meet the needs of an embattled Australia? Of course not. Australia is a nation in crisis. The Budget is a weak-kneed and spineless attempt to trick the Australian public. Fuel tax continues to soar and unemployment will increase. Our dollar has virtually collapsed. Foreign debt will increase to about $100 billion this year, which is almost $6,700 for every man, woman and child in this country.

The projected Budget deficit is a fraud. Most of the lower forecast deficit has been achieved by raising expenditure rather than by cutting taxes. This is quite wrong and I believe that the Government will be recognised for what it is. The deficit estimate of $3.5 billion has been achieved by a postponement of tax cuts that would be worth $650m and delays in changes to pension arrangements, amounting to $300m. These are one-offs, so the real Budget deficit is likely to be $5 billion or more. The Budget blew out last year and that will happen again.

Inflation remains significantly higher than that of our overseas trading partners. It is more than 16 times that of Japan. Where will it all end? Where are we heading? Where is Australia going? There is no doubt that we are fast becoming a Third World country. Australia is in trouble under Labor. On 5 March 1983, the Labor Party was elected to the treasury bench. It came forward with a vision of a bright new Australia. The Prime Minister, prior to the election, said at the Sydney Opera House that there would be no new capital gains tax. What did we see in September 1985? We saw a capital gains tax announced. The Prime Minister said that fuel prices would drop by 3c a litre; not 1c, not 2c, but 3c. What has happened? Fuel excise has increased from 6c a litre to almost 24c a litre. This Government has a string of broken promises. This Government cannot be trusted by the people of Australia. This Government is disreputable. This Government is on the way out. This Government should stand up and admit that it has failed, because failed it has. Every opinion poll shows that Labor is destined to be cast on to the scrap heap of political history where it will join its discredited predecessor, the Whitlam Government.

I conclude by making a plea-it might fall on deaf ears, but I plead anyway-to this Government to consider the interests of middle Australia. I ask it to get off its ideological hobby horse and to reject extremism. I ask it to stand up for the ordinary man and woman. I ask it to support people who believe in family life and traditional values. I ask it to back people who want to work, people who have jobs and people who pay their taxes. I ask it to support people who are law abiding and honest, people who are not members of radical minority groups who constantly demand so many handouts that one would imagine they want a private pipeline to the Treasury. I ask it to back those people who risked their lives in times of war to keep us free and to preserve democracy. I ask it to support those people who are the very backbone of Australia, the people who are being rejected, and ignored by Labor. What about a fair go for Australia's forgotten majority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard many speeches from the Opposition tonight but very few of them have addressed the legislation before the House. We have heard all sorts of drivel, such as that which the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) came forth with, and references by many others to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his so-called travel allowance, all of which has nothing to do with the legislation in the three Bills before the House this evening, that is, the Income Tax Rates Bill and cognate Bills. Very few speakers have touched on them. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was one honourable member who at least attempted to address the questions before the House this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the questions before the House? We are looking at the taxation Bills, the last group of taxation Bills that are part of the overall package of taxation reform that this Government has brought before this Parliament over the last few months. It has been a fairly extensive package and the biggest reform of taxation this country has ever seen; not a wimp, but a major reform of taxation. The legislation before us tonight puts into law the fact that we will see the marginal rates of taxation in this country come down to 24c, 29c, 40c and 49c in the dollar as of 1 December this year and 1 July next year. The two top rates-if I may say them again-are coming down to 40c and 49c, the lowest marginal rates we have seen in this country. The Opposition can pontificate as much as it likes-I see the Leader Opposition (Mr Howard) has come into the House and he was Treasurer for five years-but the fact is that for 30 years successive conservative governments did nothing. In fact they left the top marginal rate at 60c in the dollar. We are the ones who will bring it down to 40c and 49c in the dollar.

As the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) trotted out a few statistics earlier, let me trot a few statistics back at him relating to the Government in which he was a Minister between 1975 and 1983. The Parliamentary Library statistical service has come forth with the fact that between 1975-76 and 1981-82, a person on average weekly earnings had his net tax as a proportion of income increased by 21.6 per cent. Worse still, the average wage at that time, of around $11,000, had a tax increase of 72.9 per cent. Worse still, someone earning $10,770-today's equivalent would be around $14,000 to $15,000-had a percentage increase in tax of 381 per cent. If we go to the other end of the table, someone earning $64,000 a year with a dependent spouse and two children-all these examples are people with a dependent spouse and two children-had his taxation decreased by 2.9 per cent. So the honourable member should not come into this House and talk about statistics and how things have improved or have not improved. That is what the Opposition did to the average wage and salary earner in its time in office. The average wage earner, earning less than $25,000, was absolutely slugged to high heaven while people earning $1,000 and more actually had a decrease in the percentage of the tax that they paid. That is what happened and that was at a time when the Fraser Government had the easy money. The statistics from this year's Budget show, as they have in previous Budgets, that for example in 1980-81 fuel tax receipts reached 8.9 per cent of total Budget receipts; nearly 9 per cent. What are they estimated to be in this year's Budget? The answer is 1.8 per cent. The Opposition when in government had the easy money and it slugged the average Australian to high heaven.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had the chance.

—The Opposition had the chance for 30 years, and for five of those years the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer in this House. He now comes into this place and pontificates about the tax system. What did he do? Nothing. In fact what is he going to do now? We do not know. The Opposition changes its mind all the time. The only thing that really grew in its time in government was the tax avoidance industry. As Mr Costigan stated, it was the biggest growth industry during the Fraser years.
—That is what it calls an initiative.
—That is right, an initiative, as the Minister stated. In fact in this year's Budget Papers at page 360 the following is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Collections from other (non-PAYE) individuals as a proportion of total receipts fell in the 1970s, reflecting the relative weakness in primary producer incomes and increased recourse to tax avoidance.

That is written in the Budget Papers; it is not a statement from a member of the House. Tax avoidance was rife. Opposition members have talked about what a great low taxing party theirs is. None of its mates paid tax at all when it was in government and that is probably why it slugged the workers so much. We have seen honourable members opposite come into this House and pontificate about this legislation, or at least some of them did. The majority have not even talked about the legislation that will bring great benefits to the people of Australia. For the first time we will see the two top marginal rates in Australia come down to 40c and 49c, and the two bottom rates to 24c and 29c in the dollar.

The honourable member for Fisher talked about what a low taxing party his is. I suppose he would point to the United States of America, which is in the process of reforming its taxation system also. He could probably point to that country and say that its proposals, which will be brought in shortly, are the sorts of things we should be looking at. The United States is proposing to introduce only two rates of marginal tax of 15c and 28c in the dollar. That sounds excellent; it sounds good; it sounds as though there is a rainbow around every corner. It is marvellous but, of course, the Opposition forgets to tell us that that is not the whole tax package. On top of that are State taxes, which average about 10 per cent and social security levies. The Medicare levy in Australia is 1.25 per cent and in America it is around 7 1/2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —No family allowances.

—As the honourable member for Dobell says, there are no family allowances in the United States of America. Most of the tax deductions are being wiped out in this reform package. In the United States there will be a tax shift in virtually exactly the same proportions that this Government has introduced in this country. It is a shift away from the pay as you earn taxpayer to companies which will pay slightly more. That is what is happening; there is no difference. (Quorum formed) The honourable member for Fisher talked about what a great low tax party the Opposition is. I have talked about the Australian tax measures and compared them with those of America-it has a new system-and they are virtually the same. The Opposition talks about capital gains. What is the United States of America doing? It is upgrading its capital gains tax; it is making it much tougher than what it will be in Australia. Those are the facts. Until this Government introduced the rather milder capital gains tax there was only one other country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development that did not have a capital gains tax or wealth tax. Let us not have this balderdash that members of the Opposition have carried on with.

SPEECH.PARA: We still do not know where the Opposition stands in regard to taxation. The honourable member for Mackellar would not tell us tonight. He wanted to talk about the travelling allowance of the Treasurer and all sorts of other things. He would not tell us what the Opposition would do. One minute the Opposition says that it will introduce such measures as a fringe benefits tax and the next minute it is not going to do that, as the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) said today.
Let us look at some of the things that the Leader of the Opposition has mentioned. The Treasurer used this quote recently and I will repeat it. The Leader of the Opposition said in 1980:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-and most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.

That is what the Leader of the Opposition said when he was the Treasurer of this country. As I said on 17 September in this House, the former Treasurer said on the Carleton-Walsh Report on 30 July this year:

I said when I made the announcement about the fringe benefits tax that what we were going to do was get rid of Mr Hawke's fringe benefits tax and that abuses in the areas-there were some, are some and would be some in the future-would be dealt with in another fashion.

In other words, the Opposition would get rid of the Prime Minister's fringe benefits tax but it would introduce the Leader of the Opposition's fringe benefits tax because the Opposition has still not moved away from taxing fringe benefits in some form or another. It does not matter how it is done. Is the Opposition concerned with taxing fringe benefits or is it not? Where does the Opposition stand on this matter? (Quorum formed) It is fairly obvious that the Opposition does not wish to debate this issue in any substance. This has been demonstrated all day and it is doing it again now. We do not know what the Opposition is doing with the fringe benefits tax; we do not know what it is doing with the taxation system in general.

Let me remind honourable members of some of the commitments the Opposition has made that are still on the record. It has said that it will introduce income splitting; that will cost $2.7 billion. The Opposition will have a flatter tax system, not a flat tax system. I do not know what that means. One needs a flat tax system of 33c in the dollar with a threshold of $5,000 to bring in the necessary revenue. The Opposition will not have that; it will have a flatter tax system. The honourable member for Mackellar has not quite decided what that means yet, but so be it. That will cost $1.6 billion. It will abolish the fringe benefits tax at a cost of $325m. It will abolish capital gains tax at a cost of $5m. It will abolish the tax on lump sum superannuation at a cost of $80m. It will reinstitute entertainment expenses at a cost of $310m. It will reinstitute negative gearing at a cost of $50m. It will have a full flow-on of world oil price reductions at a cost of $400m. It will abolish sales tax on oils and lubricants at a cost of $66m. It will abolish the tax on new oil at a cost of $165m. The provision of child care rebates will involve a cost of $108m. It will restore income equalisation deposits in in-out tax averaging at a cost of $23m. It will abolish the wine tax at a cost of $107m.

All this totals $5.9 billion. When the Opposition balances the books overnight, as it wants to, it will mean another $3.5 billion. On top of that it will fiddle with Medicare to disadvantage the poor, the underprivileged and the chronically ill, to the advantage of the people who have money, and it will abolish the assets test, so we come to a figure of $11 billion, which means that the entire education and defence budgets put together would be abolished. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is in the House and he would be glad to hear that. He would be glad to tell everyone connected with defence that the Opposition will abolish the entire defence budget. Where will the Opposition make up this $11 billion? It has not said anything. We have invited the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Mackellar again and again, and again tonight, but not one word has come forth on what they intend to do.

This legislation, which the Opposition refuses to speak about, is all about bringing down the marginal rates of tax to 24c and 29c with the two top rates of 40c and 49c in the dollar. It is something that has not been done under three decades of conservative governments in this country. The working people were absolutely demoralised by the Fraser Government, of which those honourable members opposite were members, but the people will be thankful when they receive the money in their pockets over the next six months, when they will see that this Government has brought fairness and equity to the taxation system.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise a matter which I believe is of the utmost concern to all members of the House. It is a question which the community is finding both disturbing and unacceptably costly. I refer to the vandalism of Australia's public telephone system. Before I comment further on this matter, I would mention that the staff of Telecom Australia has done a pretty good job this year. I notice in the latest report that a trading profit of $465m has been achieved.
—Madam Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
—A quorum is required. Ring the bells.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) walked into the House and then withdrew from the House. I suggest to you that under our Standing Orders, as he has entered the House there is an obligation for him to stay. I also draw your attention to the fact that there are a number of members standing outside the House, which is contrary to the Standing Orders.
—The honourable member for Leichhardt must not leave the House when the bells are ringing. (Quorum formed)

—I was trying to raise the question of vandalism of public phones, which obviously enraged the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I do not know whether he has any particular influence in this area. The fact is that in 1968 Telecom spent $18.9m on the maintenance of its 12,100 public telephones. Approximately $9m of that was directly attributable to damage caused by wanton vandalism. I am sure that all honourable members would agree with me that this is an atrocious state of affairs for the public telephone system in Australia. I believe that urgent attention is needed to correct this. So many people throughout Australia are being grossly disadvantaged by the fact that people are robbing public telephones and public telephones are not available for use by the general public.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the Government is not interested in this particular matter, because the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has drawn the attention of the House to the fact that there were not sufficient members of the Government present to maintain a quorum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tourism's contribution to Australia's national income and employment has now eclipsed that of the motor vehicle, footwear and clothing industries combined. This has not all just happened of its own accord. It has happened because the Hawke Government has recognised the enormous value of the tourism industry. A variety of successful measures has been established by the Hawke Government. These include the tourism overseas promotions scheme and the highly acclaimed Hogan advertisements produced for the Australian Tourist Commission which, I might add, has received from the Hawke Government a 160 per cent increase in its funding to a record of $26m over the past three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Above all, there is the inspired and capable leadership of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). He has given new life to the tourist industry, long moribund under the Fraser Government. There is no doubt that as a result of the Hawke Government's policies tourism has taken off. The number of international visitor arrivals passed the 100 million mark for the first time in 1984. Receipts were up 16 per cent on the previous year, to $1.4 billion. Australians travelling within Australia made some 58 million trips in 1984-85 and spent an estimated $13.8 billion. As at December 1985, about $5.5 billion had been spent on major tourism projects in Australia under construction or firmly committed. I am confident that industry and government promotional efforts will bring two million visitors to Australia in 1988. The Hawke Government has no illusions about the magnitude of that endeavour.

There is tremendous potential for further development of the industry. Whether it is grass-roots training in the kitchen or the bar or in management, training improves the service that customers receive, upgrades management knowledge and techniques, increases an employee's skills and self-esteem and creates a more efficient and responsive environment. Tourism is a service industry. It depends more on the quality of its staff than on bricks and mortar. Without properly trained people, hundreds of millions of dollars worth of investment is at risk.

In 1987, the James Cook University of North Queensland at Townsville plans to establish a tourism studies unit which will co-ordinate the university's undergraduates and postgraduates teaching in tourism. The tourism studies unit will conduct both basic and applied research, sponsor a tourism research-based publication series, represent the university on the tourism front locally, nationally and internationally and provide advisory consultancy services to government at all levels and to the tourist industry in planning and management policy matters.

There is no doubt that what has been an area of small business is rapidly developing into one with a much wider mix of company sizes. Moreover, there is growing pressure for public regulations, administration, monitoring and planning in the industry. Yet, at present, no specific training at a university level is being given to students who go into the industry in either the private or the public sector. The undergraduate program will aim to produce a graduate with a knowledge of critical factors in the industry and their impact on planning for tourism, and a knowledge of management principles and practices as they relate to the environmental, human resources, service and financial aspects of tourism.

The degree would be offered basically as a three-year full time course at the pass level and as a four-year full time course at the honours level. It would be a multi-disciplinary degree program with provision for part-time equivalents embracing theory and practical work and periods of work experience in the tourist industry. Masters and doctoral programs would aim to increase greatly the database on tourism and its activities, and to more accurately understand the industry's character, constraints and impacts within Australia, and more especially in north Queensland. For an industry of such significance it is remarkable how little research effort has been directed towards the study of tourism, especially within Australia. This is a long overdue activity at university level and I believe that James Cook University has a great deal to contribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is approximately three years since the Army first took an interest in the land around Cobar for an impact and manoeuvres area. During that time the people in that area have been subjected to a great deal of indecision and have been placed in limbo. The Army first looked at land around New South Wales and one of the places it looked at was south of Cobar, where the fight for survival was led by people such as Trish McInerney and Marie Forsythe. They led the battle against acquisition and eventually were fortunate enough to win that battle. The Army decided next to look at an area to the north-west of Cobar, where six families in the impact area would be affected. Those six families would have to leave the area and another 40 families would be affected by the Army moving into their area over a period of time. Of course that would affect the farming of this area. I have been to this area many times and I must admit that I have never seen people who have worked so hard to develop what is a fairly hard and harsh environment.
—Under great mental stress too.

—Under great mental stress. An anti-acquisition group was formed in that area. After a few months the Bathurst-Orange area was dropped from consideration by the Army after a great deal of pressure was put on it and the Government to do so. But the Cobar area is still under doubt. No one knows what is going on. The reason I raise this matter tonight is that in the proceedings of Estimates Committee E on 18 September 1986 a question was asked by Senator Sir John Carrick of a person attending that Estimates Committee. I must pay tribute to the honourable senator for the great work he has done in this regard. He asked, in effect, whether any money was set aside for the acquisition of land in the Cobar area. The following answer was given:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no money provided in this Budget for land acquisition, as I understand it.
In answer to a further question about whether any money was set aside for an environmental impact study, it was stated:
. . . I believe that there are some minor moneys in that consultancy segment.

I ask the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is present tonight: If it is the case that no money is set aside for acquisition and there is very little money set aside for an environmental impact study, when will he let these people know exactly what is going on--

TALK.START.PARA: —And let them off the hook.

—And let them off the hook, so that they know where they are going. Because of the drought that occurred a couple of years ago, because of the pressure put on them by the various taxes that are being applied and because of the downturn in the rural economy, these people are facing great hardship and they would like to know from the Minister exactly what the situation is. If it is correct, as was stated in the Estimates Committee, that there is no money for acquisition this year-I believe the situation is that the Government will not be able to find this money for many years to come-could the Minister please relieve the anxiety of these people by making a decision very, very soon? That will enable these people to get on with their lives, develop the area, allow their families to go to school and arrange their loans with the banks, which they are finding very difficult at the moment, and just do all those things that the people out there want to do. They want to work hard, develop their properties and make those applications that would normally be made at this time in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: In matters of commerce the fault of the Dutch
Is giving too little and asking too much.
The French are with equal advantage content,
So we clap on Dutch bottoms just twenty per cent.

I think he was referring to the bottoms of Dutch ships, but one just never knows, because that was before the age when sexism became an offence. But it is very important because it is popular these days to harangue and condemn the French. I could say that they are not the flavour of the month. The truth is that the French are an extremely resourceful race, they are an extremely inventive race and in many ways they are a very generous race. I have been asked to declare my interest. I will say that they have some great sheilas. Like every member of this House I receive propaganda from the French Embassy, as we receive it from other embassies. I was very interested, in glancing through it, to find that the company which makes 70 per cent of all teleprinters used in Australia is a French company-Sagem, I think. I was also very interested to read a report by the General Manager of the company. He said that he found Australian workers to be very attentive to detail, very productive and extremely well trained and that there was a very low level of industrial disputation. I thought his was a very noteworthy commendation of Australian workers, particularly given the abuse that is hurled upon them by Opposition members and their friends from the extreme socialist factions which have now started to spring up. By `extreme socialist' I mean the New Right, the national socialists. The national socialists who constitute the New Right are doing an enormous disservice to this nation. They are selling our workers short and are lowering our general national esteem in the eyes of the whole world. That is not a good strategy to adopt, I would have thought, if one is interested in the future of this country.

It is my belief that the future of this country lies in reindustrialisation. If we are to have jobs for our kids in the future, we must reindustrialise this country. But we cannot do it in the manner in which it was done in the past by the people who now occupy the Opposition benches. We cannot afford the luxury any more of inefficient industries which require large amounts of protection. In the reindustrialisation process we must rely very much on the intellectual capacity, industry and ingenuity of our people. All those attributes are present in abundance in the work force. They are being kicked to death by the national socialists of the New Right. That is a great disservice to this nation. If we are prepared to give the workers of Australia a go, and if we are prepared to recognise their innate ability, as the French do and as foreign companies do, we will succeed.

Talking about foreign companies, I have taken a great interest in the Government Aircraft Factories in Melbourne. The combined unions there have been extraordinarily efficient. They have pinpointed areas of mismanagement. They have overcome many of the problems of demarcation disputes. They have been very concerned about the use of material in the factory. Our reward to those people has been to sack them. The truth is that when representatives of the Westland helicopter company saw the factory they said; `My word, you can do anything in this country. You have the capacity and the ability to do absolutely anything'. It is a great tragedy that that ability is recognised by companies overseas, but that it is totally disregarded by the people who inhabit the Opposition benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday marked the anniversary of the introduction of the capital gains tax. There has been a lot of talk in the last few days about management practices and work practices. I draw to the attention of the House the need to look at some of the legislative practices which have been introduced by the Hawke Government. This is a matter which has not had a lot of public debate. That is for two primary reasons. The first is that assets held before September 1985 are exempt. Many people hold those assets and therefore capital gains tax does not concern them. The second reason why I believe the matter has not had a lot of the public limelight, as the fringe benefits tax has had, is that the legislation is incredibly complex, which is one of the hallmarks of this Government. So complex is it that the Government has no clues as to how much money it will bring in. When it was first mooted in September 1985 in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the mention of receipts from the capital gains tax was $25 million in the fifth year.

SPEECH.PARA: In the explanatory memorandum to the Bill there was talk about receipts of $5 million in 1986-87 and $25 million in the fifth year. In this year's Budget Papers, such is the state of confusion that page 271 of Budget Statement No. 4 states that the Government cannot work out what the tax will bring in in 1986-87 or in future years. So no estimate is given at all. Let us contrast that with a letter from the Treasurer addressed to colleagues to assist them in considering economic issues at the Australian Labor Party National Conference. On page 1 of a document entitled `Taxation Policy Initiatives of the Hawke Labor Government' the Treasurer states that the capital gains tax ultimately will bring in $200m to $300m. That figure is very different from the figure of up to $25 million, which is the highest in the cases I have cited.

I have been looking very carefully at the capital gains tax legislation and it is my view that one of the areas where we will see considerably more revenue accruing to government than has otherwise been expected relates to the definition of `principal residence' and to the exemptions available to Australian home owners. When one comes to grips with the complexities of the legislation, tens of thousands of ordinary Australian home owners will be paying capital gains tax under this legislation. Let me give some fairly straightforward examples which will occur in many cases around Australia and certainly in the case of Government members. I am glad that there are some in the House tonight to hear them. For example, the capital gains tax exemption will not apply where the family home is used for income producing purposes. Such a purpose would include a situation where a member of the family pays rent or board or where an office within that house is used for income-producing purposes associated with a business run by the owner of that house. That will certainly happen in many of the farming areas around Australia.

Secondly, it is claimed that two hectares is a definition of curtilage, thereby accruing the exemptions. That is not the reality. There are situations where properties of less than two hectares will accrue a capital gains tax. There will also be many circumstances where people own more than two hectares, but not much more than two hectares-for example, the 10-acre blocks which are very popular in outer metropolitan areas. Things such as the garden shed, which one can take off a family home block, will all be subject to capital gains tax and will be taxable at their full value because they represent the creation of an asset at a nil asset cost base. Other examples would include people who have retired to retirement villages and who do not have a title, lease or shares in the titleholding. For those people it is their family home. The reality is that it will be subject to capital gains tax.

I was surprised to hear from some of my colleagues who saw the program that the Leader of the National Party appeared. He was interviewed on that program without any representation at all from the Government side. What had happened after the time that the person doing the program had contacted me and had asked whether I would be prepared to go to the studio in this Parliament where members of the Parliament often do interviews? I discovered today, from reports I had from the 7.30 Report, that the Leader of the National Party had gone on that program and had been interviewed. His threat to the ABC resulted in the fact that the Government and the Whip were denied the right to put their position on that program last night. I ask whether a member of any political party in this House has a right to deny another member's participation in a program. I am rather ashamed to believe that the ABC allowed him to get away with that and that he was able to say: `No, I will not do the program'. I was informed, as the Government Whip, that the program would not go to air but he appeared on the program. That type of threatening position by the Leader of the National Party needs to be investigated, especially as the interview was to take place in Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House the hypocritical attitude of Government members in regard to the Government's taxation measures, and in particular the attitude of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who in the House today launched an attack in regard to taxation and supported the Government's measures. The honourable member for Capricornia, who is one of those lions in his electorate and a lamb when he gets down here, attended the annual conference of the Queensland Graingrowers Association in Rockhampton. Because he was representing the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Prime Minister had given him a copy of a speech to deliver at the conference, but he chose not to deliver it. I will not question why he chose not to deliver the speech that the Prime Minister had given to him, but I will question his attitude at the conference in regard to the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Robert Grover, the Association's financial services manager, asked Mr Wright:

Now that the Government (through the Fringe Benefits Tax Act) has the ability to calculate the tax on fringe benefits, what is its reason for imposing the tax on the employer and not the employee who is receiving the benefit?
The reporter who covered this was very careful to take down verbatim what the honourable member for Capricornia had said, and I shall repeat verbatim his statement:

What the Government decided, for political reasons, and I won't walk away from that, because we saw what happened when John Howard tried to do it in the mining industry, for political reasons to ensure it would go through it was decided to place it on the employer. For efficiency reasons, when you consider that you've got far less employers to deal with than you have employees, that because of the political aspects of getting it through it was the decision that was made.

It is a little different from the way in which the honourable member for Capricornia acts when he comes down here, because apart from trying to make attacks on the Queensland Government-he was defeated in that Parliament and decided to change Houses-he has made the statement that the Government made the decision on fringe benefits tax for political reasons. He is the man who has laid that charge against the Government, yet he comes down here and will not admit it in this House.

On taxation, the Government has tried to mislead the people of Australia. It has been around the country trying to sell the fringe benefits tax, and every time that a ruling comes out from the Australian Taxation Office, the anomalies start to appear. They appeared in the car parking spaces issue. If an employer gives to an employee a car parking space in an area where no free parking space is available, the employer has to pay a fringe benefits tax on the car parking space that is provided. Last night in this House, I told honourable members about funeral directors. If a funeral director provides accommodation to an employee who is looking after the mortuary, because that is an adverse situation according to the Taxation Office, he can get 40 per cent discount on the accommodation. But if it is onerous accommodation-if you are on 24-hour call-no discount is allowed. Which is the more adverse?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cause that I wish to raise in the House tonight concerns the disappearances that have been reported by Amnesty International in one of our near neighbours-Sri Lanka. I am disappointed that so many honourable members have sought to leave the chamber when a matter is raised that should be of concern to all of us.
—That is not right. That is unfair.

—I withdraw that. I did not mean to cast any aspersions, but I would hope that all members of parliament from all parties would share my concern on this. I compliment members of the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party who attended a Press conference on this matter convened by Amnesty International today.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some people who believe that Federal members of parliament should confine themselves to bread and butter issues, that the cause of human rights is somehow an esoteric or emotive matter and that we should not turn our attention to those questions. As you would be aware, Madam Speaker, this Parliament truly provides a model for parliaments around the world, given its already outstanding contribution to advancing the cause of human rights. The parliamentary group of Amnesty International has almost 100 members and, if those honourable members in the chamber tonight who are not already members of that group were to join, it would certainly top the 100 mark within the week. I encourage all honourable members to do that.

Turning my attention to the cause of human rights in Sri Lanka, I would mention that Amnesty International has produced a very comprehensive report on this question which is entitled `Disappearances'. It chronicles a human tragedy of 272 specific cases of disappearances. The evidence is that many of the people who are referred to in this report have been shot or have died after torture and been buried in secret graves or burned.

Before I go further, let me say that I do not seek to canvass the merits or otherwise of the internal politics of Sri Lanka. That is not my concern, nor is it the concern of Amnesty International. However, it is a concern of Amnesty to uphold some basic principles of human rights, and whatever differences separate us in this Parliament, I believe that we can rally round the basic principles of Amnesty International. They are, in essence, a concern for prisoners of conscience; that is, people who, for no reason other than their racial or ethnic origins, their religious beliefs or their political beliefs, are detained by a government. Amnesty's charter is strictly confined to circumstances where people have not advocated violence, so let there be no suggestion that Amnesty is some left wing front or some right wing push; it is truly a movement that can unite people of totally different political persuasions. It is also appropriate to place on record the long-standing friendship that exists between our country and the Government of Sri Lanka. Our friendship and co-operation dates back beyond the Colombo Plan and continues to this day. So it should. That places on us a very special responsibility to take a stand, and to express our concerns to the Government of Sri Lanka about these violations of human rights.

It has been suggested to me on occasions that it is not a proper concern of Amnesty or of foreign governments to take an interest in what are sometimes called the internal politics or the internal affairs of a country. Madam Speaker, you will be aware that, when you and I and others recently visited the Soviet Union, that view was taken on occasion by Soviet authorities and on other occasions by Polish authorities. But we asserted then, and I can say confidently that all honourable members would agree, that any country that is a signatory to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, as Sri Lanka became in 1980, can no longer, if it ever could, claim that human rights concerns are a matter for its internal consideration alone. It is a world issue and, increasingly, the Government of Sri Lanka must respond to these international concerns. I would call on all members of parliament to read the Amnesty International report, to back its concerns and to apply constructive pressure to the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure that these basic human rights standards are upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, the contribution by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: The time is 11 o'clock.
—No, it is not.
—It is not quite 11 o'clock.

—The earlier contribution by the honourable member for McMillan again brought to mind the single most consistent characteristic of the right wing members of the Australian Labor Party, which is that they squeal. They can dish it out, but they cannot take it, as the Victorian Branch of the Labor Party is finding as it accuses the New South Wales right wing of standing over it. For a member of this House to admit publicly his own humiliation seems to me to be rather extraordinary. It seems to be an invitation to be mocked. I find it curious that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and particularly the journalists in this place, could be stood over in the manner alleged by the honourable member for McMillan. It is a gross insult to their integrity, to their competence and to their strength of character.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Australian Government not informed of a `red alert' applied to the North West Cape installation as reported in the Brisbane Courier Mail on 21 November 1973.
(2) Should Australia have been consulted under the ANZUS Treaty and the US Naval Communications Agreement.
(3) Did this constitute a breach by the USA of these agreements.
(4) Has the USA further breached these agreements by refusing to inform Australia of a command sent to submarines through North West Cape to arm their nuclear missiles.
(5) Were bases in Australia alerted as a result of a low-level nuclear attack alert on or about 10.50 a.m. on 9 November 1979, which was later attributed to a computer malfunction.

(6) What steps has the Government taken to insist upon international surveillance of arms monitoring in present and future agreements with the USA in particular and what steps are possible and likely, leading up to the expiry of the Pine Gap agreement in 1987.
(7) Is Australia bound to support the USA should it become involved in a nuclear conflict.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable member to the answer given to Senate question on notice No. 300, Senate Hansard 5 October 1983, page 1181 and confirm that the alert status of US forces at North West Cape was increased in October 1973 without consultation with the Australian Government. This occurred before the Naval Communication Station became, in 1974, a jointly operated facility of the RAN and the US Navy.
(4) The Australian Government has no reason to believe that the US has ever breached either the ANZUS or the North West Cape agreements.

(6) The Government has not insisted upon international surveillance of arms monitoring in its existing agreements with the US on the joint defence facilities and has no intention of doing so in future. Nor is it the case that the agreement with the US relating to the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap will expire in 1987. While nuclear weapons are owned and under the exclusive control of individual countries rather than the international community, it would not be realistic to expect the US and USSR to transfer to international control their existing systems for verifying the other's compliance with arms control agreements.

(7) Australia has no binding legal obligation to provide military support to the US in those hypothetical circumstances. However should the situation arise, the Government of the day would naturally give due weight to the broad interests it shares with its US ally as well as to the specific obligations contained in the ANZUS Treaty in determining what support would be appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department reclassifying income for eligibility of the aged pension; if so, (a) what changes are being made, (b) how many pensioners will be affected and (c) how many persons will have their pensions reduced or cancelled.
(2) Is there abuse of the aged pension benefit; if so, to what extent.
(3) Will the Government give adequate warning of changes in eligibility criteria so that pensioners can make necessary changes to their financial affairs.
(4) Has he directed that all his Department's reductions in benefit payments should affect the aged; if so, why.
(5) What action will he take to ensure pensioners will not worry unnecessarily about pension cuts.
(6) Does the receipt of communications from his Department often cause its clients undue alarm; if so, what action has he taken to overcome this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) While considerable numbers of age pensioners are placing funds in a range of relatively sophisticated investments, including forms of investment introduced onto the market in recent times, there is no reason to conclude that the age pension program is being abused. In accordance with standard practice my department is examining the proper application of the existing provisions of the Social Security Act to these new products as well as the consistency and comprehensiveness of existing guidelines dealing with investments in general. Should any legislative change be required to treat in a consistent manner all investments which produce support for the investor, this will be subject to normal parliamentary procedures with associated debate and publicity.
(4) and (5) I have given no directions that there should be reductions in benefit payments nor that any reductions in benefit payments should affect the aged.

(6) I am aware that official communications always have the capacity to cause concern to clients especially elderly clients. My department has been consciously following a policy of simplifying its communications and of providing its clients with more comprehensive information to minimise this possibility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the US Department of Defense has discarded the tendering requirement for man-portable anti-armour weapons capable of destroying the main battle tanks of an opposing force.
(2) If the US Department of Defense has taken this action is he able to say why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the US Army has not discarded the competitive bidding process for the acquisition of man-portable anti-tank weapons systems. The Competition in Contracting Act of 1984, part of the Budget Reduction Act of 1984, requires that the competitive bidding process be carried out.
